description:
This is really a Hipsterville cafe. I wanted a cup of coffee and walked into a place full of hipsters mulling around the tables with laptops everywhere.  The latte was really good and for a moment made me want to give up chain coffee like Peet's and Starbucks.  

They have a cute corner magazine section where folks would survey the mags but I didn't see anyone buy any. Long lines for a weekday around noon. Don't these hipsters even work?
author: Ry T.

description:
This is a super cute coffee shop in Potrero Hill. I love the matcha latte here. The place itself is also super spacious and has great lighting, and a lot of random magazines/books for those looking to read a little. There's plenty of seating and tables also for others who are looking to do some work or study sessions!

They have a really cute outdoor seating area too, which I personally love because sitting outside is really nice when it's not too cold or windy.
author: Theresa L.

description:
Highlights: the carrot zucchini walnut bread was absolutely delicious. They give you a solid chunk; Id return to get it again

Low: The espresso macchiato tasted burnt and acidic. Probably one of the worst I've had.
author: Kimberlee G.

description: Great place to work on your laptop or catch up with friends over a hot coffee. They serve small bites, too. I liked my oat milk latte to stay along with the coconut milk chia pudding- super yummy!
author: Meryam B.

description: Cute cafe in Potrero Hill! I wish I had spent more time here, because it seems like a great place to pull out a book and read or catch up with friends. I ordered the Golden Milk latte with oat milk and it was definitely one of the tastier ones that I've had, having the perfect balance between sweet and spicy. Service was very pleasant and friendly and I like how they have a typewriter in the back near the magazines!
author: Samantha C.

description: Cute cafe in Potrero with indoor and outdoor seating. The cafe is pretty poppin so it may be difficult to find seating inside (especially on weekend afternoons), but I recommend this cafe if you're looking to chill with a book (no outlets)! Not so good for heart to heart conversations because tables are so close to each other unless you don't mind people hearing you get rejected and almost cry during a determine-the-relationship talk for example
author: Annie S.

description: (3.5 stars) Really solid drip coffee, plenty of seating, and a unique neighborhood-like feel. However, the seating is remarkably uncomfortable and it seems like every table is wobbly. The walls have a back panel that sticks out which provides support but is neither comfortable nor conducive for reading. The outdoor patio area does look pretty snazzy though.
author: Jason S.

description:
I recommend this as an ideal coffee stop as you patiently wait the 45min -1hr wait for Plow a block away that is a must for breakfast or brunch.  

Farley's has a delicious selection of coffees, Gourmet coffee drinks and yes, magazines.  You may be fortunate enough to get a mocha drink signed in chocolate syrup.

You can easily lose sense of time just relaxing here in the cozy interior or just outside on a patio that is shared by a few businesses.

Parking- no issues finding spots but be prepared to hike the steep inclines on Texas street!

-Dog friendly
-Corner bookstore a block away
author: Etienne H.

description: AMAZING coffee- must go. We went here waiting to get a table in Plow - like a lot of people. Almost wanted to just stay here and eat - but we were so close to getting a table in Plow. Will go again - this time just for Farley's! Such warm people too.
author: Namrata J.

description: Excellent coffee, people, and beautiful place. Farley's is in the lovely Potrero Hill (16th street) part of San Francisco that takes one out of the crazy tech drunk atmosphere that prevails in most of the City.
author: Bryan G.

description: Amazing place to post up and work. Also a super cute neighborhood. There is literally not one outlet though, and I pretty much always need at least one :(
author: Hareem M.

description:
Small, quiet coffeeshop in Potrero Hill. They even have a magazine section! Nice touch.

They have a rule of no cell phones at the register.

I didn't get to spend any time hanging out in the coffeeshop but people seem nice.

I ordered an iced mocha, pretty standard.
author: Monica G.

description: Super cute coffeeshop and super friendly staff. Locals flock here, it seems. We sat outside in the parklet in front of Farley's and truly enjoyed our coffee drinks and snacks. I really enjoyed the mushroom empanada and matcha latte. Great vibe!
author: Jan Z.

description: When visiting from vancouver I went to Farley's for an morning coffee. I brought my dslr and took a few photos of my friend, his 3 yr old nephew, and my girlfriend. To my surprise, the guy who served us decided to pull out his phone and shove it in my face as if he was taking photos of me. He said he was offended that I was taking photos of my friends. I was shocked, told him off, and am now leaving this review. Brutal incredibly rude experience. I hope the owner deals with him.
author: Courtney W.

description: Great neighborhood spot with solid coffee, good bit of seating, and a magazine corner with a fun little typewriter. There's also solid savory and sweet options to munch on --- the daily special happened to be a very good vegetarian chili the day I was there. Almond latte is also on point and people working behind the counter are nice.
author: Jay K.

description:
Cute cafe, but no outlets at all!
If you are looking for a place to work for few hours, and don't have your laptop charged - i do not recommend this place.
Their chai is a little watery too. Otherwise it's located in a cute neighborhood.
author: Erika S.

description: Great place for a cup of coffee on a nice sunny day. The outdoor area is the best. Grab a bite from Provender next door then get a cup of almond latte here. What I love most about this place is their add-shots a double. The lovely people that work here is really friendly.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
It was a freezing Xmas eve morning and we were subjugated to wait 45 mins for Plow (It didn't help that I had wet hair).

After about 30 mins I needed something to warm my hands and came here for a chai tea. They use the mix from the SF chai cart (which is nice - since I have never tried the chai art - but always want to. BUT insider tip I noticed AFTER I ordered - only 2 sizes , the small is $3.55 and the large is $4.05 - so go ahead and get the large.

My only gripe is that is was not very crowned and the wait for my tea was so long (17 mins) that we missed our original call for a table at Plow - Luckily they put us right back on the list and we only waited another 7 or so mins.

Lesson learned - put your name in at Plow and come here for a coffee or Tea IMMEDIATLY (and get the large). You are welcome.
author: Amy W.

description: Great early morning spot to find coffee, chit chat with the friendly barista and muse through interesting magazines.
author: David O.

description:
Came here for a hang out with friends after church. A rather interesting coffee shop located in Potrero Hill, this place features coffee/tea & pastries with small lunch options + both indoor & outdoor seating. Ordered a iced chai tea latte at the counter. To describe the ambience, lots of tables & chairs in the indoors along with some couches/sofas near the front/windows with board games to entertain goers and the outdoor seating features tables & chairs. It took longer than I thought it should for the baristas to fulfill the order after being placed, but it didn't bother me too much (it might for those less patient). Now, as for the product itself? It came out okay. Sweetness was there, but it lacked the sharp slight bitterness that should distinguish good chai tea. There was also too much ice in the drink as well. All in all, a decent & okay option for coffee/tea and pastries.

P.S. Wifi also available here, but there's a 2-hr time limit so consider yourself warned if you're planning on trying to complete a long study session here (it won't really work unless you're willing to turn your phone into a Wifi hotspot).
author: Jack M.

description:
I mostly like this place. Highlights:
- good coffee 
- nice outdoor area with seating (yay if you have dogs)
- good location 

Things that are okay:
- vibe inside is okay but could be a little cozier

Not like:
- expensive for the sizes you get 

Overall, a nice place to grab a weekend coffee or have a nice working breakfast.
author: Grace A.

description:
Pros:
Nice place to study, plenty of seating when I came on a Tuesday night. Wifi was available with no password needed. Presentation of the coffee was on point, as was the taste (more on the sweet side for the mocha latte). Cute cafe with a patio and fake grass outside, as well as a magazine/book shelf inside. Open later compared to other cafes (9pm). 

Cons:
Parking is a little hard since there are hills on both sides. I didn't see where the outlets were so I'm not sure how readily available they are.
author: Jessa May C.

description:
Came here when we were waiting for a table at Plow. This was on a Sunday morning around 9:15 AM.

Drink: We both got a mocha, they were rich with chocolate and super filling. They both had words written in chocolate sauce, one said "enjoy" and the other said "thank you". I've never been anywhere where they write stuff on the coffee so I thought that was cute. 

Service: Super friendly staff. It was pretty busy so it took about 10-15 mins to get our drinks, but luckily we weren't in a hurry. 

Ambiance: Very cute and rustic feel to the coffee shop with both outside and inside seating. We got a little table inside right away. They have a lot of magazines to look at and good music playing. They are dog friendly which is great!
author: Hayley D.

description:
Farley's San Francisco is a small cafe located in San Francisco's Portrero Hills neighborhood. Although located on steel hills, the cafe is nicely situated alongside other mom and pop shops.

For the positives - Farley's San Francisco is in a nice neighborhood. If you walk around you'll hit a few artisan shops with friendly owners. The artisan feel is very San Francisco. Also, the food and coffee here is not bad. It's slightly above average with pretty delightful pastries. 

For things to improve - the ambiance in this Farley's is a far cry from the one in Oakland. The cafe is always crowded with no space or room for creative deep focus. In fact, the cafe feels a lot like a regular coffee shop chain during their busier days. So, this is an unfortunate turn off especially since it's located in a nice neighborhood.

Overall, I give this Farley's an okay rating of three stars. They have above average coffee and pastries but poor, crowded ambiance during peak periods. So, I recommend visiting Farley's only if you're able to visit on less busy periods.
author: Jon T.

description: Pretty impressed by the coffee, matcha lattes, and pastries here. The flat white I had was great although I would have liked it to be slightly stronger. Really good espresso with the sweetness and nuttiness a nice shot of espresso has. The matcha latte was also good but again, would have liked it to be a little stronger in matcha flavor. A good amount of both indoor and outdoor seating too so this seems like a great place to grab some coffee and hang out or to get some work done at. I'll definitely be back!
author: Seema U.

description:
Dropped in here because I was looking for somewhere to work/hang out outside of my apartment. It's a nice spot. Very chill, friendly vibe. There's a bunch of tables inside and some outdoor seating on a little patio. They're also open late, until 9PM!

There's free WiFi but there's a 2 hour limit, so it's not the most ideal spot if you're looking to really get work done. There's also no A/C (just 2 ceiling fans), so it's not a great spot if you're looking to escape those rare SF heat waves.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Spacious spot right down the street from PLOW with a bunch of magazines on hand for you to read. Reminds me a little like the Barnes & Noble magazine area.

As for the Latte, it's nothing special. Has a very noticeable burnt taste to the coffee, for those of you who are about that. Probably wouldn't go out of my way to grab something here.
author: Eric N.

description: Love this place. Found it last minute on Yelp and honestly I think I found my new reading spot. They have an outdoor area that's patched with fake grass and table.. it's perfect. They make a great cappuccino and it's very well lit, naturally.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: This place had a decent vibe but it wasn't for me. I specifically came here to get some work done. This place didn't have any power sockets which was annoying. The tables and chairs were more suited for conversation than work,  meaning not suited for hours of sitting. The place was also quite noisy. I got a Gibraltar which was great, although pricey for the amount of coffee. Maybe good for a chat with friends but not coffee.
author: Mackie M.

description: One of the most charming coffee shops I've been to. Grab a tea or coffee and snag the corner spot by the window and enjoy Potrero Hill sights and sounds.
author: John H.

description:
Good place to pit stop while you wait for Plow on the corner. 

Staff was attentive and the coffee is strong. I personally liked my friend's hot chocolate more than my cafe au lait. Liked how they served free self serve water for guests. 

Crowded when I stopped by on a Sunday morning but it could just be the Plow guests waiting for a table too. Nice place to stop by but the area isn't too popping to be there for anything besides brunch. 

Looks like a good place to get some work done if you're in the area though! Saw some people on that grind
author: Carissa G.

description: Farley's has a great vibe. What I don't like about most coffee shops is that they are used as a study more than a social gathering location. Most of the patrons on a Saturday were young professionals and came in groups to hang out or buy coffee to go. I like that it is also a place for people watching. All these are in addition to great coffee!
author: Doruk B.

description:
Met up at Farley's for a casual date. This is definitely a neighborhood spot. Seating inside was full and we grabbed the last remaining table outside. The latte art was very nice. I had to bring it outside by myself and the klutz that I am nearly spilled it.

The ambiance is alright. It's not a destination coffee shop but it's perfect if you live nearby.
author: Yi Z.

description:
GET THE MOCHA. Not too sweet & will have you wired for the rest of the day.

Cinnamon roll (more like a croissant covered in icing chock full of raisins) is out of this world.

Love the wifi policy that promotes minimal screen time & meeting your neighbors. Great vibe. Will be back!
author: Sarah U.

description:
I normally never eat anywhere unless I've done a ton of research on the restaurant/cafe beforehand (I'm a methodical foodie, folks!) in order to avoid disasters and unpleasant surprises such as walking into a steakhouse only to find out there's nothing for you to eat (ooh, never again!).

However, when faced with a wait time of over an hour and a half for brunch at The Plow right across the street and a much needed catch up session with my brunch buddy, we decided it was worth the risk to stumble into Farley's and grab a tea, maybe a small bite, and sit down for a chat. 

And good news, Farley's doesn't disappoint! This cafe has plenty of indoor and outdoor seating and on an early Sunday afternoon was filled with lots of busy bees on their laptops and studying with a full array of books. This cafe reminded me a lot of my college days in that the cafes on and around campus are filled to the brim with students, and it strangely made me feel at home? To be fair, I graduated from college less than a year ago, so it would make sense why Farley's would have that sense of comfort for me!

Farley's had a nice selection of teas and pastries, and I ordered the Pacific Peppermint tea with a salted caramel fudge brownie. The tea was refreshing and cooling, but ehh it's peppermint tea, so you can find this anywhere, but the brownie was AMAZING. It was perfectly fudgey and dense and the salted caramel drizzle on top balanced out the indulgent chocolate in the brownie -- definitely the winner for me. 

Farley's makes a great spot to study on a lazy weekend afternoon and a lovely place to pass the time if you're waiting to eat brunch at The Plow. If I'm back in the area again, I'll be making a repeat visit!
author: Pooja M.

description: Loveeee their coffee and will probably take detours to end up here for their coffee again. :) apart from the few steps, it's a pretty kid friendly place. They have a nice selection of breakfast breads - we got banana walnut bread and was delish!
author: Aditi S.

description: This is apparently the Plow overflow waiting spot.  Loved the ambiance and the menu that includes several healthy options.  I chose a matcha au lait and chia pudding.  The games were a huge draw and really helped pass the time.  I love cafes so I'll definitely be back seprate from brunch plans at Plow.
author: Lance D.

description:
Farley's is such a quaint and homey coffee shop.  I can see why it's landed on quite a few "best cafes in SF" lists.  There is lots of space inside and outside to sit, and it's not too crowded, even at prime brunch time on a Saturday.  There are rows of magazines, divided into sections by subject (of course, with a full selection of food and tech themed reading material... oh, SF), well organized and in great condition.

I had the cold brew, which I thought was just fine and not incredible.  Just thankful it's not too sour, but it could have been smoother.  I added in a little almond milk (they don't carry soy milk), cinnamon, and Splenda to sweeten it up.  

My boyfriend's cappuccino had a pretty design in it (he took a sip before I could photograph it).

Service was great.  I asked for light ice, and the barista showed me the level of ice in the cup to make sure it was what I wanted, before he added coffee in it.  My cold brew came out immediately, and my boyfriend's drink came about 5 minutes later.  If I were in Potrero Hill again, I'd grab a coffee here for the atmosphere, but I wouldn't get coffee here if it was just for takeout.
author: Christina G.

description:
This is the second time I've been here in a week.   My partner had a latte and I had a mocha.  Both delicious.   My only complaint is there is only one outlet in the entire place.   :( When finished with your drink, you may refill it with drip coffee for one dollar.  Can't go wrong.   

A simple neighborhood coffee shop.  Will be returning soon.
author: William G.

description: tasty coffee in an open atmosphere. They have a cool assortment of baked goods and art. It's a popular place for people working with the free wi-fi. The house brew and mocha were both solid-mocha was so good I didn't leave any for my friend to try. The atmosphere is of a hipster coffeehouse so you're not going to get a big fake smile when they take your order which I don't mind. Great place to grab a drink from as you wait to get into Plow down(up?) the street.
author: Jessie Elizabeth J.

description: i stopped here because i'm going to a concert and the place opens early so i can go before waiting at the venue for 12 hours and the coffee taste marvellous, that's the beginning of a good day
author: Jeanne D.

description: Excellent matcha lattes! We came here while waiting for our table at Plow.
author: Sharon D.

description:
Finally almond milk latte that is made perfectly. Some vegan options salads, sometimes soups, fruit, banana bread. Not alot of options but some.

Wait time is okay. Order a drip coffee if your in a rush. 

Will come again
author: Ms. B.

description:
I come from generations of coffee addicts, the types of people who will drink three cups a day despite developing cysts, because it's that good. I held off until last year, and then I just couldn't stop. Go figure. I'm drinking iced coffee right now.

I have absolutely no clue how I have not yet written a review for Farley's considering I work out of there almost every single day. Their inside seating is spacious and their interior is unapologetically hipster. A well stocked magazine rack and small standing table are there to accompany you while you're waiting for your beverage (all of which are excellent). The parklet outside is equally lovely. 

I've seen throngs of people give up on Plow to grab a sandwich from Hazel's Kitchen and a coffee from Farley's. This is never ever a bad idea. Farley's also has good smaller bites--I have likely eaten several loaves of their banana bread, on my own. And the water cooler always has a different label. My favorite was "life juice," but I believe it is currently labeled "maximum power elixir." 

Don't forget: if you plan on working at a coffee shop, be the hero our city deserves, and bring a power strip.
author: Nicole C.

description: I have been coming to Farleys for 10 years they are a great collective of people and Carly does a great job running the place
author: James C.

description: Always great coffee and friendly service. I've never had a bad experience here, and this was my favorite coffee shop when I worked in Potrero Hill. It's most definitely worth the walk up the hill for Farley's over some of the other options lower in the neighborhood.
author: Adam H.

description: Farley's book signing and cafe's journals made by the customers. This place is a treasure trove!  I've tried the Gibraltar: mighty Cortado style coffee!
author: Mario F.

description:
This coffee shop was actually featured on a show called "Bay Area Drop In" which was broadcasted on KTSF channel 26. After hearing some information about Farley's from this show, I decided to come in for a cup of latte today. The coffee and service are both very good. Two of the baristas were friendly and the facility looked clean.

There are racks filled with magazines to read while your pastry and coffee. Props to this feature! This is a very compact sized coffee shop. Indoor and outdoor seating also available. Overall, very good first experience here so I'll definitely be back.

Reason for rating:
- Compact sized coffee shop (+1)
- Good coffee and good service (+1)
- Clean facility and friendly staff (+2)
author: Bennett W.

description: I got to try their apple cider here, and it was SO good!! This is a wonderful place to sit in, the interior is very warm and welcoming. It would be a beautiful place to sit and chill on a rainy day or perhaps to meet a friend. Very good, definitely recommend.
author: Claire L.

description:
Not sure if we came on an off day but the customer service was almost nonexistent. Does it hurt to be smile for your customers? The lady taking my order and gentleman making my order seemed annoyed by our presence(or maybe everything). Not sure if theyre portraying an "in" pretentious attitude (whatever is cool nowadays) or they hate their job or maybe both! Save your moola and go to another coffee shop where they will be nice to you or at least crack a semi smile. 

latte was just o.k.
author: Yerm I.

description: "Getting a little gnarly at Farley's" is what I used to say. Gosh, how I miss San Francisco's coffee shop scene. And I wouldn't recommend walking around at night in this charming Potrero hill neighborhood, especially with a bag , because there are stick up artists that drive around looking for there next naive victim. I got a story to tell about myself and my Sony A 3 camera along with my 1300 dollar lens and tripod. If I didn't get wind of these two characters casing me, I wouldn't of been able to walk to my car in time and drive off. If you stay around the crowds you'll be ok, but if you walk several blocks outside of the action either to the right or left, you're asking for trouble. There are some angry ghetto folk in the Potrero Hill projects situated peripherally outside the wonderful fine folks with lovely abodes aloft these charming Potrero hills overlooking downtown San Francisco. That's one thing I truly despised of San Francisco. New "transplants" as I called them are quick to optimistically defend this "perfect city" without ever daring to speak the truth of how you ought to be wary  in San Francisco. Stay in the parameters of the Potrero Hill stores and private shops, then call an uber from here, and you'll be fine.
author: Clifford E B.

description: Great place to work and socialize with neighbors. Baristas are all very kind.
author: Anton E.

description: Moments at Farley's are always special moments, no matter if you go there for a coffee with your partner, with your dear friend or to work in silence. Nice coffee, delicious cakes and pleasant staff!
author: Selma T.

description:
Hung out here with my laptop for a few hours yesterday after getting brunch at Plow a block down. On a Tuesday afternoon, the place wasn't too full or loud and was great for a chill afternoon with some coffee or tea. Great FREE wifi that was faster than I expected! The staff are all extremely friendly, and they seemed to be familiar with a few regulars that dropped by. The furniture was a bit old though - a lot of the leather covering on the booth seating was split open.

I didn't have any complaints about my chai latte. They didn't oversteam the milk, making it impossibly hot to drink, which I find that a lot of cafes tend to do.

Not really a coffee shop that I would go out of my way for, but it's nice if you're already in the area.
author: Tiffany P.

description: There is not much street parking as this block gets pretty packed on the weekends. Lucky i was able to find a spot right across the street around 11am on a Saturday. There were a lot of people seated in the outdoor seating area and the inside was full. There was about 3 people in front of me in line to order. I ordered a latte and it was about 4 bucks. The typical price for a cup of decent coffee in the neighborhood. They had a variety of baked goods and salads. They sell T-shirts and books/magazine(i think, since there is a shelf in the back right corner). This is a great place to enjoy a good Saturday morning with a cup of coffee and a book. But if you do not like loud and crowded places, this may not be the spot for you,
author: Jan H.

description: Cute neighborhood cafe, I like to walk here first thing in the morning to get my Matcha fix. Family friendly. They also have a magazine corner and board games.
author: Yuan Z.

description: $4.25 for a small nonfat latte. A bit watery, medium- full body, medium-dark roast, not that complex. Milk wasn't steamed that well so that it's creamy tasting. A little better than what you'd get at Peet's. I'd give it 3.5 stars. I could almost add an extra half star at for being open on Sunday at 9 pm.
author: Will N.

description: Love the coffee and they make perfect lattes every time! Super nice staff and the place is cozy :)
author: Johanna J.

description: No power outlets. Not good for laptop work if you're not privileged enough to own a new computer. Perfectly hospitable to the wealthy! The employees were nice about it, the class-discriminating policy is not their fault.
author: Danny T.

description:
What a happy place to rest tired feet after a walk up the hill from BART :)

The staff is friendly. The cappuccino and americano were good!

I can't wait to go back and spend time on the wonderful patio. They have a wide magazine selection.
author: Lee A.

description:
neighborhood coffee shop. About as opposite from a starbucks as there is. Good coffee/tea. 

Stopped by to see friend of friend play west african music. 

Small, most tables taken with people studying or browsing internet. Free wifi. 

hot tea in ceramic cups / no paper cups here!!!
author: Doug C.

description: Love this cafe. Really great atmosphere which they put an effort into creating as they limit the time that you can spend on Wifi to two hours which is understandable. They also have a parklet outside which is great on sunny days.
author: Betty F.

description:
TL;DR - Five stars for some of the best lattes and cappuccinos I've had in SF and a super cool atmosphere. Minus stars for poor, absent minded, snail paced service.

I would honestly only come here if I needed to chill at the actual cafe. If you're in a rush a need to grab a drink (quickly), I would steer clear. 

It took a good 10 minutes to get one latte.... Probably because the barista was more interested in taking her sweet ass time and chatting with coworkers rather than expediting drinks for the customers still waiting for their drinks....
author: Crystal Z.

description: Friendly, but the coffee was burnt and tasted bad, and their chai was watery. Would like this place if they had anything worth drinking since their magazines are fun.
author: Haru M.

description:
Farley's is a very cool neighborhood cafe located over in Potrero Hill. I really like the laid back feel once you get inside. Everyone here seems to be very friendly, and I really enjoy their outdoor seatings too. They are very dog friendly and you always see someone sipping their favorite beverage outside with their dogs.

Their coffee here is nice and smooth, the Baristas are super nice, and their cappuccino is a must. What more can you ask for!!

Until then, Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description: Came here to do my school project which involved interviewing people. Very chill vibe, the baristas and the customers here are all very nice (the baristas even helped participate in my project). They have enough seating both inside and outside. There is wifi but only a 2 hour limit. Would definitely come again!
author: Grace D.

description: Came here on a Sunday after I failed to notice that a store I was going to wasn't open till 11. So I decided to come here and wait till the store opened. It was super busy but I was able to get a small table. I was going to order a soy latte because I thought that was the only plant based milk they had but the cashier let me know they also have almond milk (which he didn't have to tell me to save himself some time). No complaints with my latte it was perfect and I liked the little leaf detail they added on top of it. They have seating indoors and outdoors so if you're out and about with your fur baby you both will be welcomed. A lot of people had their dogs off leash so if you're not comfortable with dogs or your dog doesn't like other dogs then I'd advise you go elsewhere. Great location and I found parking easily. Will definitely stop by again whenever I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Cristal F.

description: This place gets pretty loud, plus the wifi is limited to 2 hours, but that stuff just comes with the personality of the place. Well decorated, nice people working there, you feel like the place has been around for a while
author: Michelle C.

description:
Charming atmosphere, pretty good coffee (latte on the sour and lighter side, not sure which beans it is using--maybe Four Barrel?). It was just down the street from Plow, so we spent our time here waiting for Plow and enjoying the coffee, instead of waiting in the cold.

There's plenty of seat, lots of locals on Sunday, lots of magazine (Current issues! Many art and scientific ones! Thumbs up!). It is also very dog friendly! We saw an adorable dog walking around the cafe, and people just absently petting it as it went by, I am sure this is a normal occurrence :D
author: Ya K.

description:
Coffee --------------------------------- 3-3 1/2
Starter Bakery Quiche ------------ 4 1/2
Service -------------------------------- 4

Repeat visit when in the neighborhood

Expect long lines in the popular place especially on the weekend.

Decent place visit

Offers Starter Bakery baked goods ... veggie quiche my fav
author: S.K. Y.

description: Awesome coffee and great wifi! They have ample seating but during peak hours it can get a little busy. The only complaint I have for this place is that they do not have enough power outlets.
author: Supriya G.

description:
Hey, I'm going to review for the workspace and not so much for the drinks. (Sue me...? No regrets.)

I headed here with my coworkers at about 10 AM to start doing work at Farley's. Because I don't really go over to Portero Hill that often, I'm not very familiar with the coffee shops around this area or their quality. 

Service and Space:
The baristas are friendly enough, since I didn't really talk to them. They're willing to ice your drinks and adjust the contents according to your wishes, and like socializing with each other as well as the customers. This space doesn't feel like all the tech-industry workers have sucked out the energy and are here to enjoy their time, not just their work. The music is calming, too.

Drinks and Food:
I ordered the ginger root tea, which was surprisingly spicy (and I liked it!) It isn't overpowering, but since they give you the tea leaves to steep for as long as necessary, you can adjust the strength of your tea. The mushroom empanada that I tried (my coworker bought one) wasn't very crisp, though.

Overall, I'd return here for the ambiance. Try to get the corner circular table, with pillows! Outlets might be hard to run by over here, but it's worth it. If not, take your friends here to talk to them outside in the cute wooden chairs.
author: Kat P.

description: Great coffee! I like their iced coffee, with  a shot of espresso.. I've also tried their espresso shot by itself, it's pretty good. And strong. Maybe with a little cream for me. It's good. They'll put it in a tiny cup. Good people too that work there.. The place seems to get full too. I've seen a few long lines. And prices are pretty average, i think. $4.75 was my total for the iced coffee. (That's including my $2 tip!). . They also have some selection of foods, and snacks. I've tried their chicken empanada last time and a croissant. The chicken empanada was good with their sauces.. but yes, good place to sit and rest and have coffee, they also have a front patio for more seating! And few places to plug your phones. Plus free WiFi. :)
author: Mariana O.

description: Love hanging out at Farley's. Plenty of room to sit with a coffee and get work done. Staff is cool. Outside patio is a perfect place to start the day in Potrero Hill.
author: Nicholas V.

description:
Unpretentious hipster.

Unpretentious:
- Fairly plain coffee shop ambiance, nothing too minimalist, with a hint of warehouse like the rest of Dogpatch
- Interesting newsstand indoors that almost looks like part of a convenience store
- Nice patio area outside with turf, which I find cute and funny
- Gratefulness tree (like the ones at temples in Japan)
- Helpful and friendly baristas 
- Loyalty stamp cards!

Hipster:
- Almond milk option
- Stamped branded paper coffee cups
- Fancy display of pastries with handwritten signs
- Communal tables
- Fairly pricey (~$4 for my almond milk latte)
- Being in the Dogpatch neighborhood
author: Edna C.

description: I like the hot chocolate because it's not too sweet or overpowering. Also there was live music, and lots of free seating!! I had a pecan bar. I biked here. I had a great day today. I went to the art store and got lots of stuff. The live music guy sang r and b and jazz. The dude made some cool designs on our hot chocolates. It's so cold outside that's why I love hot choco.
author: Maya R.

description: Sloooooooooooooooooooow. 12 min to steam an apple cider already made. Migod. People have transit to catch and jobs to go to.
author: A W.

description: Stopped by while waiting for our table at a nearby brunch spot on a Saturday. Cozy decor and warm vibe. Had a coffee ($2.75) and a Gibraltar ($3.50). Enjoyed the coffee and loved the atmosphere. Get place to pass the time on a rainy Saturday.
author: Ray K.

description: I find the coffee and baked goods fairly typical here, plus the servers always seem rather unenthusiastic, but what saves Farley's for me is the large and airy setting with picture windows overlooking the street, a decent amount of spaces to sit, and a surprisingly good magazine selection. A quality neighborhood hangout in every way.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Hot chocolate that doesn't make your head spin from too much sugar is hard to come by in this world. If I wanted a mocha or espresso high, I'd order one :) 

Thank you, Farley's for a foamy, honest-to-goodness hot chocolate. For less than $5. I drank it fast and didn't have any regrets before a gut-busting brunch at Plow down the street.
author: Abby S.

description:
Farley's is my favorite place to hang out during weekends for either doing some reading or work. They have good coffee and a selection of snacks, as well. Really love the mushroom empanadas and different cakes they have. I especially like their collection of magazines and can easily spend a couple of hours here going through different magazines. 

It is also a good place for working with a decent speed internet. The power outlets are only on the left side and they are a little limited.
author: Cem A.

description:
Just moved to Pot Hill and this is one of the places people had been recommending. So it's the first place I checked out for coffee since my coffee maker isn't out of the moving boxes yet. A quick visit to Farley's made me promptly unpack and plug in my coffee maker, so I don't have to go here again. Now I'm all for cafes with local flair and a bit of grunge - used to love Bean There when I lived in the Lower Haight so I'm not exactly what you'd call a Starbucks bigot - but this place is filthy and fly-infested.

The pastry and cookie selection is pitiful. The coffee was actually decent once I overrode my natural disinclination to touch my lips against anything I had picked up from Farley's, including the to-go cup lid. But who the hell told the staff that a smile or a little friendliness makes you a sell-out? It seemed like the 3 things most feared in this world by those "baristas" (a term I'm sure they despise so I'm gonna call them that) are yuppies, razors and polite conversation.

Whatever, this place clearly caters to the pretentious anti-pretentious segment (you know who I mean) and I just don't have the energy for that kinda attitude before the caffeine has reached the far corners of my circulatory system. Fail.
author: Aaron D.

description: Love the outdoor seating here and chill neighborhood vibe. Very good coffee and pastries also. I'm looking forward to spending many weekend mornings here!
author: Nora C. E.

description:
Great coffee! 

On a day where you have staffs that play relaxing classical, jazzy or slow music, it's nice to work at the cafe.

On a day that staffs decides to play EDM, house or progressive music, and blast it up because they are happy it's Friday, it becomes hard to work here.

Essentially this cafes music is dedicated by the staffs interest instead of catering to the crowd that comes here. 

Good or bad? You decide..
author: Henry W.

description:
Best study / remote work spot in the city! Shhh don't tell anyone though. 

The only plugs in the place are on the left hand side.  Bring a long cord and be nice to the people using the plugs and they'll probably let you switch in for a bit.
author: Justin S.

description: Perfect spot to take a little coffee break during the Pokemon Go crawl or whatever it is we're supposed to be playing these days. The barista seems a bit aloof to me when I was there but the space is very cozy.
author: Yad L.

description:
I really didn't think much of this place, but waiting for a Plow seating can drive a caffeine-less girl nuts!

This place makes out pretty well since most people who are waiting in the cold in the morning for Plow will eventually end up here, right down the street. They even do really adorable coffee designs on your lattes!

They don't do soy, so they had almond. Surprisingly their almond was very, very good. It definitely was a flavored, sweetened almond milk, but still much more tasty than most of the almond lattes I've had.

The smiley face helped too, thanks Farley's!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Seriously one of the greatest cappuccinos I've had in awhile! Espresso flavor was robust, and it was at the perfect temperature. Saw a lot of people with cortados (espresso with even less milk than a cappuccino) which I'd like to try next time.

I really like the interior too. Unlike Provender down the street, this place has a nice cozy environment with lots of seating and free wi-fi. Though I was there with my laptop, most people were there in groups of 3-4, nicely dressed, chatting, and (likely) waiting to get into Plow located at the same intersection. I know, because I was doing the same thing, and saw many familiar faces from Farley's when I was at Plow.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description: Their gibraltar (w/almond milk) was quite possibly the BEST caffeinated drink I've ever had. SO happy to have found this coffee shop - came here on a Sunday morning to get work done and was delighted by the spaciousness, friendly service, and relaxed ambiance. AND free wifi. Amazing. It's a popular coffee spot, but not overwhelming. Definitely going to come back here.
author: Karen Z.

description:
I stayed away from Farley's for a long time after moving to Dogpatch six years ago. It could be that the ex-boyfriend of the woman I was dating, who had at one point stalked us, was a regular there. It could be that I remembered being there a long time ago and getting the impression that the coffee wasn't that great and the staff kinda surly.

Times change, and Farley's deserves major props for being an old survivor that has kept some of its best qualities while evolving with them.

The coffee is as good as anything you'd get at Four Barrel (where they source their beans). The staff is great. I like these people. I love that they have a news stand even though I'm sure it makes them no money. I love that they will completely leave you alone to just park there for a while. The staff-chosen music works for me and is sometimes even really good. I love that I can pop next door to Hazel's & bring back lunch, since most of what they offer is lighter fare.

Bottom line: as a regular I notice how this shop goes out of its way to provide a good, even sometimes generous customer experience, and they're not missing anything that the newer places offer; quite the opposite, in fact.
author: Mark C.

description:
Now I'm Farley sure this place could do better.

Get it, I switched "Farley" with "fairly?"

My sad attempt at humor.

Just like this place's sad attempt at coffee and customer service.

First off, you guys really need to clean up your pastry display. All those gnats flying around inside the case, landing on the croissant and cookies made me want to barf. 

Secondly, instead of talking amongst each other, it would be nice on a busy Saturday to be actually trying to ring up the customers who are waiting for a drink.

There were 2 people ahead of us, then my buddy and I, yet it took longer for me in this line than it would be during morning rush hour at Starbucks.

Thirdly, the coffee was extremely bitter, and at $4 a cup, it was overpriced.

I want to support independent coffee shops, but they need to work on smiling or at least being a little friendlier and faster, and work on not holding that espresso shot too long before adding the milk. Hence, the bitterness.
author: Jack R.

description:
So I've become a bit spoiled on the coffee front, what with Phil's, Blue Bottle, Sightglass, Ritual Coffee, and so many other stellar coffee spots within a few blocks of my place.  It's hard to be unbiased when I've become so accustomed to the high-quality coffee those places have to offer. 

With that being said, the coffee I received at Farley's was pretty good.  It is definitely above quality (i.e., you won't find Starbucks or Peet's level of coffee here!).  The reason for the 3 rating is because I wasn't "wow-ed" as I am with the other aforementioned places.  I won't be making a concerted effort to make my way back here for coffee; but if I'm in the neighborhood, I would most definitely consider popping back in for a cup of joe.
author: Rachael S.

description: A very nice atmosphere and they also sell many different magazines! I ordered the cafe latte and it was really good.
author: Chloe S.

description: I love it here! Everything is so welcoming. It's a calm place to get work down and relax from a long day. I can honestly fall asleep here. They switch up the music every now and then but it's all music I enjoy. The hot chocolate was really good and they have really good customer service. I love the way the shop is set up itself. There's bleachers and pillows for you to dine in and relax. There's also a journal shelf where they provided books and also games for the kids to play with. nice paintings and everything looks so vintage which is what really attaches me to this place! Definitely recommend this for everyone!!
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I really want to like this place. The outside patio is nice to sit at, the wifi works, and the area is easy to park in.

Unfortunately, the service leaves something to be desired.  It just doesn't seem like the folks behind the register care about making the paying customer happy.
author: Janet Z.

description:
Just havin' one of those days like Monica sings....that a girl goes through :)

...and I happened to stop by this cafe and ordered an ice tea and coffee (was craving both...cravings)

Cool cafe! They have magazines to browse/buy, lots of seating, and just a unique setup. I'd recommend checking this space out!

The coffee & tea were good - nothing mind blowing but solid coffee and iced tea.
author: Carina M.

description: I've been to this coffee shop several times to work, draw, and meet friends. It's got a great local neighborhood vibe. Many times you have to wait awhile for seat to open up, but I guess that speaks to its popularity among locals.
author: Neha G.

description:
I would probably have to vote Farley's as one of the most relaxed coffee shops that I've been to here in San Francisco. Nestled in a quiet neighborhood in Potrero Hill, you are instinctively drawn in by the chatter and the house full of patrons eagerly waiting for their caffeine fix and clicking away on their laptops as they sip on house brewed coffee and tea. 

The organic chai tea latte was creamy, piping hot, and perfectly spiced, all in a unique Farley's black and white mug. Now, the gibraltar, that monster is no joke. Perfect for those who need an extra pep in their step, nice and strong, served in a shot glass!

So what made this coffee shop so enjoyable was the fact that there were so many different things available to occupy your time. They had different board games, quirky books, current magazines, and good ol' WiFi. The atmosphere is wonderfully casual, yet hipsterish at the same time. 

The baristas were friendly and prompt. I would definitely recommend Farley's as a fun, cool, coffee shop to visit on a lazy day! What a hidden gem!
author: Ann S.

description:
A name like Farley's conjures up images of an Irish pub, but it turns out it's one of the better coffee shops in the uber fun neighborhood of Portrero Hill. The parallel parking on the steeper parts of 18th street on the other hand, not so fun.

It has all the makings of a fabulous coffee spot. The incredible odor from the brews,  grinding of the beans, the frothy steam of the milk (along with the cool pour art), is all put perfectly put together in a cup. As the cruelty of life has kept me from enjoying coffee the way other aficionados have, I still score a wonderful chai latte here from time to time.

Save for the wifi and the magazine stand (wow!), this beats newspapers any day. One can browse without having to purchase and the food they serve here is surprisingly decent (shoot for oatmeal squares). Interesting soundtracks flood the audio ambiance, everything from progressive metal to classic 90s alternative.

Finally, that view of the city from atop the hill, makes San Francisco very easy on the eyes. Take a sip and take a gander; soak it all in.
author: Jando S.

description: Wifi, check. Conducive work environment, check. The coffee is not bad. The age of the place is definitely visible - if you're looking for sleek, this is not your place, but for a chat or to wait on Plow, it's alright. 9pm closing is also one of the latest open coffee places this side of the Mission but it makes you wish they keep the light on until 11.
author: Joy Y.

description:
The welcoming baristas here are always up for asking how your day is going and I make it a point to visit here whenever I'm in the city even though it may be somewhat out of the way.  The weathered hardwood floors, high ceiling, communal table and magazine rack stocked with various periodicals help create an airy and pleasant environment.  I especially appreciate the fact that they have magazines related to architecture such as Abitare, Dwell and Mark.

I am not a coffee person so I can't really comment on the quality of the coffee, but it's good enough for me.  I always have a brownie or a pound cake with my coffee.

Tip: Ask for the vanilla bean ice cream with espresso on the side.  They'll put the ice cream in a cup so you can create an affogato.
author: Yoshi O.

description: Nice out door patio, their bath room leads to the back rooms. Cappuccino was milky but made with burnt beans. I went here on a Sunday so they could've been restocking their supply.
author: Miguel E.

description:
I just love coming to this little street in this side of town it's like a little breath of fresh air in the city.  The shops are all so quaint and cute and this coffee shop is no exception. There's a nice feel to this place where I wouldn't mind coming and studying or getting work done. They have board games and a section with magazines to read. My latte was really goood I enjoyed it greatly. 
And I love the tree of thankfulness right outside the door. On a warm day there is nice outdoor seating as well.
author: Kathlena H.

description:
Welcoming neighborhood coffee shop packed with character.  Friendly staff, great music, comfortable benches, crispy empanadas, abundant caffeine and free wifi - what more can one ask for?!  And, I just heard the barista ask a customer if they wanted their latte with extra love ;-).

Great place to work or socialize.  Inside, you'll regularly see people huddled over laptops in deep concentration.  Outside, patrons are engaged in conversation, reading books, or enjoying the sun with their dogs.  

Farley's also has an eclectic selection of magazines from around the world, music playlists curated by the staff, and some creative t-shirts on the wall.  Unique mix of retro, hipster, techie, and artsy in character.
author: Heather W.

description:
Seriously unpleasant customer service. 

The barista tossed the change from the purchase into the tip jar. Then took it out and sarcastically said " Sorry, that was incredibly presumptius of me."


Ok, I'd give a higher rating if the coffee was good. Yet, my latte was lukewarm and the cups were teeny tiny. 

Not surprisingly, I don't think I'll come back.
author: Nina M.

description:
I'm not a coffee person so a little disclaimer that this review is only for the ambiance not the taste of the coffee. I happened to stroll in here with a friend while waiting for brunch lines to die down. The second I walked in I immediately was brought back to New York-style cafes with its modern look and feel. It's a very open cafe with tons of seating and airy feel. What I loved most was the little news stand in the corner -- with every magazine you could think of (minus trashy tabloids). People were sitting around reading their magazines while sipping coffee. I loved it! Such a different vibe that what I'm used to. I would definitely sit and study/ read here on a weekend. 

Best of all they had banana bread samples on the counter which was SUPER fresh and scrumptious.
author: Naseem K.

description:
Just started a new internship in the neighborhood. Had no idea it had all these hidden gems!!
I was attracted by the elevated patio seating outside with faux grass, it was really cute. It's your typical neighborhood cafe that is well maintained and friendly service. They have a corner with magazines (for sale?), and a high top table for reading. The two tables with welcoming pillows next to the bay windows seem to be the best seats.
The latte was perfect, not too acidic, not too milky. Will come back after I've made my rounds with exploring new cafés!
author: Jess L.

description:
Today was probably the last time I'll go to Farley's. At $3.25 for an Americano (that's espresso and water, folks!), they've gone completely round the bend -- that's close to what a cappuccino costs at a Blue Bottle, and indisputably, ridiculously expensive, even by San Francisco's insane standards. The coffee isn't even that good!

Worse, the new owners have basically sterilized the culture: today I walked in the shop to find that every. single. table. was occupied by someone with their face buried in a laptop. Almost nobody had food or drinks. A cafe that used to have conversation and readers and singers and poets now has...tech dorks. Like every other San Francisco public space. It's just sad.

Farley's owners: eliminate/regulate the wi-fi, cover the outlets, and otherwise discourage Laptop People from setting up camp. Do that, and you'll probably find you don't have to charge outrageous prices to make ends meet.
author: Tim R.

description:
Um, ok.  I've been in here at least five mornings and got GREAT coffee in the past month.  Every time, I've asked (usually a nice woman) to make me a double espresso with a teeny bit of water, and a teeny bit of warm milk.  I'll say, "Essentially, an Italiano as I've heard it called, with a little milk."  Every time, she (then a nice dark haired guy yesterday) made it with no question, other than "water up to here?" They both charged me for what they call a Macchiato, $3.00.  

TODAY, some blonde dude with a British accent took my order, and charged me $3.25, which just made me curious so I explained, that whatever they were making me (which was PERFECT) had been called a Macchiato for $3 - I didn't want to end up with a different drink.  He started raking me over the coals, explaining to me that what I wanted was actually a "GIBRALTAR" and that I was actually "getting a DEAL" on it.  (Like I was trying to steal from them?!)

I don't mind paying $3.25 for a drink, but I don't like being schooled, (to the point of embarrassment) in my coffee by a barista who was probably still drinking mother's milk when I was sipping cappuccinos in NYC 20 years ago.  .... 
Gibraltar.  Pfft!
author: m h.

description: Waited for plow here and the barista and cashier were pleasant, and the coffee amazing!
author: Baye N.

description:
This place is nice and trendy and the coffee is good to boot!  Portrero Hill is slowly becoming the place to be in San Francisco.  It's on the top of the hill with gorgeous views of downtown San Francisco and the bay. So whether you want to grab your coffee, relax inside with one of their wide variety of magazines or grab your drink to go and walk around in the warm weather that's up to you, but the coffee is gooooooooooood here.  

Try an iced latte.  It packs a punch.
author: Kevin J.

description: A nice little coffee shop in a quite area in the city. I tried the almond croissant which was moist and not too sweet, perfect. I can't say anything about their coffee since I haven't ordered one but it is the perfect spot to have a hot drink together with a girlfriend to talk about life. They have outdoor seating which is nice.
author: Michèle S.

description: Great neighborhood spot for coffee.  Mochas are delicious and if you sit outside on the sidewalk deck, there's a view of the Bay from this Portrero gem.  This is one reason SF real estate is so expensive...great neighborhood amenities you can walk to like this!
author: Gregory J.

description: Nice if pretentious ambiance, staff was pretty inhospitable and there were bugs in the pastry case.
author: E G.

description: This is a cozy little neighborhood cafe, but if you're here for the food consider going elsewhere (or at least grab something from Hazel's Kitchen next door) Baked goods are stale and I've seen bugs in the display case on numerous occasions.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Awesome awesome awesome. Such a cool vibe, friendly baristas, and the coffee is great. They don't mind people camping out with laptops or school books for a few hours, which is so refreshing when many SF coffee shops frown upon it. The music is eclectic and always changing. They have a huge magazine rack where you can buy the magazines or simply read them. Great selection of pastries that always varies.

Note! They only take credit cards if your purchase is over $5.
author: Laura S.

description:
I had an almond latte here (they don't have soy milk). Cost about $4 which is standard I think. The latte was velvety and smooth. The line went really quick and I was able to get my drink pretty quickly.

Ambiance is nice, there are plenty of tables to sit at and magazines to read.
author: Mel C.

description: Nice ambience with lots of college students.
author: Neha G.

description: Love this place. Probably one of the friendliest atmospheres and coffee shops I've been to.
author: Mohamed M.

description: Lovely, robust flavors makes Farley's delicious!
author: Shereen A.

description: Great outdoor seating area and drip coffee was . However, lots of little gnats flying around in their pastry case. Only opted for coffee here.
author: Jacklyn L.

description:
I've patronized Farley's regularly for the past year - by regularly I am referring to a visit or two ever 2-3 weeks.   Here's the lowdown:

+

Good quality coffee - particularly if you like full bodied, darker roasts.   If you are more inclined to the mass produced, innocuous lighter roasts of S-bucks, you won't like Farley's.

They have almond and soy milk to mix in with your coffees, which is rare and most welcomed.

-

To go cups - 1 size and it's miniscule.   Need to offer to go cups in various sizes.

Hygiene of staff leaves something to be desired.   When preparing food, their long, scraggly, unkempt and visibly dirty hair projects over the preparation space....Resulting in the likelier probability of unwelcome ingredients as you bite into your morning bagel with cream cheese.

Staff also prepares food with bare hands....God knows what they've touched in the last hour!

Attitude - I concur with most other reviewers.  The hipster/angsty quotient within staff is overpowering.   Customer service with a smile you will not receive.
author: Todd K.

description: My favorite coffee place in Potrero Hill. Love being able to sit outside and enjoy my coffee. Plus, they won my heart when I got a little piggie in my cappuccino. How did they know?!?!
author: Kristen M.

description:
Best coffee cake here.Great coffee.This place is spacious.Has a good magazine collection and a unique music taste.

Tip: use paypal coupon.
author: Priyanka L.

description: Update:  Coffee MUCH improved.  Now this place has the best vibe AND some of the best coffee in town.  Peter is a great presence there.  It's a pity they don't have more proper nourishing food - their panini sandwiches were amazing, but still this is a really great place.
author: dean b.

description: Every time I visit the city...I stop here for a weekend coffee. The atmosphere is great, the view on a nice day is lovely and the coffee delicious!
author: Tina B.

description:
At first glance, Farley's is a cozy, indie coffee shop with unique lifestyle & fashion mags & lattes with pretty designs. You're thinking, "I could kick it here for a minute..."

But spend more that two minutes here & you'll soon realize this joint is not conducive to long amounts of chillin', as I tend to like to do. Seats, which are easy to come by, aren't very comfortable...uneven tables, unstable wooden chairs. Their regular drip coffee is too dark & their espresso drinks, like the last cappuccino I had here, have overwhelming amounts of foam. 

Service is always a little cold, a little annoyed. I feel completely, absolutely 'meh' about this p.hill shop.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I was in SF this last weekend and I was able to go to Farleys for coffee 2 days in a row.
It was wonderful...  I wish I could make coffee like that...

1 of the best cups of coffee ever to exsist.   I know my coffee, and this place does also.
author: Captain C.

description:
I really like this place! I got the tea and I didn't get a chance to try the coffee...so I can't speak to the other reviews that aren't a fan of the coffee.  This review is mainly on the atmosphere of the cafe. 

It's so cozy inside and there is so much natural lighting - which I love!
I came here with a bunch of friends to do a project and there are big tables in the front where you can spread out and talk. 
There is a magazine stand in the back and there is something that is so beauitfully quaint and old school about this place.  It's great for coming on a sunday morning, reading the newspaper, and enjoying the sun.   There is outdoor seating on some fake grass that's pretty cute.
author: Kristin C.

description:
Despite the prior reviews, I have experienced nothing but kindness from the staff consistently, but there might be a reason why they are giving you the stink eye.   They are always nice to my dog when I studied with her outside.

I no longer live in SF but make people take me here when I'm back. The foam is just perfect, it looks like a piece of art,  the expresso is just strong caffienated goodness. It tastes so sweet when it touches your lips.

I seriously miss this place.
author: Sahar R.

description:
Farley's is a really lovely neighborhood establishment. It seems that past reviewers have noted issues with rude staff (wait... am I still in New York??) as well as increasing prices and less comfortable chairs, but - oddly enough - these Yelpers never reviewed Farley's when they liked it, and only reviewed the place once it "went south."

I'm here to report that Farley's has again soared... north. The coffee is delicious, the ambiance is cozy, and the woman behind the counter was so generous that I tipped her extra. It's a cafe, so no, they don't have a huge menu. Want lunch? Go around the corner to Papito for a burrito, and come back when you want a cuppa java. Sheesh. 

There's seating indoors as well as a faux-grass park with benches and tables outside, which is downright endearing. I love the Border's-like array of magazines for purchase, just in case you came to work but would prefer to procrastinate. There's free wi-fi, but herein lies my only complaint (god forbid I shouldn't have one): it runs out after 2 hours. My friend insisted that if I "kept logging on" I could beat the system, but no such luck. Oh well, I suppose they have to make money somehow. After 2 hours my drink was cold, my scone was gone, and there were 3 people eager to fill the window seat. 

Oh! And there are free refills! Score!
author: Ray J.

description: Delicious coffee and delicious snacks. Great magazines too. I loved the atmosphere, the music and the employees were very nice. I will be back next time I'm in SF.
author: Ryan E.

description: Potrero Hill's original hang out cafe up on the hill. They have a great selection of teas, milks, soy, almond, skim, cream, etc. The cappuccinos are always perfect taste and temperature. If you want a good local spot to meet someone then come here. Parking is also quite easy too. There is a great bookstore, wine shop, and good restaurants nearby.
author: Greg O.

description: Farley's is such a quaint little coffee shop in Portrero Hill.  The almond latte was okay, but the reason to come here is the ambiance.  They have a number of board games that are pretty dated (Trivial Pursuit - Genus Edition, Pictionary - The Simpsons Edition, Monopoly) yet a ton of fun.  There's two window seats, a handful of tables, one large table in the middle, a magazine section in the back, and a bathroom in the upstairs janitor's closet.  Perfect place for a rainy day.
author: Kristen H.

description:
Farley's is a pretty cozy, compact place to hang out. there are couple racks of mags for patrons to browse gratis. the tables and chairs are too close for my comfort. i am really fortunate not to havespin hot  coffee on anyone as i exited. it's that cramped here.

drink:
-coffee(2) black as usual
de la paz coffee is featured now. pretty smooth brew,
bold taste, little acidity, no harshness.
not a robust flavor but silky smooth in texture.

coffee drips:
-benches and chairs outside shop as well
-de la paz coffee easily drinkable, could be a rotating fav.
-shop nice but too cramped for me....
author: Victor G.

description:
Coffee was fine but I didn't like the fact that when I asked for a drip it wasn't made to order. They dispensed it from a container which made me wonder how long was it in there. 

With so many competitors out there who make coffee fresh to order, it makes me wonder what does Farley's do to separate themselves from all the others?

Maybe I am missing something?

Overall Thoughts

I think I am spoiled by other micro coffee brewery establishments
author: Eddie W.

description: Excellent cappuccino
author: Amy O.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and have been coming here for decades (really). I love this place. The people who work here are nice, very nice. So are the customers.  I have had great conversations with my neighbors and total strangers. They have the best selection of magazines, some games and journals.

There is every kind of table style - take your pick, a high bar, booths, community table what ever you like including a parklet. The tea selection is very nice and a pot is a bargain. I like the coffee and the pastries are really good. They have fresh beignets (early), ham and cheese croissants, muffins and more, all really fresh.

I have even shown my collection in the window (years ago). It is a fun. community minded local gem.
author: Kristian M.

description: Since it's near my place, I come here quite a bit especially when I need a break from sitting in front of my computer.  Farley has a lay-back atmosphere that fits the PH neighborhood quite well.  The coffee is good too.  I don't buy or read magazines, but I do like finding a magazine stand at a coffee shop.  I also love the sidewalk seating too.  Very often just a great place to chill for half hour before going back to the grind.
author: Jj S.

description: It was my favorite coffee place coming almost every day with our new baby until the manager decided to tell me using my first name got from my credit card that they have a bussing policy. Apparently we missed one night to return our plates. She didn't notice or thank us when we cleaned the tables after others previously. A key way to kill customer empathy, and tips
author: Ivan K.

description:
They have the worst seating in San Francisco.. don't sit more the 30 minutes.. The chairs are cheap and nasty they will hurt  your back. Their coffee is better then Starbucks for sure and totally deserve 3 stars..
All together the barista gets 2 stars, their poor attitude toward the customer is so Unethical... Why do they bite the hand that feed them?
Job is a job.. Just love what you can do for now. Stop hating on your customers who help you to have a job..
author: Pedro D.

description: Pretty good coffee shop.   Friendly staff, food was decent.  The outdoor seating is nice.
author: Michael E.

description:
I'm a big Farley's fan. It's conveniently located right across from my dry cleaner's, so on a Saturday I'll often roll over with my dry cleaning, drop it off, and then spend a wonderful few hours reading a book or two. They have a wonderful selection of magazines and papers. 

The coffee is good and strong, just how I like it. But the unsung hero is the house made limeade. Be sure and have a brownie while you're there as well.
author: Nellie S.

description: Nice local spot to meet people. Everyone is casual and friendly. Known for great sandwiches, I stop by for the Ginger Ale. A bookshelf has notebooks that customers fill with artwork, poems, random thoughts ~ and then return to the shelf. Every once in awhile, the place hosts lectures and celebrations for non-profits and the public is welcome. (This is how I discovered the place.) The magazine rack in the corner is like something from a NYC corner back in the day. Friendly staff. Amazing live music once in awhile ... Free parking, which is just about a miracle in SF.
author: Phoebe W.

description:
We came in on a Friday afternoon to get some coffee and a light lunch.
Here's the list of what they ran out:
- Milk
- Salad
- Pastries

I'm surprised they didn't run out of coffee. Even though they told us they ran out of milk (I guess they rant out of whole milk, but not fat free), we still got our coffee, which was pretty bitter, i.e. worse than Starbucks and much worse than The Coffee Bean and the Tea Leaf.

The store itself is very poorly up kept (on purpose), because I guess it's supposed to look hipsterish...

The only reason this place gets the 2nd star is because they didn't mind us coming back with our salads that we got from a place next door (there is no seating in the place next door...)
author: Anna P.

description:
Great place to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon working and drinking a coffee. It has lots of natural light and some outdoor seating if you want to hang and read a book. Doesn't have that many outlets, so you got to approach this place strategically. Left side of the cafe has all the outlets (by the benches). We ended up buying black coffee there and getting sandwiches next door as the kitchen was closed.

I probably wouldn't mind coming back for brunch in the future but it looked like the typical overpriced Potrero faire. Not a bad place to catch up with a friend you don't want to commit to dinner for.
author: Jake B.

description:
Okay the coffee is good and that's about it.

Don't eat here, by any means. It was seriously the worst food I have had in San Francisco. McDonald's egg sandwiches (which are disgusting) are considerably better.
author: Bret G.

description:
This is a really cute neighborhood coffee shop with tables and also a magazine stand in the back (they have a lot of harder to find selections like French Vanity Fair). It's nice to be able to peruse magazines while you wait and sip your coffee.

I went with a cafe au lait, and I was surprised they had only almond milk and no soy milk. Nonetheless, the drink tasted pretty creamy (I've actually never had almond milk before..).  I also tried the cappuccino and gibraltar, both of which were pretty good.

We also tried a chocolate croissant, which was ok.

I do really like the neighborhood coffee shop feel and set up.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
Solid place with good coffee and other drinks. ALSO ICE CREAM and very good food. 
It gets very busy on weekends ... mostly due to the overflow of people waiting to eat 17$ eggs at that fancy restaurant down the block.
author: Keenan M.

description:
I ordered a bacon quiche to go. The guy took my money and put the change in his tip jar without asking. It was only .25 and I would have put it there anyway but thought it very presumptuous.

He brought my quiche and I asked him "are you sure this is bacon because it has lots of veggies on top?" he said "yes it is bacon with vegetables."

Warmed it up at home....no bacon just veggies. Imagine if I was a vegetarian and he had slipped me the bacon quiche?

For 6 dollars just give me the right quiche, how hard is that!?
author: Tia L.

description:
Great local coffee shop with a cool vibe and a big magazine rack for you to grab any mag you want while drinking your coffee/tea. 

If you want a break from the corporate shops like Starbucks and Pete's, then this is the place if you're in the area.
author: Louis C.

description:
Cool coffee shop with good coffee. Grab a seat outside and enjoy the rolling hills and views of SF! Staff were nice; bathroom is old and kinda sketch. Not sure what other yelpers meant by the unfriendliness. I got a smile and conversation as I ordered my drink. People watching is great though on that street. I saw people around me get sandwiches; they looked decent. 

My main gripe is that the only non-dairy option that day was almond milk which I detest (and I can't have dairy.) So, that's the only reason I won't be back for coffee anytime soon.
author: Sneha P.

description:
Farley's is my benchmark on which I measure other coffee houses. And if I look at their recent "franchising" into the East Bay, their java vision has appeared to have traveled well.

Farley's had me years ago starting with the Lincoln Logs, magazines, and a cool "living room" environment. They also do black coffee (and the right nosh to go with it) very well.  

Beyond that, I love the somewhat hard to find Potrero Hill location, the warm  interior and hangout comfort, and the fun and sometimes educational people watching and conversation. Best of all is that with all the shiny new things out there, this Farley's keeps staying who they are. It's a place that I could spend hours (and have).
author: Eric B.

description:
House Coffee: Yum

Location: Could use better parking, but so can the rest of San Francisco. Most of the parking nearby is 2 hours, which isn't too bad if you're looking for a nice spot to relax for a bit. 

Atmosphere: It has a good amount of seating, outlets, and they keep the door open on a nice day, which makes it feel more open and spacious. They have outdoor seating as well. They also have a huge magazine rack and some board games, which is nice when doing actual work gets boring. 

Service: I didn't realize how offensive it would be to ask what the most popular item on the menu  was. Apparently it's more frustrating for the barista to answer than I realized. My bad. 
Thus, I just got the house coffee. How hard is it to say "I like this..", "Most people like that...," "Yelpers recommend the Chai Latte" ? My mistake; I should've checked with the Yelp community first. 

But either way, I got what I wanted: a nice cup of coffee and a seat next to the outlets. I'll probably be back for that Chai Latte though. The feel of the coffee place as a whole seems to be worth it--at least around lunch time. I'm not sure how the morning crowd is, but I imagine that my stupid question is the least of the cashier's worries.
author: Jenn F.

description:
Almond latte! 

Would come back again. 

Good spot before or after plow :)
author: Ari C.

description: Awesome place to work from or hangout with friends... They make great coffee too...
author: Ashok L.

description: Farley's is the ideal neighborhood coffee shop. Good for working. Good for hanging and friendly staff. If you like ginger tea-- they carry an amazing, super spicy ginger tea. Also the empanadas are delish.
author: Urban S.

description: By far the best cafe in the area. Excellent and pretty staff that will cater your drink however you like it. Lots of work space, and you never feel like you out wear your welcome. Lovely humble and homey feeling. I am only in SF for 2 months but this place is such a treat. The coffee is excellent but the vibe really ties it together!
author: Leesa E.

description: I was in town for a two day visit and kept coming back here. These guys take their coffee very seriously. Quantity of espresso, the latte art. And the extras like the triangle shaped granola bar add to the place. Also there's really good atmosphere here. Whether you sit in the long shared table or in the large rounded tables in the corner, you will find very friendly people.
author: Tomer S.

description:
Adoration.

I'm so happy to see this place still here amidst the changing environment for most cafes sprouting up all over the city.  Farley's has held steadfast with the unassuming exterior and extremely warm interior.

On a recent stroll through the neighborhood, there is no such definitive that lies behind temptation with this establishment.  I always find myself drawn in.  The wooden plank floors.  The books that are out in the open requesting the flipping of the cover or pages, as one feels inclined.  The baristas here are warm and conducive to the caffeinated environment and during the summers, the sniffing done by passing dogs is always a warm welcome to my toes in flip flops.  Farley's does a fabulous job of inviting the public, especially the locals, in for their daily ration of black gold. 

My Breve Latte came foaming over the lip in the traditional large porcelain cup.  I took this, cradled between two hands, to one of the many quaint tables and a copy of The Captain's Daughter.  I had recently finished reading a Steig Larsson book (upon the recommendation of a friend who had just finished the Millennium series) and had found the modern fiction somewhat entertaining, if not a hard return to reality, given the subject material in that specific title.  My latte did a fantastic job of erasing such thoughts.  Hot.  Creamy.  Perfect.

I had a supper gathering to attend to later, so after finishing my latte, decided it was high time to walk further down the block to kill time and rev up my metabolism for what I knew was a feast awaiting me.
author: Miika M.

description: Really good coffee and cute area. Has a parklet outside for seating and there's a bunch of magazines inside!
author: Page F.

description: Fav coffee spot in the city. Love the ambience perfect for a first date or study session. Surprized the reviews weren't higher - actually shocked. Nice, cute, staff, great bathroom (I mean lets be real, that is a HUGE indicator of the cleanliness/vibe of the business). If were going off taste or price it wouldn't be number one probably number three. Honestly though - great place and a nice food selection. Fabulous parklet area too. And close to my house. A coffee feinds dream come true!
author: Kati K.

description:
OMG!!! This place is such a scene. This is the biggest hipster cafe 
on the hill. 

I have been here on numerous occasions because I work a block 
down from it. Never again. 

My biggest complaint, if your going to be a coffee shop, you MUST 
have decent coffee. What they have is watered down coffee beans 
This is the WORST COFFEE IN THE CITY! 

The lattes are okay, but when I asked if they had any flavoring syrups
the cashier got confused. 

I ordered the turkey and cheese sandwich one time. It was super greasy, had
waay too much cheese, and didn't come with any salad or anything like that.
Which, for the price, surprised me. 

I seriously don't know why this place is cool. But whatever, good for them.
author: Patricia L.

description:
I want to love this place cause it's in my neighborhood and I've been living here 17 years!! But regretfully, I've refrained from going to Farley's for many years because of the bad service. It shouldn't be too hard to recruit baristas that enjoy interacting with people. I bet that this alone will make the coffee taste better ----- a good chunk of it is in the mind....ok... and taste buds too :)
