On the positive side, now that I overcame my frustration and that there are new owners and a few fresh and friendly faces behind the counter, I am hoping for a better experience.

Farley's upsides include:
-Great magazine selection!
-board games
-lovely new outdoor sitting addition 
-tons of parking
-family friendly environment
-art on the walls

Ahh.... I forgot to mention that the coffee is mediocre.

When the service will be consistently friendly i'll gladly give it 5 stars!
author: icy b.

description:
I just happened to do a Google search on coffee and came across Farley's--reviews on Yelp helped but I usually go on my own personal experiences.

This is definitely a hidden gem! Cute little place, I love the area and the customer service was fantastic!

Being a big time coffee drinker who knows a bit about coffee and coffee roasters, I was excited to learn that their roaster is De La Paz coffee.

The girl at the counter took the time to discuss the 3 regions (Kenya, Guatemala and Ethiopia) that they offered for their pour overs....I just love talking coffee :)

Anyways, I finally decided on the Kenyan pour over which was really good and walked out a happy 1st time customer.

I'm definitely going back and would definitely recommend this place!
author: This Is M E.

description:
They have beef empanadas. 'Nuff said.

The tall server with the mustache could use a shower and a hair comb, though.

Coffee is great. Try the Gibraltar. It is as good as a cortado!
author: Pony R.

description:
Waited for my Plow table here.

Mediocre mocha using beans from De La Paz roasters.  Maybe I'm not a coffee pro yet.  My mocha tasted too milky.  

Almond croissant was good.  

I liked the decor and music.  Loved the barista's attitude!  Fun, friendly guy.
author: Erika C.

description:
I like coffee. I like tea. I like Farley's, and they like me...
...at least I think they do...but they like everybody. I guess I'm not that special. Ah well, regardless, there needs to be more coffeehouses like Farley's in this cold, cold city.

Cozy... zen-like in its quietude.... tables and chairs set up for actual conversation... magazines for days... and a good cup of joe served up by people with good manners. You can nurse a cup for hours...and hours, which some people do...much to the chagrin of the rest of us who wish they would just give up their seats.

But I need to relax. Stop and smell the roses. Learn to respect the needs of others. Try to..."WHAT THE...DID YOU RENT THAT TABLE?? GET A LIFE!! GO HOME!!"...There, I feel much more zen-like now. They also have tables outside for caffeine addicts who like to stare in an unsettling manner at passing pedestrians. Not that I've ever done that. Really.

COFFEE - 4 stars...not quite up to Philz or Blue Bottle but still a solid caffeine fix
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...homey coffeehouse...grab a table the minute somebody gets up...all's fair, y'know
SERVICE - 5 stars...really friendly without being unctuous
TOTAL - 4 stars...the epitome of a neighborhood coffee place
author: Ed U.

description: I am in love with Farley's. I love great local coffee shops in cute adorable neighborhoods. It was pretty cold the Saturday afternoon I went, so everyone was inside. I love how there is a variety of people what come to Farley's. You have young folks, older adults, a few teens, and young families with children. Really cozy, cute, adorable, and will definitely come back!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Yum...........

Delicious iced latte. One of the best I've had. I've had many great HOT lattes, but not very many cold. They always tend to be super bitter or super bland. This one was just the right amount of milkiness and tasted divine. The crowd is mixed, but definitely very San Francisco. I think I can grow to love this spot.

Credit card minimum $5

Parking is good, so I will definitely be back!
author: Elaine H.

description:
Nice coffee spot in Potrero Hill. Friendly and knowledgeable staff. Excellent gibralter and a very good ginger scone.  
The wait wasn't long though they were busy on a Saturday morning. The interesting magazine collection made the wait seem even quicker. 
The pocket park right outside the door made for good people watching.
author: Karen S.

description:
I have been going to Farley's for almost 20 years - and I literally have bought thousands of cups of coffee there - I only drink just house coffee - no lattes, caps, etc.

I moved out of the neighborhood two years ago - and sometime recently, they switched coffee.   I am sorry, but it is the worst, most bitter coffee I have ever had.  Worse than gas station coffee in the middle of rural Florida.  I've tried it three times now - it is incredibly bad.

Please please bring back Jack's Roast.  The new stuff is awful.  

Besides the putrid coffee, I love the place.  Great magazines, relaxing atmosphere and general warmth make this place a gem - but I think I'll bring my own coffee from now on.
author: Brian S.

description:
I would give this place 5 stars for atmosphere alone- minimalistic, airy, open space with ample seating and outdoor patio- but I had to take off one star for unfriendly staff and another star for a chin hair (hopefully) found in my $6 fruit and granola yogurt. 

Even with that, I'll probably be back.  Good place to get some work done-even on a Sunday.
author: Marianna D.

description: Best neighborhood coffee shop EVER! Awesome lattes. Cool old rickety furniture. Great vibe. Nice outdoor seating area. Next to the best sandwich shop EVER (Hazel's kitchen)!
author: Mark H.

description: So glad they're open late.  It's excellent to have a Farley's down the street, and the location is expansive with a lovely patio as well. Tons of magazines, local artists' work exhibited, good coffee... a solid spot.
author: Chloe B.

description: The location is cute wrapped up around other little shops and cafes in the pleasant Potrero Hill SF's sunniest up and rising location. The Grilked chicken melt is excellent on the seeded roll...Bueno! Also the Roast beef and cheddar is also solid and on point. 6+ stars if I could. On fleek.
author: Matthew F.

description:
I haven't had a worse cup of coffee anywhere.

Farley's calls themselves a coffee place.  Yes they have a place.  No they don't have coffee, at least not the house "i'd like a cup of coffee please" coffee.  I'm trying hard to come up with a name for it.  Let's have a contest... uh, no... why waste more time.  My time investment will be spent warning you to steer clear until further notice.

I met friends here yesterday, my suggestion.  I can't remember ever having to apologize to someone for the coffee before.  Plenty of meh out there, but nothing sinking to this level.

How to describe it?  You may know and recognize the intrinsically lousy flavor of Farmers Brothers Coffee.  You know, favorite of greasy spoons and institutional kitchens, not because it's good.  Add a strong insult of burning and you have a reasonable approximation.  I had mine black (VERY BAD IDEA) but I doubt any amount of adulterant could hide this awfulness.  If the idea is to teach me not to be a cheapskate and steer me to fancier made-to-order barista drinks, forget it, FAIL.  A coffee place that has no pride in its house coffee is no coffee place of mine.

As a local Potreran, this is an embarrassment.  I haven't been to Farleys since the ownership change.  Doubt I'll go back unless I hear about a reborn interest in quality.
  
The one star is because the liquid was hot and it was nice to meet out of the rain.  I mostly Yelp 4 and 5.  I hate to give 1s; this 1 is unfortunately well deserved. Shame on you F-is-for-Farleys.
author: Bob K.

description: This is one of the best places for coffee in SF! The coffee is delicious and the atmosphere is chill.  The ambiance is cute, inviting and cozy.
author: Victoria L.

description: After enjoying breakfast at Plow and hiking our way around the neighborhood to McKinley Square and back we needed a rest!  So we stopped in at Farley's and enjoyed a quick coffee on their patio area.  The weather was beautiful and although seating was limited we found a couple seats and caught our breath before moving on.  I wish we had tried some of their pastries but coffee was ok and it served it's purpose.
author: Bianca A.

description:
My favorite hangout place on 18th street! The coffee, tea, and scones are always superb, but what keeps me coming back is the outdoor patio and friendly, communal vibe. 

On the astroturf seating area outside, you can watch the MUNI and local dogs pass by, read the paperback you just bought at Christopher's down the street, or bump into friends. The window display shows off thoughtful quotes from visionaries like Maya Angelou or charity projects in progress. The magazine rack inside has an amazing selection. The gratitude tree makes you reflect sincerely on your blessings.  I've spent many happy, sunny afternoons working or reading at Farley's!

The baked goods are always tasty and vary often, but if the selection doesn't float your boat, you can always grab a sandwich from Hazel's Kitchen next door. Those sandwiches are amazing, but that's for another review.
author: M L.

description: Great soy latte. Well lit space to get work done. Not the warmest atmosphere. It's cute.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Farley's was a pleasant surprise when it came to a very good Americano!  I came in here with my girlfriend and friends before dinner looking to wake up, but what I didn't expect to find was a very good cup of coffee.  It was also nice to see a section with magazines that reminded me of the good old days when there was an abundance of Barnes and Nobles where you could drink coffee and find good reading material.
author: Euge R.

description: Great neighborhood spot, delicious baked goods and great java. Try the bacon scone, you won't regret it.
author: Jenni M.

description: Best granola fruit and yogurt I've ever had in my life.
author: Laura P.

description:
Okay, this is kind of embarrassing, but here goes: I've only recently, in the last year or so, started drinking coffee.  I know, it's a ridiculous thing to hear from a man in his 40s, but what can I tell you?  It wasn't in the house when I grew up, I tried it when I went off to college and didn't like the taste, and over the years since, every time I've tried it it always seemed unnecessarily bitter tasting.  I mean, let's face, ANYTHING is going to taste good buried under cream and sugar, but I wanted to like the coffee itself, you know?

My gateway drug came in the form of "New Orleans style Iced Coffee" from Blue Bottle.  They soften the bitter edge with Chicory.  And of course, the amazing, meth-like rush wasn't anything to sneeze at either.  Slowly, I began to acquire a taste for the bean juice.  And now, like the rest of the world, I am finally hooked.  HAPPY?  Another junkie joins your ranks.

Anyway, all of this rather lengthy introduction is to say that I come to this whole coffee thing with a "beginner's mind."  I have no pre-conceptions of how it should taste, I wasn't raised on Chock full o' Nuts, so I bring very little bias to the table. 

Having said that, out of all the "TOP TIER" coffee joints in SF, I can tell you that, IMHO, Farley's is the best.  I've tried Blue Bottle, I've tried Four Barrel, Philz, Peet's, Faye's.  But, to me, Farley's tastes the best, hands down.  (Not to say that the others are bad, I can enjoy a cup from all of those places, but there can be only one Top Dog, and that is Farley's.)

I have not had any problems with any of the staff being rude.  Maybe the manager saw all your negative posts and changed things up there, I don't know, it's not like I've been going for years and years.  But as far as I can tell the folks behind the counter are nice and friendly.  We usually have a brief chat if it's not too busy, so nothing bad to report on the customer relations front.

In short: yea Farley's!!  And they're not nearly as expensive as Four Barrel.  

Now, can someone explain to me how Starbucks became so damn popular?  I tried their coffee and it taste like garbage.  I thought they somehow elevated American's taste for coffee, but that stuff is the worst.  What gives?
author: FoodDudeS F.

description:
Free wifi, a ton of magazines, delicious beverages, and always changing local art.

If this were my personal toilet, I'd have died on the shitter long ago.  

But alas, I have to stick with my windowless crap factory with the fan that, because of it's weak sucking, actually blows.  Hehe, get it?

Usually after any one of my trips, I'll spend a few days working from home to decompress and Farley's is like a second home office for me.  

I love the simplicity of the place and the menu.  

Take Philz for example.  Love the coffee, but seriously man, how many choices must I make just to buy a friggin cup?

And no, just because someone in Sumatra puts mint in their coffee, don't try to lace my beverage with anything green (well, almost anything).

Farley's is like the In-n-out of the coffee world.  

Plus the parklet out front is a fantastic people watching/work spot.  

Grind.
author: Archie R.

description:
I like this place.  It's my go to spot in my work neighborhood.  It's cozy, the drinks are of sufficient quality, and the people are friendly.

Plus, they have an awesome rack full of magazines that are fun to check out.  Overall a good place to go to work or just for coffee.
author: Jesse M.

description: Coffee is OK, but definitely not one of the best in the neighborhood. They have nice seating area outside, which is absolutely great!
author: Rafael O.

description:
The $2.17 Americano was strong and good, but the cafe's large open doorway cooled it quickly, so consider that if you consider lingering here. Many people really came in to just chat and catch up before heading to elsewhere; probably all the quaint eateries nearby. 

More like 3 stars. It was time for a revisit since it's near the Mariposa St. exit off of 280. Like other yelpeeps reviewed, this is really a neighborhood/non-chain-style cafe, but I didn't receive any too-cool vibe or surly attitude.

Oh, the restroom is upstairs to the right.
author: Peter L.

description:
I'm so glad I walked in here! 

DELICIOUS lattes, yummy and perfectly spiced carrot ginger soup. 

6 stars.
author: Toby B.

description: Charming! Teeny lil park out front, good coffee, friendly barista and crowd. Nice place to hang.
author: Loren C.

description:
Good coffee, great espresso drinks. Outdoor seating is awesome on a sunny potrero day.

I come here every time I am in potrero and am never disappointed!
author: Nilu r.

description: Nice little place in PH... service is mediocre (hey staff: it's okay to crack a smile), Americano was solid, and the outdoor seating is pretty awesome. If you're in the area already, go for it, but I wouldn't make a trip out here from other parts of SF.
author: Tik P.

description: Cute spot, love the marble... but super quiet and no jams...
author: Denise M.

description:
Communist.

No Red Scare here. Just genuine enthusiasm for their lowfat Russian yogurt and homemade granola combo. Nutty. Filling. Delicious.

Diestel turkey on wheat was simple and straightforward and satisfied the late lunch hunger pains. Would have liked a side for the $9 cost.

Like more granola.
author: Jason B.

description: I love Farley ' s and have been coming here for the last four years. It's a weekend go-to when you want to force yourself to drink coffee, read magazines (they have all the classics and a bunch from over seas that you've never heard of) and actually relax like people used to do.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Yelpers who recommended the chai were right, it was good.

I went there hoping to get some work done. Most of the nearby parking is 2 hours only. I lasted about 90' in an uncomfortable seat by the window, at the kids' table, because all the other tables were full at 9 AM on a weekday. 

The wifi password is on the cash register. The music is not bad. 

Wouldn't be my first choice to get work done, partly because there were so many people already taking up tables with laptops, and partly because there were some people clearly just hanging out to talk, so it wasn't a completely low-traffic spot.
author: Sam Z.

description: I do enjoy the coffee. When I'm in the neighborhood this is my place. The 3 's is because the banana bread was not good at all. So bad in fact, I'm not sure I want to try any other pastries. But the coffee is good, so I will be back.
author: Not M.

description: My new favorite coffee shop... Place is great, coffee is delicious, they even have a nice little patio outside w/ a fake lawn. But most importantly, the vibe is amazing. The energy is strong.
author: Phil H.

description: Solid cafe, really yummy sea salt chocolate chip cookies. Next door is an amazing sandwich place. And they have a little park let out front. Good to study at. And staff is nice.
author: Kaylan A.

description:
I am one of those laptopping grad students who goes to Farley's to fight the loneliness of being a long-form writer. Free wifi, power strip, and people who are decent about sharing tables when it gets crowded. 

But my favorite thing about Farley's? The baristas. Or the baristas' music more specifically. I get so bored with my iTunes and then pop over to Farley's to find ridiculously obscure but rocking new wave, noise rock, math rock, Kate Bush (what category would she even be in?). Some people complain about the music, but I hope Farley's baristas' do not succumb to those complainers' desires for synthetic versions of soothing Kenny G. 

Other favorite thing -- there was a long haired, Asian man barista-ing a few years ago. I had a terrible morning and went in. He asked how it was going. I told him it was pretty sucky. He brilliantly gestured to New Potrero Market next door and suggested that Jameson's goes well with cappuccino. 10 minutes later, baby Jameson's flask in hand, I learned how right he was. And in case anyone has issues with people drinking moderately and responsibly on the job, he definitely did not did not have any jameson's in my company. no no.
author: Lilly I.

description: love this place i come here on occasion good people good location good atmosphere and good karma from the employees and customers good relibale fast wifi too
author: Leigh G.

description: I have been coming here for 10+ years, and am sad to agree with others that the neighborhood charm is gone. A really solid tea list has been replaced with fewer, higher end but less tasty teas. Friendly, quirky staff have been replaced by hipsters with attitudes. Nice big ceramic cups replaced with glass cups (who wants to drink tea in a glass cup?). I used to come back every time I was in the city, but won't be back.
author: LA M.

description:
I love Farley's. It's a great neighborhood spot. The dogs line the sidewalk, people sit at the tables with newspapers and laptops, or with some Hazel's sandwiches, from next door. And best of all, they make good coffee. Each can of milk is individually steamed, and you can see the baristas taking their time to make your coffee well. 

This is not the place to come and ask for a vanilla latte. Even ordering a normal cup of coffee will give you a bit of an eye roll, but they do have it. Come here for standard coffee - lattes, espressos, cappuccinos.. you get my drift. 

They have a great selection of pastries to. They have Anzac cookies, which I haven't seen anywhere else. And the strawberry-rosemary muffins that they have there are great. 

This is a great place to come, relax and enjoy a cup of coffee. I have to say that the staff are sometimes downright rude and in a bad mood, but I just shrug that off. Usually, they are happy and friendly. 

They are cash only, but there is an ATM in the convenience store, next door.
author: Mariko F.

description:
What San Francisco coffeehouse doesn't have food?  I don't need a seasonal lunch menu or scones to die for or free-range chickens that led happy lives until you decided to slit their throats humanely, but I would appreciate a bagel.  Or toast.  Or maybe even--gasp--a sandwich.

But Farley's has none of this.  What it does have is coffee.  And there are games and magazines, so it looks really promising, actually.  Except that it's huge.  That's a positive thing, right?  Well, no, because despite its impressive square footage, it has managed to lay itself out so poorly that there are relatively few places to sit, and all of these places are crowded around one another.

The last time I was here, this blowhard who used to live in the neighborhood was literally walking around striking up conversations with people he used to know/work with/bother.  Despite the fact that no one seemed to be interested in what he was saying, he went on and on about how he had to pick up the keys to his Ferrari because his au pair from Denmark wanted to drive it before she returned home and about how he couldn't decide whether to build a house in Marin or Malibu or Miami.  I was trying to concentrate on grading, but it was impossible because he kept repeating himself loudly to different people.  I was here for at least forty-five minutes, and he was still talking when I left.  He hadn't sat down; he was just hovering and carrying on about his shallow, materialistic life.

You can bring in food from next-door Hazel's Kitchen, and that's pretty nice.  But the ambiance.  It's too big and too cramped at the same time.  It's really cold, and while it looks the part, it's not really a San Francisco coffeehouse.  Its clientele is just a little bit too--well, like that guy.  I know not everyone is like him, but if he felt comfortable doing what he did here and if he used to spend time here, it's likely that many other people are like him.  Where were the unkempt grad students, the struggling, strung-out artists?  Not at Farley's, apparently.

So two stars it would be, except that there's a doozy of a front step, making the place completely inaccessible to wheelchair users.
author: John S.

description: I live in the Castro, but I love coming to Farley's to work remotely. It is relatively quiet for a busy coffee shop, and it's light-filled and airy.
author: Jess W.

description: Slow paced neighborhood coffee house. Read, work on your laptop or kids can use the board games. Very simple, basic, relaxed attitude here.
author: M F.

description: Dropped by this place first time, there was a long line for the only one register. However the cashier had no problem taking time to chat with the 4 people in front of me for 5 minutes. The coffee was alright, but the milk tastes rancid.
author: chloe l.

description:
How adorbs is this cafe?  My cousins live nearby and two of us popped in on St. Patty's Day for a hot tea before heading over to Plow for breakfast (this shop doesn't serve food).  We were totally in for a fun surprise: a live Irish band (complete with violin, guitar, and some other instrument that slips my mind now) were there to treat the crowd in light of the holiday.
When we walked back out about an hour later, a man on a bagpipe was bringing it as well.  So cool!  I am not a fan of bagpipes, but I am a fan of talent and all the musicians were really talented.  Beyond St. Patty's Day, you can tell that Farley is the type of place that really supports local artists, which I appreciate.  Many of their painting hung on the way and the set up of the cafe itself seemed like they must have had a hand in the design. Very nice.  I wish there were a shop like this in my own neighborhood, but for now I will just continue to stop by when I am visiting my fam.
author: Elsa M.

description: I came to redeem my "free coffee" card I think I picked up from Potrero Hill festival . she said she could also make me a mocha or any specialty drink if I wanted . so nice ! my latte was amazing , and I also love the comprehensive "coffee condiments" bar . honey , almond creamer , cocoa , everything you would need . cafe has board games on shelf available to play . very very chill . good for studying or hanging in groups :)
author: Nancee C.

description:
Update: So the reno is done and hopefully with it all the changes

The good-the space has been updated and spruced up without losing it's character. There doesn't seem to be any more seats as they claimed but they didn't loss any seats so that is good. They also take credit and debit card. They also are now serving four flavors of Three Twins Ice Cream (although no cones!).

The bad-the blend is still far worse than it used to be. They are going to be selling sandwiches in direct competition with the sandwich shop RIGHT next door and that is a huge douche move.

The poor decisions just keep on coming at Farley's. The new roast which they proudly proclaim costs more (hipsters seem to have a real love of paying more for less quality) is super sour and weak tasting more like starbucks chain coffee than a local custom roast. The folks have had a month to get the grind and roast right so that isn't the issue. Nope like most of the changes it's a matter of taste. Poor taste.

Roger's son has taken over this place and the changes have not been good. I don't care if they worked in Oakland where he lives but the changes he has made like closing earlier, getting rid of seating and adding really uncomfortable seats and crappy hipster stuff don't improve this place at all. I am for change when it actually makes a place better. His changes haven't. Also a coffee shop does not need a "creative director" ever.

Most of the folks that work there have always been nice and sweet to me and it will still be my local place, I just don't believe in "fixing" things that aren't broken.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: Nice staff, and good service. Always have space to work in peace.
author: F A.

description:
This place is so cute! I'm new to the area, and came here when my girlfriend and I were dog sitting 3 little pups. What a perfect place I walked into. They converted a parking spot into a  little turf area and was so cute - perfect for my little pups to hang. There were tons of dogs and kids around, which made for a really nice vibe.

The owner was actually there, and she was super sweet, and greeted us by giving us dog treats for our pups! She had her own children and new puppy hanging around, which was also super cool.

The actual coffee was good, but the inside cashier seemed a little distracted. Probably just an off day, but it was definitely a little strange how long it took to actually order the coffee. The girl making the coffee was pretty quick though. 

I'd like to come back and try some different drinks - probably next time we dog sit.

Highlights: dog-friendly, kid-friendly, owners are great, and they turf lounge area is a great place to relax on  sunny day in Potreo.
author: Meredith S.

description:
I love it! It feels like a neighborhood hangout spot for the laptop and/or book happy. Seating is cool but the turnover rate isn't, so it can be hard to land a seat, but once you do, you'll enjoy your experience. Magazines and board games galore; compact menu (whew, no decision fatigue) with good coffee; not only FREE, but FAST wifi! (it's not T3 but it's fast for free wifi, so yay!).

My experience: I came here with my sister, and we caught a woman leaving her table so we were able to sit right away - we lucked out there. After receiving my sister's order and getting paid, the employees for some reason completely forgot to make the sandwich. My kind sister forgave them, but I found it negatively memorable...

Nevertheless, I would return :)
author: Lana L.

description: Absolutely amazing granola. Fresh fruit and homemade granola was to die for. Their house blend of coffee is so smooth and easy to drink. The line for Plow down the street was too long so we came to Farley's. They have a partnership with Hazels Kitchen next door so you can get food there and eat at Farley's since Farley's has a very limited menu. Had a blast.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Farley's, a fave cafe in Potrero Hill, has niceoutdoor seating area along with a cozy indoor tables and bench/couch by the window with ample light. 

Oh, don't forget to know that it is one of the few cafes left in SF with a magazine stand!
author: Jackie G.

description:
De la paz latte $3.50.  Solid.

Great mellow spot for doing some work.
author: Josie M.

description: Cute & hip little cafe with upbeat and friendly baristas! My friend, who is originally from SF brought me here & highly recommended this place. Parking was a bit of a pain, but we eventually found a spot. I thought the coffee was just O.K. I would come back to try other drinks, like a chai latte, but I decided to just order an iced latte and since they didn't have soymilk, i opted for almond milk (60 cents extra). Honestly, my latte tasted a bit odd with the almond milk and the coffee flavor wasn't as rich or bold as I would have liked.
author: Juliet Rachel C.

description: I LOVED Farley's.  I think I had the best Latte of my life here!  The environment is very fun to be in both inside and outside.  They roast their own beans and I purchased some as well to take home.  Great coffee!  I will try to go here as often as possible!
author: Denise B.

description: This place needs to get over itself. It hires folks that all seem to be really unhappy to be there, make you feel like a jerk if you do one thing out of line, and simply doesn't match the vibe anymore of the community. The ownership changed a couple years ago and while everyone still goes (because it's location), I think it's less fun. The coffee frankly isn't even that good. Bottom line is I check-in a lot because it's there, and I'm too lazy most of the time to make my own coffee. I wish they'd talk to the staff.
author: Darin A.

description: Love this place! I'm a magazine lover, so this is a great place to go and check them out, read there or buy them. The drinks are awesome and their Internet connection is superb (I often go to work at cafés so this is a major plus for me).
author: Elsa F.

description:
Great space in a unique SF location - the heart of Potrero Hill. 

If you want to be glared at and made to feel like a second class citizen, you no longer have to buy a plane ticket to Paris.

I was so excited when I moved right around the corner from Farley's two years ago. The first few mornings I went in for coffee the people behind the counter were unbelievably rude. I just figured everyone has a bad day, and the place is busy - it is early - the work can be hard. I understand. I waited tables and worked in cafes for ten years before, during and after college.

This experience of INSANELY RUDE servers on the morning shift turned out to be the rule, not the exception. So I started asking my neighbors about their experience at Farley's. Everyone had very similar horrible stories. Some said they still go there out of convenience, but many said they go elsewhere.

Unless you are practicing for your next trip to Paris, avoid Farley's at all costs.
author: B. B.

description:
Huge bookshelf of mags, crazy mix of chairs and tables, Mariah Heartbreaker playing, faux grass sitting area outside -that's what you will get here.

I want to come back for the live shows.
author: Kali F.

description:
I have lived in Potrero Hill for two months and only stumbled upon Farley's about a month ago. I feel as though I have been cheating myself for having not explored my new neighborhood a bit sooner. 

The staff is pleasant and professional and the overall atmosphere of the place is  comfortable. The refills are free so keep in mind that if we went to Starbucks or Peet's we'd pay for our refills. I really like this place.
author: David J.

description: I just love the atmosphere here....for about 15 minutes! A nice selection of pastries and below average cappuccino.  The hot chocolate sucks, don't even bother.  "This is not good at all".- says a youngster who normally downs a hot chocolate from other places in less than 5 minutes.
author: Jodie S.

description: Cozy coffee place, I believe they have free wifi (saw from other customers) but I never used it. Their cookies are delicious and fresh (went in during the evening), and also had their Earl Grey Tea. Very reasonable prices!
author: Elisa L.

description:
DECEMBER:
I revisited Farley's and the espresso is better now... I still prefer the former roast. Everything else about the place is still great.

NOVEMBER:
I like Farley's a great deal in all of its aspects: Nice space, good baristas, pastries, prices, location, atmosphere, music. I liked the espresso a lot until it just changed this month. I am not especially picky, finicky or pretentious about coffee. So I am totally bummed out because the espresso they just changed to tastes bad to me. I have tried the new espresso on five separate occasions. It is different every time - which is not a great thing - but it just doesn't taste good to me. I hope it will change. I will revisit in a few months - for now I will look for another place. 

I want the owner to know this because it is important information to have. Maybe everyone else likes it except me - that would be okay too. Maybe other people will register their opinion of the new coffee.
author: grace v.

description: The coffee here is pretty good, but the service is seriously lacking. The baristas generally seem really unhappy to be there and are just unpleasant to deal with. The pastries are dry and unappetizing. One good thing about Farley's is it's a nice place to sit and people watch. It's usually crowded with Potrero Hill residents and is a good place to feel connected to the community.
author: Diana G.

description: I like Farley's, I really do. But, I don't know what they're thinking in the food department. The scones used to be great, now they suck. I just had some type of bread pudding muffin and it was terrible - super greasy. And the panninis are just bland. If you're going to serve food, at least do it well.
author: Daniel D.

description:
Lovely space, decent menu, great magazine selection, free wifi should be worth a few stars eh?

Most appalling service to the point that I'm of the opinion that anybody who has ever worked in the hospitality industry and has any pride in the trade should blackball this café on principle alone. Hospitality can be an art but most of the time a good attitude will cover you. Farley's staff, you fail.
author: Susan C.

description:
I'm not a frequent visitor, but I saw the reviews for this place while I was getting GPS directions, and I was expecting them to visibly spit in my coffee.

I think the management got the message. The staff was gratuitously friendly - like, under orders to be charming. Dude even complimented my T-shirt. Reward their managerial response to your reviews by giving them your business.
author: Bobby C.

description:
I'm a Potrero local and I really really really want to like Farley's. Every once in a while I give it another shot, thinking I was being to critical, but I always leave disappointed.

It's pretty simple.

The Good:
- Great parklet where you can sit and sip 
- Friendly staff and neighborhood feel
- Board games!

The Bad:
- It hurts to say. Bad coffee. Just not good.
- Slightly overpriced
author: Penny K.

description: This is my first time here at Farley's. I've heard from a lot of friends that I should check it out since I'm a coffee shop lover. Right on point! Great customer service, quality espresso, and the quiche is to die for! Would definitely recommend this place to my friends!
author: Ally M.

description:
Waiting for some friends here was an excellent decision. My wife was in dire need of caffeine, and made the brilliant decision to try their iced mocha. We soon discovered that this place not only has a nifty magazine rack, lots of seating, and free wi-fi, but also the best damn mocha EVER.

I don't even LIKE coffee or espresso, and I loved this thing. It was rich, flavorful, and had the right amount of chocolate without being overly sweet. My wife also purchased a banana, and while I did not try it, she seemed to be of the opinion that it was, in fact, a banana. So there's that.

A happy wife is a happy life - so if yours is feeling cranky and Needs Caffeine Badly, take her here.
author: Matthew L.

description: Guy taking orders was very rude, our coffee and chai order took forever and then when we checked, he gave us some "you caught us on a Sunday" excuse. It was 30 minutes already and they realized that they screwed up only after we checked for the second time. Even then the guy who was rude never apologized and the guy who gave the money back also slammed the change on the table. Took our money, left their free coffee on the table. Someone needs to teach them customer service.
author: Mahatma G.

description:
Simply the most unfriendliest bunch of pseudo-hipsters running a coffee shop that I have ever run into.  Trust me, your coffee's not that good. You need to show at least some human emotions when taking my money instead of acting like I'm bothering you for a cup of coffee.

I started working in the area about two weeks ago. I like the 18th street area and it's convenient for me even if I have to climb that deadly hill. In the 5 times I've been in Farley's, I've actually gotten maybe five words out of the zombies that work in that place, none of which were, "What would you like?".

Get a clue, I stopped going there and now walk an extra two blocks to go to Starbucks in the UCSF campus. You represent the worst of San Francisco posers.
author: Jim T.

description: Been going to farleys from the year it opened and have always enjoyed the ambiance and coffee. However lately. It takes at least 10 minutes to get a latte even when it's not busy and the croissants are verging on terrible and tasted a day old. I hope they step up their game. There's more cafe choices and great coffee in the nabe so that should be a motivator.
author: Pamela W.

description: First time this morning. Staff was so friendly! Plus yummy coffee and ham and cheese croissant. Loved the space and magazines. Plenty of outdoor seating with the parklet. Can't wait to come back!
author: Amber W.

description: Let's just say this place is way better than the Yelp reviews would suggest. I am sitting here on a chill, overcast Sunday afternoon, and there are all sorts of nice and diverse people here. The vibe is conducive to productive laptop studying (free wifi). Most importantly, the drip coffee (or quite possibly pour-over), is very good. I have no idea how some of the reviews manage to conclude that Farley's has the worst coffee in the city... I am more or less a coffee snob and I'm quite satisfied. I haven't tried their espresso-based drinks yet, but I have a good feeling about these as well. Also I really dig their magazine corner. Every table was occupied when I got here, so I spent a few minutes browsing some of these magazines. Shortly thereafter, several tables opened up.
author: Leo G.

description: Great coffee and tea followed by innovated pastry flavors make this place well worth visiting. They also have a lot of magazines to read. One draw back is that people come and sit here for hours. This is why more businesses are starting to limit wifi. There are to many people coming to these type of cafés  and buy one cup of coffee but sit for five hours with a laptop. Go home already!
author: Robert H.

description:
Ok, I went from recommending this place to all of my out of town friends to giving it one star. The reason? The most unpleasant customer service.
The barista at the counter today seemed to hate me the moment she laid her eyes on me. Then practically yelled at me for inquiring about a matcha latte...Phew! She had so much hatred towards me and made me feel like s^%$, I just had to run for my life. I am not sure I'll ever go back, still feeling traumatized.
Owners, please hire more friendly stuff!!
author: Prem M.

description:
OMG - Farley's what happened?  Are you serious, you charge?  I tried to give you ZERO stars but Yelp didn't let me.  

Ok, here's the scoop:

Either the poser with the ugly tattoo on his forearm and his coffee mate, the wicked witch with the nasty spider rings, are the following:

A) Haters of the SF Giants and my baseball cap
B) Haters of paying customers
C) HOMOPHOBIC (maybe hates gays who love their City and their Giants team and this odd combination)?  I was waiting in line with my boyfriend and waiting with our proud caps.

I have no idea why these disorganized jerks would think they have a right to be so rude to paying customers? What did I do?  I hate to say it Farley lovers but I think it is C above.  I have never gotten such rude treatment.  These baristas (vitriolic baristas) were very angry.  I hope that they are not now the owners?  I remember the old gentleman years ago who would be quite hospitable to coffee entusiasts - he was the owner and drew a loyal following.   

This is so sad.  Farley's was the best place in the ate 80's and early 90's to go, hang out, read and enjoy some peace and quiet with smart, nice folks.  

Now it's a nasty place.  If this what their idea of being a hipster is about in the Big City, give me San Jose any day.  

Get lost vitriol Tattoo Man and Witch coffee attendees!
author: Seamus C.

description: If you have the chance to go to Potrero hill, this is what I would consider to be a hidden gem that really makes you take a moment to pause in life. Right outside is a gratitude tree where you can fill out a note about something you are grateful for, or read what others have said. There is a nice greenery too outside, dog friendly! Honestly anything you order here is good, but a personal favorite is the cider! A must try! Brings you right into the holiday spirit! Service here is spectacular, you will always be greeted with a warm welcome smile! Happy holidays
author: Esther K.

description:
This is what a coffee shop should be - 

Located on Potrero Hill, so you have a beautiful view of the city...friendly staff, interesting patrons, and a nicely stocked magazine rack (I picked up The Economist, Utne Reader, and Harper's).  

My iced coffee was great and the bar had organic cream and raw sugar (not in the little packets but bulk, better for the environment!)- 

Congratulations Farley's for keeping it real!~
author: Jesseca T.

description: Good coffee, good magazine selection, unique music taste, and the baristas are very friendly. I like that there's a chalkboard in the bathroom where people right all sorts of interesting things. Very cool. I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Jacob T.

description:
Update: After I wrote my review, I received a personal note from Farley's and I have to say, I was impressed. They are aware that service hasn't been great. But mostly, the message they sent was very considerate. Bumped it up from 2 stars to 3 stars. I really appreciate their concern and it shows a lot about their efforts. Now if that service thing were to improve, it'd be even better. But for now, I'll come back and ignore that other stuff.

**************

I only come here because the location is convenient and they have seating (although it gets full during busy times). But that's about it. Their coffee is okay. I usually get lattes and the ones here have been good or just okay. Food selection is just your typical sweets (cookies, fruit bar stuff, etc.). What I don't care for is the occasional surly, unfriendly face behind the counter. Too bad. Also they just take cash.

Clientele is fine. Pretty typical city cafe people with their laptops and conversations. Not overrun by any particular type in my opinion. There's an interesting mix on the weekend.
author: Veronica H.

description:
the coffee, crowd, and games is worth every step I take up the hill to get my caffeine rush.. well its good for my glutes too...since, in this town everyone is advertising their arse one way or another...thus I get to take care of both my fave ass-ets!!

Some snaps and clenches for the CARD program...it keeps me coming back!
author: Bryan G. W.

description:
I really want to love this place but the attitude is just a little too much. The coffee is good but not great. My advice is go up or down the hill.  

Skip it.
author: Joseph M.

description: This place sucks and the staff are a bunch of hipster-idiot-wannabees. It is sad it is the only place to get coffee in Potrero as I have had to come here for many time already. Everytime I walk in it seems as though I am interupting their morning suicide cult kool-aid party, and they look at me, repulsed, as if I am so vile to ask one of the 3 employees standing there for a cup of Joe before they all keel over. If you live in Potrero and must visit this place, don't. Buy a coffee maker and a bag of Peet's and save yourself the trouble and depression session.
author: Phillip K.

description: I love this place! Cute neighborhood coffee shop in Portrero Hills. Browse magazines while enjoying your coffee. Is there a better place to spend some relaxation time?
author: Betty C.

description: Nothing bad to say about this place! Love the new parklet in front, fake grass and all. The boardgames are also a great offering, and the magazines are always a fun distraction. I travel across the city sometimes to spend an afternoon at Farley's...need I say more to convince you of its splendor?
author: Erin W.

description: Nice neighborhood spot.   Service wasn't great and, without the outdoor seating and the little public parklet, there wouldn't really be at that much space or seating.   I came in and it was pretty busy. I ordered some pour over coffee. There wasn't really any room inside to sit down and the space over by the counter where it looked like they would hand over drinks was kinda awkward. I ended up going outside, but the service had no way of calling me in for my coffee. They definitely didn't come outside to let me know it was ready. Since it was a little busy, I had to come in a couple times and checking to see if my coffee was ready. Kind of a pain.
author: Corey O.

description: Small indoor space with outdoor seating. I went in on a reasonably busy Sunday, but I was still able to claim a table and a power outlet inside. Chill atmosphere, hipster baristas, good coffee, and free WiFi. Nice place to sit and work-slash-people-watch for hours.
author: Anna B.

description: Been coming here for years!  Love the new look.  Staff always so accommodating.  Coffee's amazing, but my new addiction is their breakfast sandwiches that can feed a family of 3 or just me.  Keep it up, Farley's!
author: Jaime A.

description: This is the best coffee I've found in San Francisco so far. It's a neighborhood coffee shop that's been here for quite some time. The walls are adorned with local art, and they're usually playing music I dig. What keeps us coming back is the coffee and the quality at which it's made. One of the baristas even recently competed in a competition. The lattes are always perfect, and their food is quite good as well. Try the quiche on the weekends.
author: Brian C.

description: Quaint neighborhood coffee shop in Potrero Hill. Perfect place to stay out of the cold while waiting for a table at plow
author: Vince E.

description:
Farley's reminded me of being back in Brooklyn, NY, in a bad way. That was the first time I've really experienced "hipsters" outside of NYC, and I can now confidently say that they're just as annoying on the West coast.

I ordered a small cappuccino with skim milk. The barrista proceeded to ask me if i "was sure" I wanted skim milk, then told me "it's mostly air anyway." He didn't say this in a nice, friendly way, either. I'm all about barristas making good recommendations, but don't be condescending and lecture me on my choice of milk. I asked for skim milk, so give me skim milk please. 

I asked another barrista where the bathroom was and she was equally as unfriendly. Then when I was in the bathroom, they have this "Dear Ms. Manners" letter posted on the paper towel dispenser about how it's bad practice to use more than one paper towel when drying your hands because it's bad for the environment. I'm all about saving trees, but next time skip the passive aggressive sign that I wasted 5 minutes of my life reading, and just post a nice friendly reminder to be considerate of the environment, like most places do. 

I must say, however, that the cappuccino itself was good. The espresso they used was quite tasty. However, the quality of the drinks, for me personally, is not worth the condescending preachy barristas and the hipster vibe.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Wow, Farley's - don't look me in the eye when I order a coffee, and then instead of giving me my change back - you put it in the tip jar?  

I'll be getting my coffee elsewhere from now on.
author: Michelle P.

description:
I've alwayed the coffee, location, and magazine rack at Farley's. On several occasions, its been the only reason I've taken an afternoon to get some work done when I'm near Potrero. 

And yet I seem to forget that Farley's seemed staffed by people who are incapable of being nice. So much so that they seem to take some nasty pleasure in being just a little less than polite, a little cold rather than helpful, and a little to eager to tell you what they can't do rather than what they can. 

Case in point: I'm writing this review from Farley's. I ordered an iced coffee 10 minutes ago, which was delicious. The fellow behind the counter began our interaction not with "hello" or "what can I get for you?" but with "the line is on this side of the counter." (Hey, jerk. There isn't anyone else ordering. a) how was I to know that b) what difference does it make and c) you beginning our transaction by scolding me makes me want to turn around and leave). After getting my coffee, I asked him for less ice, which he ignored. I then paid, tipped him anyway, at which point he didn't say thank you and waved his hand over his shoulder when I asked where the cream was. 

Farley's, I understand everyone has a bad day. This is at least the 4th time I've had this kind of rude, careless service at your counter. It is not cool, it is not fashionable, it isn't "just our vibe." Rude is rude. 

Would it kill you to be nice people? If the answer is anything other than "no, it would not" I would be happy to leave and never come back.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I stopped in this morning for some coffee and to hang out and use my computer and have had a good experience. The staff is not exactly friendly but I haven't had any problems with them. I've had two cups of coffee and a scone which I've enjoyed.

The atmosphere has been good for working (good music, some light conversations around, good internet), and I've generally enjoyed myself. I'll likely be back again to hang out and get some work done.
author: Kathryn H.

description: Best $2 tea.  I wish their petition to sell beer went through.  It's got such a better vibe than most things in the area.
author: Steven S.

description: Just moved to the neighborhood and my boyfriend and I came here for coffee on Saturday morning. There was a line out the door, but the line moved decently quick. The guy who took our order wasn't all that friendly, but the coffee and fruit Danish was tasty! We sat out on the par kelt (which would have been better if it were sunny). Coffee was good, latte was tasty and Danish was decent. Nothing amazing but I'll be back-good cute neighborhood spot!
author: Sarah F.

description:
I love Farley's! I am biased because I'm in the neighborhood, but as neighborhood coffee shops go, it's the best. They carry delicious pastries, their coffee is good, and it's full of local regulars. It's a really unique/artsy/dive-y place with a lot of character. And to make it even better, you can bring your breakfast bagel or sandwich from Hazel's next door to eat.

It can get pretty crowded at peak hours, but if you get a table, it's a great place to work, provided you have good headphones (if you need quiet).

I recommend their maple-apple-bacon or ginger scones if you're there for breakfast.

The baristas are a little hit or miss, but some are really great. Some are a little snooty-acting, but not in an annoying hipster or trendy way. Just...different.
author: P F.

description:
I love coming here when I know who's working the front.  Evan and another dude with a beard and tattoos (so sorry I forgot your name) are so awesome and interesting to talk to.  They're great for catching up with for a few minutes.  On the other hand, the Vince Gallo wannabe and his merry band of hipster-cronies are assholes so I just keep walking when I see any of them up front.  

It's great for what it is, a local coffee shop.  I live around the corner so it's not as if I'm making some holy pilgrimage for a cup of coffee.  So I don't take it personally if someone gives me attitude, I just learn my lesson and keep walking down to Chats instead.   

If Evan and Epic Beard Guy ever leave, that would probably be it for me*
author: CeeLo L.

description: A nice neigborhood coffee place in Potrero Hill.  I've had coffee here couple of times and both times felt it was "average", thus didn't understand why they've won awards.  Perhaps it's the independant (anti-Starbucks) feel.  T-Shirts they sell here looks pretty cool - I would buy it if I ever become a regular here, but I cannot see myself coming here over places like Crossroads Cafe (http://www.yelp.com/biz/t5C-jBvWZ69XrIm6eaJL7Q) or Ritual Coffee Roasters (http://www.yelp.com/biz/VOoHZDC-dgDUzTSsmgESOQ).
author: トモ T.

description: If you're looking for a languid hangout with good coffee, good people, and a good vibe, this is your place. Farley's knows who it is, and it doesn't pretend to be something it's not. It's good, regular folks who like to drink good coffee and hang out. Our 9 year old loved curling up in the window seat to read her book while we relaxed. An overall chill vibe. We'll become regulars.
author: Rae B.

description:
I come from a city with a strong coffee culture (Melbourne, Australia) and my coffee experiences in SF have been lukewarm. The best of the bunch I have tried has been Blue Bottle, but that varies according to where I get it from.

Last weekend I went to Farleys as I heard it was the 'best coffee in SF'. And as a fussy coffee drinker, I'm happy to say it was. Smooth to sip and at the perfect temperature where I don't have to wait 10 minutes to drink.

Great atmosphere inside, but with coffee like that, I would drink it anywhere.
author: Marina K.

description:
For 4 long years I enjoyed Farley's coffee as I sped my way through grad school. And by sped, I mean practically main-lined coffee to get me through my intense schedule.

Fortunately, Farley's was the perfect place to get my fix. Lots of tables to spread out and study. And the fact that they have a really impressive magazine stand still makes me yearn for my days on Portrero Hill. I'll admit, Farley's is the coffeehouse equivalent to crushing on a guy who's way too cool to ever pass a glance your way.

The coffee has always been good. (and by coffee I mean "latte" as drinking regular coffee would burn my stomach into a terrible mess) The service has always been a little fair-to-midland, but no one has ever been rude to me. Taking my past experiences into consideration, I gotta say that this weekend's visit to Potrero Hill revealed a different caffe latte of yesteryear. 

It was in the same "one cup." It was made by the same dude with the cool glasses who would make my coffee back in the day. It was more refined and smoother. It was the sort of latte to languor over. The sort of latte deserving of being sipped whilst people watching at one of the sidewalk tables.

Farley's still has the quintessential Potrero Hill clientele of classic car and motorcycle enthusiasts, acupuncture school students, true hipsters (not your run of the mill Mission hipsters), and cool families. They offer non-fat milk now. (I guess the "One cup, One milk" tag line is done.) 

What I would give to have a Farley's just like this one in my neighborhood. Turns out, I'm still crushing pretty hard.
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
If you don't live or work in Portero hill, I assume you probably don't spend much time up there and you are missing out. There are lots of great restaurants and I particularly love the street where Farley's coffee is. Farley's is like a small town coffee shop. It's quiet, there's free two hours of wireless and they have great coffee. 

It's well worth the trek up the hill!
author: Julia H.

description:
My personal favorite is the cappuccino.  Lots of foam and hot enough where its nice and toasty but cool enough where I can actually still drink the dang thing. haha. 

The ambiance is great with lots of seating areas and it also includes a whole section with magazines you can read and buy.  This place would be a great place for studying, getting together with friends or even taking your cup of joe to go. They're fast and somewhat friendly.
author: JENNY P.

description:
The heart of Potrero Hill. This has been our home away from home since moving here 11 years ago. Great coffee. Expansive and informed magazine rack. Baristas that exude cool. Rotating funky art exhibits. The best banana bread on the continent. A collection of doodle journals dating back to the early 90s. 

And now for the picky and high-maintenance, they have non-fat, skinny, soy, etc. to add to their classic "i'll take that with full cow" option.

Roger is a neighborhood institution.
author: Nicki P.

description: Great local neighborhood place to get a cup of coffee. It can get pretty busy on the weekends but that's because local brunch places have over-an-hour wait so everyone goes here to have a cup of coffee while waiting for a table. The parklet outside provides nice outdoor seating that is just glorious on a sunny day.
author: Rylan C.

description:
Cup o' joe and Whitesnake blasting at 10am.

The Coffee is great, and the magazine rack is a good idea.  The only thing that I hate is the collection of hipster douchebags with their stupid flannel shirts, dumb mustaches, and awful hats.  Hipsters ruin neighborhoods, and this is no exception, but Farley's gets 4 stars for the coffee for sure.
author: Paul T.

description: Farley's is pretty decent. The coffee is good, and so is the granola/yogurt. Usually the baked goods are tasty, but I recently found nut shells in my banana bread. There used to be some good talent behind the counter, but lately they've been slipping.
author: Lloyd B.

description:
The coffee and espresso are great and completely for purists (no Monin flavored syrups here). Love the awesome variety of magazines that are for sale. Decent seating inside and out.  

But someone needs to tell the people that work here that it wouldn't hurt to smile once and a while. All of the employees seem utterly annoyed at everyone and everything.
author: Jen D.

description: Was excited to try this place as it's always full of customers no matter what the day & time. Ordered cafe au lait & almond croissant. Cafe had no steamed milk at all, which is my favorite part of the drink. Croissant was tough, not tender & flaky. Came back a few days later to try chai latte. Found it very spicy & lacking sweetness: I added sugar. Service both times was friendly, atmosphere relaxed, seating comfortable. May go back for convenience of location & chill neighborhood vibe, not for food.
author: Kira K.

description: Our favorite weekend hangout. Total neighborhood joint. Lovely parquette in front. Cool games, toys, full designy magazine selection, colorful regulars. Family friendly and non pretentious but yet hip.
author: Caneel R.

description:
A lovely place to relax and sip and catch up with a friend, or a book.

Wonderful even if you're allergic to coffee.
author: Miriam W.

description: I could hang out here, strike up a conversation, play games, people watch, and drink cafe au lait with brown sugar and a dash of cinnamon all day. And buy a magazine (they seem to have a nice selection). Anyone want to join?
author: Andrew K.

description:
Went there today for the first time without having read a single review.

First customer of the day.

NO GREETING, NO good morning, NO welcome.  IGNORE! They wouldn't have noticed if I didnt place order and just walked out to a place where someone would say hello as I walked in door.

Beyond unfriendly. Felt hostile.

Tried their darndest to ignore me while I placed order.

Never thanked me for order.

Really?  Neighbourhood coffeeshop?? Blech. Beyond disappointing.
author: Leslie K.

description:
Everybody Loves Farley's.  Just like Everybody Loves Raymond.  Except for me, I think Raymond is boring and neurotic, and not in a funny way.

Granted, I've only been to Farley's once, out of four people, only one was satisfied with their beverage.  We received a teapot filled so low the water didn't even touch the tea, a luke-warm latte, and a mocha that I suspect was actually a hot chocolate (a suspicion confirmed amongst the table of seasoned mocha drinkers).

I politely asked the dejected hipster-girl working up front to add a little espresso, as it tasted like she may have forgotten.  I received a blank stare and the response, "No. It's a mocha. I added it."  Oh, well, hmmm... then I GUESS YOU MAKE THE WORST MOCHAS EVER.  

Finally she agreed to remake it, which I don't think was necessary as all I wanted was a little coffee added, but whatever.  When my drink was ready, she announced loudly and with a perceivable snark:
"Mocha... REMADE!"

I guess she wanted to advertise to other customers that she was making sub-standard beverages, though I'm not sure of her motives for yelling so loudly when I was still standing right in front of her.

So I don't know.  Other people seem to love it, the one person at our table who liked her drink went there three more times over the course of her stay in Potrero Hill, and claimed other baristas were more pleasant.  But I'm not going back. If I want snarky coffee, its a lot easier to patronize the million cafes here in the Mission.
author: Mari C.

description: I'm a picky tea drinker. There's very few varieties I like and which sit well with my stomach. So I was expecting to get my standard mint tea when I saw that Farley's serves licorice tea! Now almost nobody that I've ever met likes licorice tea, but it's my very favorite and so I was stoked that some wise person also values its deliciousness. They had no problem giving me additional hot water. Farley's is full of a lot of things that I love in a coffee shop: magazines (not to mention a magazine stand), free wi-fi, nice window seats and outdoor tables, games, and nice baristas. It'd be nice if they had some savory options in addition to pastries. This is a solid cafe of choice with a special treat for the rare licorice tea aficionados.
author: Megan K.

description:
I love Farley's.

That's the only to express how Farley's is to me; this coffee/tea joint is my new boyfriend that smells mm-mm good! Ever since we met a couple of months ago, I've made sure to stop by on the way home from the city. Even though PH is a little out of my way, I always make a stretch to get my cup of tea (sorry folks, grew up being a tea snob from my time in the UK). I haven't given their coffee a try yet, but I will in the near future.

Their chamomile and organic jasmine blends are simply divine; the chamomile crisp, while the jasmine very fresh. I prefer the cup (less than $2 w/free fill up of hot water!), rather than the pot (less than $4), though I'm not sure if I get a free fill for that, too? I don't know Besides, the cup is enough, it's pretty big. 

As for the service, couldn't ask for more. Everyone there is nice and helpful. When I pay for my order, I'm usually told that if I wanted more hot water, just ask. Even though I've already engraved it in my brain, it's real nice of them to let me know. And the milk, sugar, honey & such is off to a sideboard by the magazines.

Oh, the magazine corner. Very impressive collection. They have a LOAD of different names, and subjects from auto to music to beauty to...well, you get the idea! There are some outdoor seating; few tables for two and seats that holds those plants/small trees (whatever it is you call them), as well as a few seats by the window, more tables for two, and wall/diner style seats inside. The atmosphere is very relaxed, selection of music very nice (well, it's my type of songs, so I deal), all in all, my 'boyfriend' is very comforting.

I usually take the 22 when I go to Farley's, there's a stop on Texas and you just backtrack to Farley's. Or when I'm coming from CalTrain on 4th and King, I take the T (off at 3rd and 20th, transfer on the 22) or 10 (get off on 18th and Connecticut) to get there.

Until we next meet (which is tonight, yay!) boyfriend. Don't worry, I won't cheat on you with Starbucks anymore (sorry, I was craving tea and there was only Starbucks in Barnes & Noble!!). Maybe Peet's, but that's only because you live 20 miles away from me and Peet's is a few minutes from the house.
author: C. H.

description:
Two stars for the coffee + and extra for the very cool very low effort decor. I mean Scrabble and Yahtzee! games, etc. stack (or more like thrown) on a shelf, very ancient floor looking like it was rescued from a sunken ship, the galvanized table tops, the casual arrangements of magazines, yaddah yaddah.

We all had the decaf latte (it was late), and they were large and only OK on strength and improved with a sprinkling of cinnamon and a touch of turbino sugar.

Loved the laid back jazzy music and the overall feeling of winding down there.

They got yet another extra star [totaling 4] for "going Green" meaning fair trade organic coffee is at least part of their mix of coffees. Their pastries looked yummy too--thick cut and moist, but alas, I didn't have room.
author: Glenn H.

description: Great, strongly brewed coffee.  I love the outdoor area, where I can sit with my dog.  The staff have always been very friendly, and the overall vibe is friendly and comfortable.  Inside is a cool "living room" type environment, great to bring your laptop and work for a few hours or visit with a friend.
author: Steve S.

description: Review #1208. Nicer spot to pick up an espresso when you are in the neighborhood with some De La Paz. The parklet was an excellent addition especially on a sunny day after the rain where you can breathe in some fresh crisp air. The laid back style is perfect on a lazy Sunday afternoon after a good brunch over at Plow.
author: T L.

description: I recently went back to Farley's for the first time in over a year. The workers there are now friendly and prompt, such a positive change from a year ago! Their house coffee still tastes great, and the cappuccino was nicely made with coffee art. Keep up the great work!! Nice work with the renovation, too.
author: Ender X.

description: Came here to get some studying done due to their late hours. Atmosphere is good for studying (nice tables and chairs), big windows that let in a lot of light, but the music is WAY TO LOUD! Even with earplugs, it was too loud. Most of the other people there were also trying to do work, so I don't understand why they think the music needs to be so loud.
author: Nancy B.

description:
It's got a friendly vibe, but the chairs are too hard.  I want a nice fluffy couch.  Every cafe should have a nice fluffy couch.

Never tried their food.  Only had tea. and by the way, what is up with the whole white tea movement?  It's green, you know that, right?
author: Audrey T.

description: So here's the deal.  Farley's owner wrote me a really cool, caring response to my review.  Did it fix the problem?  I'll see the next time I go back.  What really matters is because he took the time to reach out to me, I WILL go back.  Well done, and for that you get a star-up for professionalism and customer service.
author: Liz S.

description:
i love this neighborhood cafe tucked away in potrero hill.  they have an extensive collection of magazines and board games as well!

be aware of how strong their coffee is, i had a latte in the afternoon and i couldn't sleep until 3 am!  farley's is also a great place to grab a cup of coffee on the go and walk around the neighborhood, or to sit down and enjoy there.
author: Carli F.

description:
i was just here yesterday and that makes it the third time since i've moved into the area and every time it has been the same experience with the same story: I walk in, place my order, checkout the magazines, maybe sit down for about 5 minutes (if you can find a seat), get my soy latte, and walk out. Coffee's not great but it's not bad either. 

i'm also not so sure about the staff.  I've read other reviewers mentioning the baristas can be kind of snotty and less than friendly, but i'm not there to make friends or socialize with employees. As an observation, they do all seem to have the same faddish fashion style so there are probably discriminatory hiring practices at bay but that ain't my job. I'm there for coffee and maybe a magazine. 

About hanging out there, well it's a coffee shop and they got tables. Customers should add the atmosphere and so far i haven't stayed there long enough to experience it. Will report here if that ever changes.
author: Rob M.

description:
Wow, I just read Michelle P.'s review and can't believe that happened at the same place I know and love. I know the staff can come off a little snooty at times, but all in all they mean well. Plus, I don't even think they are snooty, but that they have their own way. For myself personally, I used to walk down the hill every day to grab a latte when Thinker's is just steps away from my old house. I I never sat around much and hung out here because I honestly find the seating to be awkward and uncomfortable. However, as a teen I sat for hours and read the magazines (isn't that was teenagers do?)

Farley's is my favorite in San Francisco. Yes, over Ritual. There is one cup and I think two milks-- soy and regular. Try the pastries too, they aren't bad. And if not, Hazel's Kitchen is right next door. 

Oh, and they only take cash!
author: Alex V.

description: The go-to in the neighborhood for coffee, breakfast, lunch and chilling.
author: Vicki L.

description: I was quite disappointed by the place. We have been living in Potrero for few years now. Of course, Farleys is the coffee place of Potrero hill. We tried to go for an afternoon coffee after a walk around the neighborhood. It was Sunday afternoon. So, in the shop there were about 27 people of which 16 had laptops and doing some sort of work. So, I wondered: am I in a coffee shop or a conference room for some sort of business meeting? I have to deal with that kind of situations already 5 days a week. Why would I like to go to a coffee shop where I feel like I am in one of those freaking meeting rooms? All these people staring at their screen completely oblivious of anything around them. Too bad! I think Farleys could be a very nice place if it wasn't for that feeling of working environment that I got on a Sunday afternoon. Ahh, by the way: all laptops where Apple. Is there some kind of of unspoken rule that state that only MacBooks are allowed in coffee shops?
author: Luca R.

description: Coffee is pretty good. They have electric outlets and wifi for laptops. Good place to work from your laptop. The outdoor seating is nice on sunny days and provides a good view. The magazine selection they have here is great.
author: Al S.

description: Coffee was a little stingy and and the milk was not fresh.  I had to go afterwards.  I usually have fine stomach when I drink coffee at other places.  And I love coffee!
author: Byron L.

description:
Farley's gets five stars for the yummy spicy chai with perfect foam, and ready to drink right away just how i like it (not too hot to enjoy)!! Good magazines to look at while i waited (though some art mags would be appreciated).. nice space too.

Four stars for the word of mouth reputation- I've heard bad things about some of the staff from other people that work around here (a certain uber rude girl..) but my experience today was lovely. Hope I never get a coffee jones on an off day, because my cup was so super good.

P.S. Cash only.
author: Jen H.

description:
The staff apparently has to undergo weeks of a-hole training before being allowed behind the counter. It had become a pastime for me to wait for my coffee (no other options in the neighborhood) and witness:

- Counter person greet incoming customers by staring at them without speaking.
- Grumpy barista getting increasingly pissed every time anyone asks him things like "Is this my mocha?"

I now walk over the (steep) hill to Piccino to get better coffee without the attitude.
author: Tom O.

description:
Eh. Nice magazine selection. Decent pastries. Coffee is OK, but what's with the one size cup only? I think they should lower their drip coffee price a bit. I mean, it's still less than $2, but come on, that little cup has to be what? 10oz. Maybe 12 max. I never go to Starbucks, but their Venti is the size of coffee I need in the morning. 

Purely average (or maybe below) for Joe on the Goe. Maybe better if you're going to hang out a bit (which I haven't done). 

Is this the only place to get coffee near the 22 stop here on Potrero?

I can thank them for one thing, now I brew my own at home in the morning. Coffee maker with timer FTW!!!  ;-)
author: Andrew C.

description:
Ref. Jeff R.'s comments last week on "the mean people behind the counter" -- today being a week later and also a Monday, I went into Farley's at 8:40 a.m. and ordered.  The cashier was fine, but there was a long line of people waiting to get their coffee. After ordering, I waited and chatted with a friend. I witnessed the coffee-making person* rudely snap at someone asking whether their coffee was done yet, and when after four and a half minutes my cafe au lait wasn't finished yet, the guy snapped at me too: "It's coming!" 

Perhaps this is a problem with the guy who makes coffee* on Mondays. Anyway, the coffee itself is fine. 

One other problem. Monday mornings is street cleaning between 8 and 9 a.m. so parking is very hard to find. Frankly I'll avoid this place on Mondays from now on. As for the coffee-making clown* with the snippy manner: Listen, Chuck, anybody who comes into your cafe and orders espresso has done it a million times at a thousand other cafes. They know how long it takes a competent person to make espresso. And none of these people were rude to you. You are an ass.

* who doesn't deserve the appellation "barista"
author: Mark P.

description:
Not bad.  espresso = good.

The hipster behind the counter was a bit rude but the service was fast and the coffee was good.  I guess it is a SF thing for the staff at "hip" places to be a-holes.

The place is relatively lively.   If you are looking to read and need more silence than most this is not the place to bring a book - unless you get a seat outside.  They do have a ton of games and free wifi.
author: Aus B.

description: Love this place!  Have been coming here for years, stopping in to get a cup of coffee for my drive down the peninsula to work. Cool neighborhood vibe and great coffee too.
author: Frank O.

description:
Coffee was just ok, it's nice to have almond milk out for coffee....that ups the review for me.  The scone- kinda average.  If you like a drier scone with crispy edges, it's for you.
The chocolate croissant was a bit tastier.
author: Sara V.

description:
I absolutely love this place and wish I lived closer.   I had a meeting here a few weeks ago and absolutely loved the atmosphere and the coffee too.  The people there are really great too!

Is there an east bay one planned soon? :-)
author: Ayelet B.

description: Really good turkey cheddar sandwich. Coffee is pretty good too! Wished they would close the door though. It's cold! Plus I wish they had more outlets, instead of only on one side of the cafe.
author: B K.

description: Farley's makes one of the best lattes in the city--bold, creamy, minimal acidity--well, only if you know to ask for a DOUBLE SHOT. They also carry Sandbox Bakery pastries--always a major plus in my book--in addition to a wide range of magazines, from the commercial to obscure and foreign. What's adorable is their fake lawn patch out front where you can sit and pretend you're on your own porch.
author: Nicole L.

description: oh Farley's, I love you so. From your fabulously delicious double lattes (to go, please) to the free back issues of some of my favorite magazines (Black Book, InStyle and Food and Wine? no cover? NO PROBLEM!) and a nice place for me to study on a Friday night until 10pm.
author: Holly C.

description:
Kudos to Farley's for hosting cool community events such as the Annual Pet Fest and Pet Parade!  The current photo wall (photos taken by Christopher Irion) is wonderful!

http://blog.junbelen.com/2009/11/16/farleys-at-18th-street/
author: Jun B.

description:
Farley's is an anachronism-- the kind found only in the Pacific Northwest or college towns in the Midwest. But I don't mean to imply it's not progressive. 

As I write this, there's a gentleman with a baby strapped across his chest reading whatever vegans read after they finish Omnivore's Dilemma, The Misfits are playing on the stereo (hardly a hi-fi, more like a glorified boom box... perfect for The Misfits), three dogs waiting obediently outside, the rejuvenating scent of coffee and pastries filling the air, and not a single non-Macintosh computer in the joint. My kind of coffee shop.

But, the anachronistic part lies in their sheer disregard of modern coffee shop convention (ahem, Peet's, Starbucks, etc.) There's a gigantic magazine rack sitting in the corner-- if only people actually read them!-- at least 10 people on their computers who haven't returned to the counter for seconds in over an hour, and none of the Crate & Barrel polish of the more chic San Francisco java hot spots.

The result? I love Farley's. Nestled in the greatest little area of the City by the Bay, it even overlooks the bay and downtown on a clear day, Farley's truly is a neighborhood coffee shop. It is MY neighborhood coffee shop... as long as they keep playing The Misfits.
author: Ross S.

description: Relatively quiet but still has a vibrant air. Mostly not youth, but still cool. Has lots of different boardgames and magazines! Played Fact or Crap, and it was funnnn :D Americano was $2.50, completely worth it thinking of how much it would cost to buy one magazine/boardgame.
author: Soo Jung R.

description:
Farley's is the best utilitarian coffee shop in the city.  If I'm working and in my neighborhood I come here almost daily.  You can work here for hours and no one bothers you, they almost always play good music (have you ever worked to Tago Mago? because you will get a LOT done), and the coffee is strong.  I realized today that they carry *both* cabinet and n+1, too, so I might have to begin paying more attention to the magazine rack (order paper monument, please!).  

The one draw-back: the acoustics are not so great, so if it's crowded it's loud and sometimes the customers can be weirdly aggressive about table-sharing (don't get me wrong, I like to share, but at least ask first!).  I certainly haven't had any negative run-ins with the baristas (like some reviewers), but I just ask for what I want and keep out of the way.
author: C J.
