description: I'm really loving the makeover on Farley's. Not to mention they have the best chocolate chip cookies. My kids love the board games and the toys. Great on a rainy day... or just for a pick me up.
author: Anna F.

description: Everything about the ambiance of this neighborhood cafe is to love, but the espresso pulls are thin, and the crema is always burnt or non-existant. Farley's, I want so much more from you.
author: Fire B.

description:
What a cute joint. Today was the first time hanging out in Potrero Hill. And I have to say, it's a neighborhood that definitely has a cool personality.

Met up with a friend at Farley's for some iced lattes. They pull a nice shot here--the espresso was bold enough to wake you up, but sweet enough where you don't need to add sugar. Definite props to the barista. The weather (no credit to Farley's) was awesome; the kind of late afternoon that coats the streets, parked cars, and shop facades with the warm hue of creme brulee. Which is probably why all the tables inside were taken. Thankfully, they've also got a few benches outside.

Puppies. Delicate conversations. Reading material. Farley's seems like a good place for all these things, plus a nice cup of coffee.
author: Tony L.

description:
By FAR the Best coffee shop South of Cafe Trieste!

My good friend "Lord E." named his dog after this place.

Pros:
NO "non-fat" milk keeps away the starbucks crowd... this is how to run a coffee shop!

Cons:
They run out of banana bread too early... this is the BEST banana bread in SF! got to get there before 9am. I shouldn't even be giving this secret away right now, but hey! maybe they'll make more upon reading my review.

Oh, almost forgot...  the "brown sugar trick", I saw a guy do this at Farley's in like 1995, have been doing it since.  This is the ONLY place I would ever drink a latte.. get it extra foamy, then sprinkle the brown sugar on top- and watch it melt.  See my photo posted.  This is highly recommended!
author: Andy B.

description:
Decided they would add wi-fi which attracts the lap top sitter and non-fat milk.  Still the staff is rude.  Following is recent experience...

me:  "um, my latte?"  (ordered 10 minutes before)
hipster barrista:  "Your depth-charge is right there"  points to cup on counter
Me:  " I didn't order a depth charge"
hipster barrista:  "WELL, that's what I heard"  ....silence...
me: "Well!  I know I didn't order it because I don't even know what a depth charge is.."
hipster barrista: "sure about that?  'cause thats what you said"
me: "yeah, I'm positive"
hipster barrista:  makes grand gesture of throwing depth charge away and sneers.
author: Anibel B.

description: Some people may complain in their reviews about the staff here, but honestly its a cup of coffee for $1.75, what are they supposed to do? Kiss your ass for it? They do ask you what you want, you tell them, they get it for you, and you pay them... Not too out of the ordinary. Plus they have an awesome rewards card - buy 9 get the 10th one free, something Starbucks doesn't necessarily indulge in. Anyway, if you want no free coffee ever, and you like your ass to be kissed by someone pouring you a cup of coffee because your lazy self couldn't make any that morning, maybe you should get over your obsession with corporations. If you want some awesome coffee in a rad little neighborhood barely tucked away from the city, go to Farleys!! Plus they support the art and music scene, and they have an extensive selection of magazines to look through. Win.
author: Julie P.

description:
Farley's is a very cool neighborhood joint.

It has an aura that is very similar to the coffee shop "Central Perk" on "Friends" (the TV show) without the comfortable sofas or Gunther, but decent in space and unique.  

My friend and I scored seating inside amongst other neighborhood patrons who came with their laptops to work.  Due to those people, though - it's a bit hard to talk in this coffee shop at a discernable volume because with everyone solo at their tables, two chatty girls talking could be heard by basically all.  We were discussing... uh... classified information.  

What disappoints me about Farley's is that their coffee is mediocre.  It's just nothing special - can't even hold a candle to Starbucks, in my opinion, never mind premium coffee like Blue Bottle.  Some love Farley's coffee, so to each his/her own, but it just wasn't my cup of coffee.  It was just OK.

Service was acceptable - - nothing warm or friendly but I can't say they were rude, either.  It's unfortunate, though, because I am sure with outstanding servers, Farley's would be the preferred coffee joint in the neighborhood for many more people.  I have been to Starbucks that make service much more personal than this place.

I've always made clear my love for coffee.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/starbucks-coffee-company-seattle-21#hrid:KvXoHdOKb7h6porFguGZuw/src:self

And I'm inclined to live at a good coffee joint for half my day with a good friend and great conversation if the coffee is good.  I've stayed at one coffee shop for up to 10 hours straight with various friends.  I'm not kidding.  (Yes, I am extremely sedentary!)

Farley's?
Good atmosphere, minimum service, and mediocre coffee.  Not bad, but not particularly great, either!
author: Grace K.

description: neighborhood spot and gathering place. great coffee. nothing not to love, right down to the astroturf sidewalk garden.
author: diana m.

description:
"Gretchen T sure is writing a lot of coffee shop reviews these days," you say? Well, that is because I HAVEN'T SLEPT MORE THAN 4 HOURS STRAIGHT IN OVER 4 MONTHS! Motherhood is by far the coolest thing I have ever done and I adore my child like no one has ever adored her child, but Jesus H (wait, is he a Yelper?) am I exhausted. Sleep has now superseded a LOT of activities on the list of things I crave (not that activity, but CLOSE!). So, coffee is what keeps me going now more than in grad school, more than living in Milan, more than a long night (or week) of partying. Liam and I are now experts on the coffee scene of Potrero Hill. 

And Farley's is one of our favorites. The customers are extremely friendly and varied--lots of people "between jobs" who are probably updating their Facebook status more than their resume, scruffy dog-lovers in clogs, newspaper readers, and then a whole clan of dark-circled breeders like myself, wearing their little love bundles in Ergo carriers for fear that if the babies weren't attached to us, we'd be so zombified we'd forget them somewhere. 

The cappuccino breves are life-savingly hot and the foam is perfect. It's like they know I have been looking forward to this beverage since my little Liam wake up call at 5 am. The atmosphere is comfortable and kid-friendly, though the staff are kind of surly for folks who get to tank up on free caffeine all day. The huge magazine selection is fun. This is also my go-to spot for coffee-loving out of towners. All I can say is Thank You Farley's for keeping my batteries charged. I promise not to sue you when my child turns out to be ADD b/c I nursed him with cappuccino-laced milk.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
I've lived in Potrero Hill for four years and Farley's used to be my standard coffee shop, but La Stazione has replaced it because the Ritual coffee is better (than the previous roaster used by Farley's).  Even so, until earlier this year, I was still regularly going to Farley's because it was a great place for work for a few hours while drinking coffee and eating a pastry or two, but the new Farley's is terrible for that.  The new (old) "hipster" tables are uncomfortable to use, random heights, and the chairs are even worse.  The old Farley's had comfortable seats that I could sit in for more than five minutes.  The new random seats are a bloody joke.

Honestly, I haven't tasted the new coffee enough to have an opinion on it because I don't like coming here much nowadays.

Seriously, I think I might go to Starbucks or Whole Foods next time I want to work an hour or two without feeling like an ass.  It is that bad now.

They still get three stars because the service is pretty good and the pastries are still excellent (I highly recommend the pumpkin cake with chocolate chips).  I have a feeling the new owner will change the pastries too, though.
author: Daniel Q.

description:
Ok, I get the Farley's shtick: cantankerous coffee "experts" pull top-notch shots without any BS.

But when I stopped in for a cup early this morning, all I got was a rude coffee dude who made me a cappuccino that was really a latte. 

Message to Farley's: stop by Four Barrel or Ritual if you want to taste a high-quality beverage. And, hey coffee guy, SMILES don't cost a dime!
author: Mr G.

description:
Might as well face it, I'm addicted to Farley's.

I mean sure, there's caffeine in the beverages, and I'm addicted to that too -- but I find myself here as often as I possibly can, so at this point I think it's about more than just chemical dependence.  

My checklist of requirements for a coffeeshop to be considered good is long and exacting, and Farley's pretty much checks them all.  It needs to be within walking distance of my house.  There needs to be kitsch on the walls, but not too much kitsch.  The baristas need to be friendly, but not BFF's.  The furniture needs to be well-used, but not ghetto.  And so goes my well-checked list.  And you can't argue with lists.

So if you choose to pop into this place, look around; there's a 40% chance I'm sitting in the corner booth with black coffee and a bagel from Hazel's next door, nursing all my addictions.
author: Shawn A.

description:
Way back when I lived in the Lower Haight ('91), I used to come all the way out here for giant cups of coffee and the community journals. When I published my first zine ('93), Farley's was the first place to buy a few copies and put them on their magazine rack.

This has always been a great cafe with a truly neighborhood feel.
author: Jaina D.

description:
Customer in front of me (CIFM): Hi, um, how fluffy are your croissants per say?

Coffee guy: (chuckles) You're f*cking kidding me right?

CIFM: No. 

Coffee guy: I don't f*cking know. Buy one and find out!

Pros: I like the shelves of magazines, selection of teas and overall atmosphere.

Cons: Internet connection sucked, the people working the counter were in no particular hurry to fill orders and they didn't accept credit cards.
author: Stephanie J.

description:
No complaints, great location, good internet, good music (classical or classic rock/new wavey, depending on who's behind counter).  Great scones, you can bring in sandwiches from hazel's next door.  Great magazine selection.  I love it

I've heard people comment on the coffee that it's not like the nuclear 20W50 you get at Peet's or Philz.  It isn't, it's good but not viscous/super dark roast. Jes so you know
author: Gene T.

description: Had great ginger tea here and hungarian coffee cake. Coffee here is always great. Awesome magazine selection that you can browse before you buy, or can just browse, dont have to buy at all. Great vibe here. free wifi.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I am a cafe squatter - Farley's has really good coffee, free WiFi and Hazel's next store for an egg bagel or big-a** sammie.

Minus one star for no real size "large" coffee cups and only two hours of free WiFi access. Like I said, I bring my biz to the streets.
author: Cinnamon F.

description: Great lattes, good tea, lots of reading material. A very cute (in a trendy/cool way) neighborhood hang.
author: Olivia P.

description:
Pastries are not so good. Croissants often taste like Wonder Bread inside. Their pastry supplier should be ashamed. Luckily they let you bring in food from the mediocre sandwich/bagel place next door.

Farley's runs a little cold. Every time I'm there, they burn an english muffin. The coffee grinder is loud which can interrupt conversation. But in Potrero, there aren't many hang-out spots with as much of a local feel. You'll definitely run into your neighbors here.

Farley's get the award for top wood floor to pass out on, since it seems likes crumbling/rotting out from under your feet.
author: Ana D.

description: This place has a cool old-school vibe, with books and games and a spacious interior that isn't trying too hard to do the hip coffee shop thing. The coffee was pretty good and fairly inexpensive, but I was disappointed by my tasteless scone. However, the baristas were cute, so that was nice a good way to start my day at 7:30am!
author: Lauren S.

description: Pretension at least needs to be backed by skill. This place has oodles of the former and seems particularly lacking in the latter. If I ever want over roasted beans and scalded milk with a side of back talk, I guess I know where to go next time.
author: Ryan D.

description: Since the bakery nearby sucks, I get mocha here sometimes to satisfy my sweet tooth. It's good. Nice tea selection too. And if I were a coffee shop nerd (no disrespect), I'd probably hang out here. The vibe definitely reflects the motto: community in a cup.
author: Bethany M.

description: I saw previous reviews saying the staff is rude and didn't believe it.  Now I get it.  They aren't outwardly rude but somehow send strong weird signals of snootiness.
author: Chris W.

description:
Great coffee, free refill.

No better way to kick back on a sunny day: grab an outdoor table, gab with your friends, and drink the delicious coffee that Farley's cranks out.

Before you know it, you'll be buying a Farley's T-Shirt to show off the caffeine molecule printed on it.

If you want food, Hazels next door has great sandwiches.
author: Rudy R.

description: Great place to get a cup of Joe and sit and do work.  I noticed today they had board games to choose from, a touch i thought was nice.  I think the coffee is pretty good and I'd say the only downside is that it is cash only.  But aside from that, when i find myself in Potrero is a nice coffee shop to visit.
author: Kirsten M.

description: Probably some of the most rude and inhospitable cashiers and baristas in the City.  You're better off going Starbucks, McDonalds or 7-11.  Skip it.
author: Bill G.

description:
I think that people who diss on Farley's because of the (sometimes) tude, or the fact they don't offer every type of milk, well. . .just don't get it.   Great cafe's are not about dbl tall this or no skim half caf etc etc. . .or displaying "design excellence" awards. . .ahem ccough cough. . .

I've been a Farley's customer since I moved to SF (I was 20 I'm now 14 added to that), and I know what to expect when I visit Farley's.

I expect to get a fabulous and decadent whole milk coffee drink.  Yum.  I expect to linger in a place that has nice windows that open to a sidewalk where tons of regulars hang out for hours on the weekend.  I expect to hear good music while I enjoy my coffee or my company or my magazine (excellent selection).

It's all good in the hood.
author: James M.

description: This is going to be unpopular review but, I have to be honest. I just moved to Potrero Hill and Farley's is my closest coffee shop. I am currently boycotting them. I have been in five or six times and only ONCE was I treated well and, that was by the manager. Every other time I've been in, I have been ignored, talked down to, or even mistreated. Also, I don't like the coffee and the cash only thing is annoying. There it is, for what it's worth.
author: Robert M.

description: I felt right at home here.  After a fun weekend of jogging and hiking, a latte and chocolate croissant made for the perfect Sunday morning breakfast.  Such a reward!  This place is energetic and great for people watching.  If you're not into people watching, there's plenty else to look at (the beautiful design in the crema of your latte, magazines, art work, flyers and business cards on the bulletin board).  I'm definitely going to make this a place I frequent.
author: Jen O.

description:
Super cute:  both the friendly staff, the actual space, and the other customers.  The coffee is good, and if you bring your own mug, you get a free refill!  Parking is pretty easy, too, for those of us that haul about 10 books with us everywhere we go.

Minus points:  very few plugs, only two hours of free wi-fi and there was a freaky girl staring at my friend and I the last time we were there.  Well, few places are perfect.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Awesome coffee, as a neighborhood local Potreo hills finest! Born and raised on the hill I was a mocha a day kinda guy. Now I'm a double espresso lover. Good short pull. Great service and good pastries! Looking for to my AM fix!
author: Sandro T.

description:
I'm torn about really liking this place. This is my local neighborhood coffee shop to hit when I have friends around who want to chill with good coffee. The people are interesting, there is always seating and the coffee is usually pretty good.

The staff however is 70% mellow and inviting, then 30% uninviting and literally gives you negative looks if they don't want you there. 

Yes, they close at 10pm and we got there at 9:15pm. We left immediately before the clock hit 10pm. There was one or two other customers sitting there before us, while more funneled in and out after us throughout the 45 minutes we were there. We were not even close to being the last people. 

We don't appreciate grumpy looks and attitudes for wanting a cup of coffee at 9:15pm when you don't close till 10pm. If you don't want people to come in, then don't be open. Change the hours. Lock the doors.

Aside from that one night experience, my daytime experiences have been quite pleasing. I don't need any fake smiles or welcomes at a coffee shop. I just want to feel comfortable and not have to make excuses for, at times, rude staff.

I'm a supporter of this independent coffee house. I feel they can improve a bit with the customer service. At least have a relaxed feel, instead of a grumpy, don't you dare walk in here and order an espresso drink feel.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
Great atmosphere, sans the staff.  I wish they were more friendly, or even not overtly rude here and then I could agree with all the "best coffee house in SF" raves.  But the fact remains that it is a great place to sit, drink coffee, and chill with friends.   I just prefer Chatz down the block because they treat me like a customer, not a bother.

UPDATE:  Just downgraded to one-star because this place could truly be the best coffee shop in town.  Instead I have consistently gotten some of the worst customer service of my life here.  "Community in a cup" is your motto, so act like it.   Indifferent service would be improvement.
author: Val U.

description:
pros:
Smallish tables but we got one quickly. Had a bench to sit at-a plus for my g-friend.
Had a power strip for our computers.
Fine coffee-pretty designs in the foam.
Cute v-day cards and sweethearts candy (did I say we went on valentine's day? well, we did)
Fabulous vegan chocolate chip cookie
pretty easy parking
kind baristas

cons:
we unexpectedly were there for a comedy show. it had funny moments but jokes were often homophobic, heterosexist, fat-phobic, racist, made fun of incest. but it was free.
author: Abi W.

description: Great mochas but really spicy chais. Finally found a place that knows how to foam the milk properly.  See pics.
author: Beatrice K.

description:
Why do I have the crappiest coffee place in the city closest to my house?  Why do people love this place?  
This place has so much potential, they really do, but have yet to discover it.
-Please put up something to catch the flies buzzing around
-Hire someone with a decorative eye to make the place feel cozy
-Lose the magazines
-Do not serve your cold beverages in a hot cup, also get a bigger cup, I got 3 drinks out of my iced tea since it was mostly cubes
-Hire some friendly people
Plus one star for the open mic and board games, though I have yet to do either because I don't get that comfy/hangout vibe
author: Sarah M.

description:
I don't get the people who are into this place.  It sucks. The coffee tastes like stronger-but-similarly-burnt-and-acidic midwestern coffee.  A staff that's no fun.  And always with the banging! Why are people who work there always banging on things?  Enough already.

I think people that live in Potrero convince themselves it's a great neighborhood joint so that they don't have to feel bad about living in the suburbs of Potrero while paying city prices for being squeezed between the freeway and some housing projects. Oohh, there's a coffee house. See honey, it's so urban! Let's take the dog for a walk!
author: John Z.

description:
I have been pretty generous with my "star" giving, but with Farley's...it's a different story.

I definitely think Farley's is way overrated...at least it's true in the more recent years. With some newbie coffee making and tea serving staff behind the counter who think they are too cool for school...specifically like "I have a moped and you don't, and my hands are dirtier than yours coz I pretend I know how to fix my moped and you don't, or I'm too good to serve you though I willingly chose to have a job at a cafe making and serving unimpressive lattes on a daily basis" attitude. Besides if you are really that cool, you don't have to PRETEND as such in order to overcompensate your insecurity. Get over yourselves already and serve me some subpar lattes with a half smile...I'll even tip you an extra $0.25 for that Kodak moment!

I have been coming here on and off for years and have seen rude/indifferent staff come and go but this latest batch really takes the cake! I remember it being more of a friendly neighborhood cafe with OK lattes and OK desserts with pretty good magazine selection minus the severe "better than thou" attitude...though it's all relatively speaking...the poser factor has definitely worsened now than ever. 

Perhaps is guilty pleasure or something, I still drop in every once in awhile if I'm in the neighborhood. I really need to remind myself to stop doing that.  

There are way too many local cafes that are much better and more worthy of my support than this so-called voted "Best Independent Coffeehouse in San Francisco". I wonder if the votes were rigged?? Hmm...

UPDATE as of 9/14/07: Apparently, the annoyingly rude batch of coffee makers (people NOT machines I was referring to) are no longer visible at Farley's lately and the new group of barristas have been quite pleasant and my lattes are actually tasting much better than before (it could be psychological or it could be not...but it's all good). So I'm upgrading them from two stars to three now. 

And if they keep up the good work/service...I'll have another update at a later date and may up one more star again in the future.
author: Jen L.

description: I am sitting in Farley's at this very moment. Although I am a fan of the coffee, I am definitely not a fan of the head banging music in the background. Not conducive to working.
author: Lindsay S.

description: This is really a 4.5star review. I really like this place and come here often. Coffee is great, little treats are good, friendly and quick service, free WiFi, some space to plop down and do some work, and an AMAZING lunch place nextdoor with delicious, home-made, reasonably-priced food. Neighborhoody feel.. some tables outside, including a parklet :) I just wish the accomodations were a little more comfy (chairs/tables/etc) and would match up with the feel of the interior a little better (thus minus half a star).
author: O K.

description:
I'd have to agree with a few of folks that have come before me here.  While I'm told Farley's is a Potrero landmark and must go for café style chillin' on a Sunday afternoon - the caretakers of the place seem a bit distracted and unimpressed with the lines of coffee goers before them.  I dunno, maybe is was a bad night, maybe they're pissed cause their alarm clock told them to get outta bed and go to work today like the rest of the world; who knows...

Dear Farley employees - ya'll need a hug?!
author: Derik P.

description: There's a really fantastic vibe here -- on sunny weekends you can catch people doing a brunch thing outside, but without all the fluff of the Valencia crowd; the magazines in the corner are wonderful, and of course the coffee + ice cream + baked goods = delicious combo. One of the lovelier spots in the city.
author: Anshu S.

description:
Farley's has won the SF Bay Guardian's 'Best Independent Coffeehouse' award for good reason. It's truly a community space and lives up to it's mantra of 'Community in a cup.' Whether it's the monthly art openings, music events, or 'little peoples day,' you can sense that this space truly is the heart of the hill. 

This magazine rack is stocked with great titles like Juxtapoz, Giant Robot, and Anthem - for the non-coffee drinkers like myself, they serve up a nice cup of hot apple cider.

If you watch the Charlize Theron / Keanu Reeves movie 'Sweet November' you might notice that Farley's makes a guest appearance. An interesting movie note - as part of the payment for use of the space, Roger worked it out so that the film makers paid for a day of free coffee for all. How's that for community?
author: Mike L.

description: I started to go here in 2000 when I moved here to SF, and worked down the hill for a dot com that had great people, but it was run by 2 dimwits. We, not including the 2 dimwits would venture up the hill for Hazels sandwiches and Farley's coffee. Farley's has a great feel with a great magazine selection, and they make one of the best mocha's in the area. I tried to enter my pet Panda "Ding Dong" in the annual Halloween pet parade and photobooth shoot, but he was too big, so..... Also, this is the coffee shop and street where the "classic" film "Sweet November" was filmed. They even have a shot in the movie of Farley's. I hope they make a make a sequel ??? I can't figure out what happened.
author: Mike C.

description:
Although I don't live in the neighborhood, I enjoy coming here after work or after a weekend motorcycle ride.  As mentioned elsewhere, the coffee is tops, especially their latte drinks.  

Also mentioned elsewhere is the indifferent attitude of the barristas, but having made espressos for a living during my youth, the guys & gals at Farley's are pretty easy going & friendly.  (I once told a hippie to "f---- off" when he wanted me to re-heat his latte, a latte he'd been sipping for over an hour.)

Sitting outside, it's fun to watch the local jocks at Bloom's Saloon across the street shout & swear as the 49ers fumble yet another pass, while munching on an excellent sandwich from Hazel's, located right next door. 

The magazine rack at Farley's is both middle-of-the-road and eclectic, but -- alas -- they don't stock Penthouse Forum.
author: Paul D.

description:
The coffee buzzed in at only 3 or 4 stars for me---- nothing to rave about back home (where is home anymore? i don't know...). 

The place lost stars for me on the snobby attitude of the baristas... they don't even know me, yet I felt so Judged. I nearly felt like I was in Chelsea again....hmph. Their location is prime, their space is generous, and yet it doesn't feel comfy. Someone needs to add some spice to their walls and some sugar to their dispositions.
author: Mo S.

description:
Every time I come here, I feel like I'm on a movie set. That is, it seems like everyone who is here is carefully chosen to be in a particular place or dressed a particular way...maybe it's the way that the light from the sun hits the place, but that's just an observation.

Anyways, great spot to kick it, meet up with a friend or hang out. Coffee's coffee, what can I say, and mags are good to go. Nice selection. The joint is laid out pretty neat with a lot of space so you don't feel like you're up in someone's business. I wish i lived closer so I can make this place my morning routine!
author: Charlene L.

description:
OK, what's up with the attitude damn it, I just want some freakin' coffee.   I think you have to get fired from DMV to work here or maybe this is a half-way house for people quiting smoking, but the employees here just have a 'real attitude'.  Cheer up for gawdsakes, I have seen happier people on death row.

Coffee is great, but if you want a large - you will have to buy two cups and feel like some addicted looser; they only have one size.  

Really nice place to just hang and check out the Po Hill scene.
author: H D.

description:
Cute place I guess but seriously, getting a cup of coffee takes SOOOOO long.  I only order black coffee, nothing fancy.  But every time I walk in to get coffee, it takes about 15-20 mins, and there's usually just a couple people ahead of me.  Yea yea, this isn't starbucks and it's not meant to be.  It just reminds of the kind of place that looks down on anyone who isn't casually strolling in with a dog in tow and the sf chronicle in hand chatting with others about global warming.

coffee is ok but nothing to wait so long for
author: peter k.

description: Great cappuccino; cool art ; and a cool magazine selection.  Fun sitting outside chatting with the neighborhood and petting their dogs.   Has a lot of games to play.
author: April M.

description:
I expected so much more from this place, and yet I was so disappointed. 

Staff were two of the rudest people I have ever dealt with. I'm no prima donna, but don't just STARE AT ME while expecting that I can read your mind and know automatically what you're trying to ask. Oh, what size? Wow... two whole syllables that would have taken .045 of a second to spit out, and you couldn't even DO IT. Small here apparently = one sip of coffee. An overpriced sip of coffee.

My iced coffee wasn't the blended goodness I am accustomed to. They threw in some ice cubes to cool off that one sip of coffee. Which wasn't even that tasty. 

I don't see how this could be such a "cool neighborhood place". All I wanted to go was leave as soon as possible. I felt totally unwelcome, and the flies swirling all around didn't help the ambiance either. Board games were missing some pieces. The photo albums seemed to convey a totally different atmosphere, like it used to be completely different...

Are there any people that work here who are, you know, NICE? Where are they hanging out at? Maybe they got lost in the scraggly hair and beards of the two assholes who were so rude to me and my girl.
author: Angie B.

description: Really good coffee and ambiance. They have a bunch of games too (board games) lying around for you to play if you are waiting for someone.
author: Shubhi T.

description: I like Farley's because it reminds me of a Seattle coffeehouse. I also LOVE that they have magazines. so hard to find a newsstand nowadays!
author: J R.

description:
Walking into Farley's is like walking into some kind of weird sitcom -- hipster Cheers meets Empire Records.
 
I get it, I get it.  You only sell your coffee in 12 oz. cups.  You don't have skim milk.  You listen to Blondie and wear uber tight jeans.  

The coffee itself is mediocre.  I'd rather go to Blue Bottle where they have the product to back up their whole "too cool for school" thing.  On the other hand, if you don't find yourself exasperated by frumpy hipsters, they do have a decent selection of free magazines to read while you sip all 12 ounces of that whole milk latte.
author: Abby M.

description:
My mom is Dutch and she knows three things, coffee, chocolate and cheese. Farley's let her down on two accounts. She ordered a latte and found it weak although topped by an exquiste latte arte de crema. She got a refill of regular coffee and couldn't finish it it was so phoo phoo. Her chocolate macaroon was provided by a 3P (I think) but it was also gummy and fatty. 

I loved their wide tea selection and enjoyed the big cup of it, but found my scone to be sort of a Costco version. My stepmom's homemade should be on the market. 

The crowd is worth it all, dipping into every age group and sub culture, all hovering around chitty chatty and sharing papers. The WIFI was drawing in the regular eye poppers. They have a album collection and regularly play vinyl, according to our server. 

I like the neighborhood feel, and the big size with local art on the wall. Saw folks I would want to befriend, but can't rave about the actual fare....
author: Miel H.

description:
Farley's is great. Often my travels take me to this neighborhood and I always make sure to stop by Farley's. The sandwiches are great, the staff is attentive and helpful, and the magazine selection is awesome. Not to mention the fun people watching and the hot and good coffee. 
They also have fun board games and usually have cool art on the walls.
author: Sam R.

description:
Farley's is a pretty charming little coffeehouse. I went on a quiet Sunday morning. Seems that Portrero Hill is a great place to go on sunny weekends-- there are great 360 views. Farley's has a cute window front and little outdoor tables which makes it very pleasant on the good weather days. Not too much sidewalk traffic when I was there--- but then again I didn't see much life outside of Farley's (this was 11am-1pm on a Sunday)

1 star reduction for a cold server. I ordered a pot of Jasmin tea and the guy behind the counter was pretty unfriendly. My tea water was actually lukewarm, not in anyway hot. Only the first cup was at a somewhat appropriate temperature. It felt like such a waste of Jasmin pearls to not make many more cups. But on account of the server's attitude I didn't want to ask for new water. 

Seems like another great SF cafe. But it's the type of place where old newspapers are left behind and the tables get bussed but not wiped down. Chairs are unevenly placed and tables are turned weird ways based on the last person who sat there. This definitely makes it feel like a more neighborhood place but not as "put together" as others. Had only a few tables big enough for working/studying, and many little round ones for 1-2 people.

The strawberry scone I had was delicious! And the music (vinyl) was really great.

Not sure what's up with the magazine rack--- are they for reading while you're there or to buy? Seemed like a news-stand where you're expected to buy them...
author: Britt A.

description: I'm not a coffee drinker - I'm giving this place 4 stars for the atmosphere. Bright, relaxed environment with cool people, including the staff who seems consistently cheery, even first thing in the morning.
author: Bob G.

description:
I Went there with a buddy to meet a friend of ours & found a copy of "Tuesdays with Morrie" right outside. I went in & enjoyed an iced coffee with a delicious sandwich from Hazel's next door, listened to an hour of Pavement (to the barista responsible for the music: You're a CHAMP), read a few chapters of 'Morrie', & plotted on how to write a comparable book (it was billed on the cover as "the runaway bestseller that changed thousands of lives) which RUINS thousands of lives. 

I've gotta say -- there was no better atmosphere to plot the demise of thousands of people. If you're working on a manifesto of some kind, Farley's is your place.
author: Pete J.

description:
On Portrero Hill I moved in with a clinical pack rat.  The den was full of magazines from as far back as the Vietnam era, old Mac computers, and VCR's in various states of disarray.  The backyard was literally a junk yard piled 10ft tall w rows to walk between.

I told myself that as long as MY room was OK for my stuff, I could take it... after all, nothing could be as bad as that hooker in San Diego, but that's another story.

After a couple of weeks, I found myself needing to be away from the place more and more.  Farley's was up the street and across from a laundromat... perfect.  

I gotta agree, the little snots staffing the place get somewhat annoying, but the coffee is good, and at some point you develop an I-don't-give-flying-f*** attitude toward the help.  Well, it was either that or go back to my place... and my jeans take forty minutes to dry.

Now that I'm not captive on the Hill, you'd think I'd be less tolerant of the 'shagtastiks', but I guess its like the a mild rash, after some itchiness and discomfort, it goes away.
author: Gilberto Y.

description:
Because of their little "one size, one milk" mantra, or whatever it is, Farley's failed to get my business. 

There's no need for all that half caf, no foam, no whip, three pump, extra hot double venti machiato gibberish, I agree...that I understand perfectly. But offering two or three different sized drinks, as well as at least one lower fat milk option? I really don't think that's too much to ask.

I have great respect for the "coffee purist" school of thought, and I don't mind having the basics, or even just more limited options, when it comes to coffee & espresso drinks. But the selection at Farley's is just a little bit too basic. Hey, at least they offer soy milk, so one extra star for that. 

I think I understand what they're trying to go for, but seriously, health-wise, this just isn't a real sound business model. Not everyone is down for soy milk. What about people who have high cholesterol? Who are trying to stay on low fat diets? Who are at risk for heart disease? Who have lactose issues? I know that I, personally, fall into one or more of those categories! So I walked down the street to Chat's, and they hooked me up with a nice small low fat latte...see, nothing fancy, nothing wacky...just a few specifics that Farley's doesn't happen to offer their customers.
author: Shannon R.

description: A long time hill resident and Farleys' customer, I have finally decided I am done. There are positive things:, the location and the magazine selection. The coffee is no longer to my taste, its now that bitter taste that seems to permeate a lot of coffee shops around the city. But, service and the lack of a good cappuccino are ultimately what drives me away. A cappuccino, is not hot milk, especially if you ask for it specifically foamy. Although some servers are polite and helpful when you complain (nicely, I may add), others let you know of their irritation and still don't seem to know what a cappuccino entails.  Take a lesson from Martha's in efficiency and pleasantness and Philz for the non bitter taste.
author: Anne C.

description: I love that all the baristas here are hot. I love how they steam their milk. I love all the magazines and that they let dogs hang out inside. I love Farley's.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
My dream coffee house. 

The selection of mainstream to special interest magazine selection is a huge plus. Any coffeehouse with "Adbuster" and "The New Yorker" gets a plus in my book. 

I adore their tea selection. The tea can be served in a refillable pot which makes it convenient for group setting. The chai latte is creamy and spicy, how yum!

I like the outdoor seating- especially if you can get food from Hazel's kitchen. I can create new flavors- keemun tea plus vegetarian quesadilla.
author: Jack C.

description:
Initially, I enjoyed my experience here but as I've tried it more and more I've grown to like it less and less. The mochas and hot chocolates always arrive beautifully with the characteristic foam flower on the surface. However, it has consistently been too sweet before sweetening--and I have a sweet tooth. So that's saying a lot. 

Additionally, the atmosphere always seems a bit loud. I think it has something to do with the high ceilings, squealing coffee machines, and close seating arrangements. I've heard a number of the workers use expletives while on the job...and I'm not a huge prude but if I wanted to hear this I would watch Weeds.

The internet times out every two hours and will kick you off the wifi. After that you must pay for it.
author: Jacq H.

description: I love it. Blow that extra $2 your absolutely delish no bulls**it latte saved you on  the fancy inspiring mags you never find anywhere else in a spot this chill.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Being new to the neighborhood, I'm so happy I live here, so happy Farley's is close by. Fantastic mochas, great standard coffee, cool magazine selection and great music. As another person mentioned, the outdoor seating is great. Farley's makes me proud to live in such a great neighborhood.

Coffee shop heaven, essentially.
author: Jono K.

description: I've only been here once but I really like the park-lett they have outside and the hot chocolate was supreme!
author: Y S.

description:
I don't drink coffee, and I've never had Farley's, but I can appreciate Farley's in other ways.  

First, I live across the street from it, and it provides plenty of opportunity for me to people watch or even spy on the occasional patron.  Yes, I spotted a patron I've known and called someone to give them a play-by-play of the patron's coffee drinking - what's wrong with that?  

Second, when I have gone into Farley's, it doesn't smell too much like coffee, which is a smell that makes me gag.  That means I can study or work there if I ever wanted to move a couple of yards away from my house.  

Last, they hold the Pet Parade, and if you don't know what this is, then you are missing out.  Animals dressing in costumes is not as cruel as it sounds, especially when it's so cute!
author: Kim S.

description:
After four years of living two blocks from Farley's, I've come to the conclusion that I don't hate it.

It exists, which is more than I can say about a number of coffeeshops in Potrero that have never existed at all, and thus could not ever have brewed coffee for me. That's good.

On the other hand, the pursuit of mediocrity should not really be celebrated in a city like San Francisco, where even the roach coach taco stands can occasionally serve up something sublime. Farley's has never done anything more than make a kind of aiight coffee drink.

So I don't hate it. It's good for an emergency coffee-based beverage. But spending time in there is not even vaguely an option. It's boring, and when they try to spice it up, it's always with terrible art. My favorite was when they had an illustration of a KKK member hanging from a tree. That's a real pick-me-up. Nothing like a quick blend of violence and racism with my latte.
author: jason l.

description: I had a very delicious soy mocha here - not too sweet. I like the ambiance and decor of the place as well. I'd come here again
author: Shivani S.

description:
Definitely a place with character.
Just went there my first time and I really like the crowd and the atmosphere.  If only they'd turn down the Michael Jackson a bit...
author: Peter O.

description:
Overrated.
Coffee, good, strong, and really not worth going out of my way to get.
-
I would rather not ever, ever return.
author: Liz L.

description: I too, like the previous reviewer, live around the corner from Farley's. Though I love the vibe, magazines, games and coffee, it makes me sad that the staff is so rude. I never feel welcome - a feeling you definitely should feel when you step into your local coffee shop. Hope they take care of that soon, or else they'll start losing customers to Thinkers Cafe and Chatz.
author: Mel C.

description:
An almost perfect neighborhood coffee shop. While there are more than a few to chose from, Farley's is definitely the standard. It can come across as a bit artsy-elitist at times, however, so here are some pointers:

To be cool at Farley's: Grow some facial hair. Mumble a bit when you order. Pay with exact change but throw an extra buck in the tip jar anyway. Wear a shirt with Che Guevara or some other figure on it who you think is cool without fully understanding why. If you have to make any phone calls, do it using the pay phone down the street.

To be uncool at Farley's: Order a "venti" of your usual Starbuck's fav. Ask if you can pay with AmEx, when they tell you no, pay with nothing smaller than a Jackson and then don't tip with any of the abundant change you just received. Wear something to show off your favorite designer logos. Use your cell phone to call up your friends in the East Bay to tell them about this cute neighborhood coffee shop you found in the city. They'll love you.
author: C P.

description:
i should be paying rent for the amount of time i spend here, so i'm not sure i'm technically allowed to review it.  but.

it's the best.  the best people come here, the best people work here.  i spend many weekdays happily existing here, sipping on fresh orange juice, downing delicious lattes, munching on the tastiest morning buns, stealing sandwiches, eavesdropping, people-watching, barista-oggling.  you know.  living the best-possible life of a sometime writer (and mostly under-employed graduate student).

it's clear that some people don't "get" farley's.  these people write snide one-star reviews and don't come back.  i find this weeding-out process to be a source of great relief.  entitled san franciscans are a source of annoyance all over this blessed city, and thankfully, they spend very little time here.  that's part of what makes this place so f-ing great.

high on the happy times and good coffee, low on the lame folk.  A+
author: Melody D.

description:
I live a block down from Farleys, and I am happy that it is there when I get the urge to get out of my flat yet not go on some major waiting-for-MUNI-too-long journey in the city. 

I'm not a coffee person at all, so I usually go for steamed milk with almond and vanilla flavorings or good 'ole hot chocolate. Farleys has no problem with these lightweight drinks.

The magazines available provide a decent reading selection - but I think this is more of a social place than a sit down and read by yourself coffee house. 

I believe this place was shown in that Potrero Hill filmed movie Sweet November (Keanu Reeves and Charlize Theron). Love the neighborhood - plan on renting here until I can afford to buy a place somewhere around the Bay (20 years from now maybe? grin)
author: Jamie W.

description:
When I was thinking about moving to Potrero Hill, part of my motivation was that I'd be able to go to Farley's on a regular basis.  Not necessarily my favorite coffee in the city*, but this is most certainly my favorite place to DRINK coffee in the city. A true neighborhood coffeehouse; everyone here seems to know each other.  They also have a good selection of board games and old paperbacks,  and a good magazine rack that pretty much obviates the need for a decent neighborhood newsstand.

*Don't get me wrong, the coffee is excellent.  But I couldn't possibly say with a straight face that anything surpasses Blue Bottle.
author: Andrew E.

description:
I really love Farley's. I've never had their coffee--only tea and goodies--but the atmosphere is wonderful (very hip small town if that makes sense) and they have a stellar magazine selection. 

They don't have sandwiches, but there's a cute place next door (emphasis on cute) and they let you eat at Farley's. See what I mean about small town? Nice and friendly like...
author: Arwen O.

description:
The coffee's fine, the atmosphere's casual and relaxing, but the staff are really unfriendly. Every time I have to interact with someone at the register, I walk away wondering what I could have possibly done to annoy them so.

There are better places to get coffee in SF without the attitude.
author: Jerry R.

description:
Don't order cold drinks.  Iced coffee?  They charge an extra $.25 for the ice and serve it in a regular (small) hot beverage cup.  So you're actually paying extra for less coffee.  And this isn't unique to the coffee.  Lemonade, too, is served in the small hot beverage cups.  Call me American, but when I pay $2.25 for a lemonade, I expect to get more.  

Also, staff seemed visibly annoyed that I brought a stroller into the shop.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Very nice coffeeshop in Potrero Hill! Love the location. If you walk one block up you have a great skyline view. Veeery good coffee with thick milk foam on top. Great magazine selection! And nice outdoor seating!
author: Katja J.

description:
Here's the thing, I just moved here from Southern California so I'm still adjusting to the vibe here. I get that Farley's is a neighborhood institution and all that but the few times I've been there the staff is just so freakin salty. I don't get it! 

They do make a great cafe au lait and they have an o.k. selection of sweets.
author: Abby P.

description:
I agree that the service is a little unfriendly and cold.  In the couple dozen times I've been there, I've seen maybe one smile (acceptable for the east coast, not so much the bay area).

That being said, they are all business and get you a good cup of coffee, stat in time to make the CalTrain.
author: Alex D.

description: Thank you Farley's!  Today is the first day of 2012 and you are open, serving some really fine coffee.  I was in the neighborhood this morning, wanted something other than St.......ks and remembered your great little place for locals and former locals (me).  My americano was so, so tasty and served at just the right temperature.   I highly recommend this place.  Give it a try.
author: Sandra S.

description: I went to Farley s for the first time since the new ownership. The staff were just as I remember, nice and friendly. I used to go to Farley s and order a coffee, and it was fine. Today, I literally almost spat out the coffee on my first sip. The new coffee is disgusting!!! It tasted like a solution of coffee, wood chips, and a whole lot of water. They charge $2 for this crap!!! I ve talked to others, and they are also angry about this new disgusting coffee! Do not go here! Even Starbucks has better coffee!
author: Leo P.

description: I had a nice soy latte while waiting for a table at Plow.  I enjoyed being able to read the magazines they have for sale.  As mentioned by other reviewers, service was whatever but I'm sure I'll be back since it's close to my sister's place.
author: Seong P.

description: Excellent Coffee, carrot cake, toast, games, you name it.
author: Michael R.

description:
I'm not a huge coffee drinker, so these four stars are for the dazzling hot chocolate and presentation. And the fact that they are very pro fair trade beans.

The baristas are a little standoffish, and too hip/busy to really look at little old me and my clearly non coffee drinking face, but I was really dazzled by their hot chocolate. I watched them mix hot water and thick spoonfuls of powdered chocolate together in a giant mug, mix more water and chocolate, and then add in steamed milk and make a dazzling leaf pattern. All for $2!! You can't beat that!

The vibe is very laid back, the cafe is not crowded (at least, on a lazy Sunday afternoon) and you can sit outside in the sunshine and enjoy your yummy drink. Lovely!
author: Katherine P.

description:
Perhaps i don't really fit in in my new neighborhood because I seem to be the only "local" who doesn't LOVE this place.

The coffee is generally pretty good but they only have one smallish size, and the milk selection is laughable.  My dream coffee shop is one that offers heavy cream rather than Half and Half but I've yet to find that.

On the plus size, it's spacious....plenty of room to relax and their magazine selection is immense...but since i've got a half dozen subscriptions already that I can barely keep up with, that does little to nothing for me.

Staff is indifferent at best (perhaps because I'm not a regular...they KNOW I go to Thinkers) and no wifi, which pretty much kills my coffee house experience.

A great place to lounge at all day with a black beret and a beat up copy of On The Road or the collected works of Marcel Proust.
author: Jay W.

description:
With over 300 magazines, the best cappuccino in SF (per my best friend who just moved here from New York), super cute tables, lots of pastries and snacks, and tons of coffee and tea options, how can you really go wrong?  

Perfect neighborhood spot to catch up with a friend, do work, homework, relax, people watch or do whatever you feel like.  Staff is nice also, and when in here, I felt like everyone around me was super content and relaxed.  There were 2 women working on a presentation on a laptop, a student doing homework, 2 guy reading, 1 guy writing, and 1 girl just people watching, and several other pairs of people just hanging out and relaxing.  

The only reason it didn't get 5 stars is because I'm so spoiled by the conformity of every single Starbucks location, when I got here, I didn't know what to order.  I was confused for a bit.  I know that reflects on how sad it is that if I'm not in a Starbucks, I don't know what coffee or tea I like.  Regardless once I had a minute to sit with the menu, I figured it out.  

If I lived in the area, this would be my go to spot.
author: Denise B.

description:
Now that my boyfriend keeps me locked far away from the bars, in a gimp closet somewhere in the vicinity of Mariposa street, I do not suffer from hangover induced panic attacks every day.  This allows me to drink coffee without feeling like I'm going to crawl out of my skin and run screaming down the street.  I'm not really sure that's a fair trade, but whatever.

This place really does feel homey to me.  Even when the barista whom I like to refer to as "Butchie" waits on me.  If the look on her face is any indication, she hates pretty much everything about my existence.  But it's refreshing!  Usually I'm the one doing the hating!  Finally, a coffee shop that understands MY needs.  I have never instantly hated anyone I have seen in here, and that is truly an accomplishment.  

In addition, you can sit here for ever and evers drinking free refills and reading fun magazines from their extensive selection of periodicals for sale and listening to some old blues or something.  I like it so much here that it makes me sad to return to my beloved gimp closet!
author: Coco D.

description:
Their coffee is delicious: smooth and round. Dunno if those are appropriate coffee descriptions, but I *always* add boatloads of cream (wherever I am...must have been a milkmaid in a previous life) and love it. 

It seems there are a lot of negative reviews regarding the staff, but isn't that typical of any coffee shop? 

Try a dirt-bomb...it's some sort of cinnamon 'n sugar donut-muffin. Yummers.
author: Elle N M.

description:
Good Coffee -- Remarkably unpleasant staff.

The coffee at this place is very good but you really need to brace yourself for the people behind the counter.  Rude, unpleasant and lots of attitude.  It has become a joke among some of my friends to see if anyone get them to engage or at least be nice.    All unsuccessful so far.... Oh well.  Get your coffee and get out....
author: Larry W.

description:
If you haven't been here, you're missing out. 

Any chance I get, I make an attempt to stop here. The coffee is the best in the city, but you need to understand the simple rules: one cup, one milk. 

I used to stop here everyday on the way work, but alas I moved out of the neighborhood.  I miss the slightly surly staff, and browsing the magazines while waiting for my coffee. I also miss what I consider the perfect latte.
author: Geoffrey P.

description: This coffee shop rocks.  Great place to meet a friend for a chat or get some work done, whatever my mood that day.  I like the eclectic mix of people and music, and often use this as my "office" away from home.
author: Kristine Kris C.

description: I live around the corner and I really want to like Farley's - its cute, its close, it hosts local art. But the slow service and rude/dont care attitude of its baristas is too much. I keep trying it periodically hoping for a staff change (or a attitude change in the staff) - nope, not yet. Its too bad.
author: April E.

description: I have mix feelings about Farley's. It's a neighboor institution and has charisma, but it's not that comfortable and the service is very slow, we've ordered 2 patted and after 20 minutes we are still waiting. So charm yes but good, effective service would also be apreciated
author: Alex A.

description: The coffee is great, lots of seats and regulars and laptops.  There's a nice new parket outside too.  Ironic t-shirts and piercings are mandatory.
author: Dave B.

description:
Ha - I love that someone else has run into the tall, skinny, unkempt dickhead who works here who doesn't speak to you, and just waits and/or points.  Shove it, hipster, and go take a frickin shower.  You're giving the rest of your generally lovely and capable co-workers a bad name, and you clearly are too stupid to do a basic service job with a modicum of ability.

In other news, I love this place.  The coffee is great, the soy lattes are delish, and the pastries are all really good and fresh.  And, they put the pics from the Halloween pet photo booth up all over the store - awesome!  So, put on your big-kid pants and accept that there's 1 size coffee, and 2 varieties of milk (fatty and soy), and come enjoy this great spot in my lovely neighborhood.
author: Shannon H.

description:
Only whole milk!?!   What coffee shop doesn't have at **least** 2 fat level options!?!   Please don't get pissy with me when I ask for non-fat and you don't have it.  I know you have to say it a zilllion times a day, but I'm only here periodically.

Okay.  I'll shut up and have soy.

And since I'm already blowing my diet, I'll have one of those yummy almond croissants.
author: Maria C.

description: Farley's is one of the best coffee shops in San Francisco, the coffee is great (not too strong...I'm not a Pete's fan) and the atmosphere is very relaxing.   Free WiFi and nice outdoor seating is a plus.   Dogs are always welcome at Farley's...I don't have a dog but I still like that idea!
author: Christy C.

description: Stop by for quick coffee after my brunch just half block away. It quite crowded, I couldn't find a seat.  Coffee was good but nothing special, cute little coffee place with a style.
author: christy l.

description: My coffee was good but I really like this place for it's laid back atmosphere, magazine rack, and board games.
author: Kevin M.

description: Not bad, everything here is organic, hence the price of a panini would cost you about 8 bucks. Its a small cute little shop which sitting in the front and outside. I ordered a hot panini turkey pesto. It was very good and also very healthy. I was hungry after 2 hours cause the sandwich was pretty small. Overall not a bad place to go especially, if you're a healthy eater.
author: Betty T.

description:
In the realm of neighborhood coffeehouses, I'd say this one definitely has a community-oriented feel. I enjoy it's super laid back atmosphere and consistent quality of coffee, which is pretty darn decent for my standards (and I am a harsh judge).

It really is a nice neighborhood hangout to do just about anything. Meeting a friend or two? Want to study or do some reading? Perhaps skim a few magazines? Your wifi at home is down (which is likely Comcast)? Farley's got your back.
author: Becky L.

description: Where else would one go on Potrero? Like a comfortable old pair of slippers, a nice place to sit and relax and read and eat and drink and just hang out. Nice.
author: William M.

description:
It is a really cute neighborhood joint. The reason why I didn't give it 5 stars because I actually didn't drink by coffee there. 

I got it to go but the Mocha I ordered was fantastic and the service was great.

As I ordered my drink I watched with envy all the people there enjoying their coffee and their magazines. (They have a huge selection of magazines for sale there). I did see a few people with their laptops, so I am assuming that they do have wifi, no?

I will definitely be back.
author: Christine S.

description: Had horrible and rude service from one of the people in the front (the Asian guy with long hair and tattoos).  I was asking him what one of the desserts they had in the display case and even though I described what I was talking about and pointed to it several times, he kept saying it was something else.  I had to repeat myself literally 3 times before he could answer me accurately.  Later I also asked him for their wifi password as I was sitting down since it didn't seem to be posted clearly anywhere, and he had the nerve to say, "It's posted on the front of the register."  Yeah, along with a thousand other signs and so small so as not to be clearly visible-why do you think I asked in the first place numnuts?  Oh yeah, and to top it off the dessert he gave me sucked and I think I might've gotten sick from it because I saw a fly roaming around in their dessert case.  Totally bad experience and I will NOT be back.
author: R Y.

description:
Nice Local Shop.  Good Coffee and Great atmosphere.

Good place to just unwind or pick-up a quick cup.
author: Capra C.

description: Grrrrrrr to the  mean people behind counter.   Then there is nice customers and good coffee. Then there is mean people behind the counter. Then there is the nice space, magazine selection and location. I boycotted this place for about two years because of the customer service...came back. Its even worse. I miss Kyp (who worked there years ago, now a musician who lives in Brooklyn) He was great. My heart sinks and really become sad for the owner. I have met him and he is such a nice guy. Why does he hire such jerks?
author: Jeff R.

description:
I'm not from the city (Campbell / SJ), but always drop by this cafe when I'm in this neighborhood. I was introduced to this place a few years ago and loved their coffee.  

Nice magazine rack as others have mentioned and a laid back crowd and baristas!

Last time I was there they had a small Jazz group playing...

* * * * *
author: Glenn O.

description:
Oh Farley's, you come so close to being the perfect coffee shop, but then you fall just a weensy bit short. You've got the cool ambiance, the wood floors, the fantastic magazine selection, the tasty coffee, and the decadent pastries. You've got the best people-watching in Potrero Hill. Why oh why don't you have wifi? This is why I usually go to Thinker's Cafe instead.

UPDATE: Farley's now has wifi! Rejoice!!
author: Melinda K.

description: Easily the best cup of coffee on Potrero Hill and good pastry, too. The downside?  Some serious attitude from the some of the staff.  Perhaps that is part of the charm of this place, but it would be nice if they were a bit friendlier.
author: Matthew C.

description: Very good coffee. Good place to hang out with a strong neighborhood feel. They've got free wifi which is a huge plus.
author: Gabe R.

description:
4 stars atmosphere. 3 coffee. 3.5 overall.
I love the atmosphere of this place. It's got the cool laid back Po'Hill vibe. The people are pretty unique. I remember one afternoon seeing a septuagenarian hitting on an innocent 20 something foreign exchange student from Bulgaria (?!) Kinda cute actually--
Anyway--the pastries are very good and the coffee so-so. I think you might have better luck with coffee earlier in the day and the espresso drinks usually are good all day long. Also, tea selection is good to ok.
author: Ms. P S.

description:
Love their motto. and the mugs that have the motto printed.
Good coffee
Great place, cozy on super hot or super cold days
Good coffee
and nice magazine stand.
Open late is a nice one too.
The windows are nice to sit inside or out.
Bike-parking friendly.

*BEANS: Mr. Espresso
author: ninja M.

description:
Love the neighborhood feel. I was there during the Halloween pet parade and saw the cutest little boy in an elephant costume. 
The best thing is to grab an americano and then head next door for a breakfast burrito. "Nothing says beunos dias like a breakfast burrito!"
Fun outdoor seating and tons of newspapers for your perusal.
author: Stacy T.

description:
i love farley's.  and after reading the yelp reviews, i'm sitting here laughing.  literally lol'ing.

let me just say this:  i walk 3 blocks, up a super annoying steep hill, right past another coffee place for their coffee.  and i do this more than once a day.  who gives a shit if the people behind the counter come off as not interested in being fake to you?  they might not actually give a shit about your day, do you care about theirs?  how is your coffee?  yea, it's damn good.  so shut the eff up if the hot grungy hipster guy didn't give you a smile, he rarely smiles at me either.
author: Emily T.

description:
Pretty fun cafe that's been the haunt in dog-patch for over 17 years.  Lots of tables where regulars read, write, or meet friends.

My favorite tidbit about Farley's- the notebooks.  There are these blank notebooks lying around, near the board games.  The notebooks are there to be written in, which is fun, and there to read, which is more fun- you can get a voyeuristic thrill as you read some mopey dude's meanderings about whether he should break up with his girlfriend or have your head spin in confusion as you try to decipher the poems written in Welsh.

Farley's only problem: the regulars have had enough time to spawn and now there are little kids running around Farley's on the weekends.  Not for the kid-phobic.
author: Brian D.

description:
There isn't much I can say about Farley's that hasn't already been said. A true neighborhood cafe where humans gather with their offspring and canine pals to sniff each others butts. Have it for here and get a free refill. Grab the latest Adbusters off the magazine shelf and marvel at how advertising subsidizes your life. With the $9 unsubsidized price tag you put it back knowing you can consume more the next visit. 

Stop by in the morning and you can get a cheap bagel with veggie fixings next door at Hazel's to have with your coffee. Or a sandwich during lunch, it's all ok for on-site consumption. Farley's and Hazel's have a symbiotic relationship much like the dogs that like to sniff butts.
author: Eddie C.

description:
One of my fav coffee shop in the city.
They do make good latte there although you don't have any choice of cup size or type of milk.  "One cup one milk" rule makes it easy for people to order.  (They only use whole milk.)

Service seems a bit slow at times depending on the number of customers waiting, but their latte is always good (with latte art on it - it's rare to see it in the city unlike Seattle), and it's worth waiting.
author: Yoko S.

description:
There's a Starbucks a block away from my place, but I still go to Farley's...on the way to work...or take a nice walk a few blocks away.  

It's has a great low key atmosphere to get juiced up...with coffee drink of choice.  I love the magazines that I get browse while waiting for my drink getting made.  :)
author: Julia H.

description:
Farley's is a good old friend.
It's a friend you don't have to think about, there when you need 'em.

Very low- maintenance, you go in, you get coffee.
There's no choice, there's no renaming small/medium/large and forcing you to use the names.
It's actually perfect to not have to answer a zillion question about your coffee before you've had your coffee.
Love the magazine, some thoughtful choices, love the rustic feel, love the music choice. PS. Coffee is good too.
author: Rhubarb M.

description:
Nice coffee.
Nice stickers.
Nice magazines.
Strange little bathroom upstairs.
author: dj z.

description:
Update 05/06/2008: I was just informed by 
someone that they are now offering non-fat and Soy milk, I haven't been in to try it yet...so we'll see..

__________________________________________________
I want to like these guys...I really do, mainly because their lattes actually taste like something I used to get in Seattle- BUT no non-fat milk? Whatwhatwhat? Who drinks whole milk anymore? 

ANYWHO- so far they've been the best I've found around here espresso-taste-wise, so...three stars...maybe three and a half....
Seriously? Only whole milk?
author: Ashly M.

description:
"hi, i think i left my bike helmet there yesterday afternoon."
"what color is it?"
"black."
"what brand?"

what brand? jeez, people. you either have the damb bike helmet or you don't...

despite this little bit of weirdness (i got my helmet back, btw) i really liked farleys. they have a couple tables outside, lots of mags, art on the walls, and a live jazz ensemble playing every now and then. and the friendly guys behind the counter even hooked me up with an extension cord for my laptop. nice! 

plus there's this one hot barista with tats and black glasses. mmm.
author: jean w.

description:
I've been having a trying week, for many reasons that I really don't feel like getting into right now, but this morning I *really* needed some GOOD COFFEE.  I've tried every coffee serving establishment on the SFSU campus in the last two months, and I am sorry to say - they all kinda suck.  Cafe Rosso comes pretty close but... really?  That's all you've got?

So, this morning Ryan recommended I just get something at Farley's... *the* place to go in the good ol' Po' Hill area.  I'm a little wary of them, to be honest, because last time we went there Ryan ordered a decaf latte and it just tasted burnt.  (Supposedly it has to do with the decaf beans, or something, but who cares?  It shouldn't taste burnt, I don't care if the beans are 'like that' or not)

Anyway.  I thought I'd give them another try, as I was feeling a bit desperate for a good coffee.

I waited in line.

I ordered and paid.

I waited.

And waited.

And waited.

And watched two people who ordered after me pick up their drinks.

At which point I finally went up to the counter and rather loudly asked when I was going to get my double latte.

At which point the cashier said, ohhhhhh someone else must have picked up yours, we had three double lattes in a row...  we have another one coming up though!

(No apology.)

Thankfully the second guy who stole my latte was still standing right there and gave me 'his' (my) double latte.

Let's just say it took 15 minutes for me to get my latte.

I am NOT PLEASED.

The only saving grace this morning, after waiting 15 minutes for a latte, plus sitting in an extra 15 minutes of traffic coming to work (because of construction) ....

The latte is damn good.

Sigh.  It would be so much easier to hate on them if it wasn't.

Regardless: This is strike two for Farley's in my book.
author: Hayley L.

description: Latte was OK but not very strong and not a lot of flavor.  The barista was a kind of rude one time I went, but for the most part people are nice.  The baristas do have a good music selection at least the couple times I have stayed to enjoy my coffee.
author: Justin F.

description: One of my favorite spots in Potrero Hill.  Laid back atmosphere, good drinks, and big tables.  It's the perfect place to meet up with a friend or get some work done.  And it's open until 10 PM every night.  My only complaints: they often leave the front door open, so it gets cold and drafty, and there are often random, noisy things happening there on Sunday nights (things like neighborhood concerts and changes in their artwork--not bad in and of themselves, but annoying if you go in order to read a book).
author: Parker B.

description:
I love the simplicity and laid back atmosphere of Farley's. Especially with the recent warm weather, I take a visit to Farley's on weekends with my dog. I order an iced coffee and read outside with cafe with my dog for a couple of hours. And because dogs are regulars at this cafe, they often put out a nice big, bowl of water - or if it's not out, you can always ask for it. The staff's great, and the order's quick with the low maintenance menu that I definitely prefer. 

And if you're not prepared with a book or without company, you can always buy a magazine - they have an impressive spread of options.
author: Joyce S.

description:
Other than the "I'm too cool to be friendly" element that some of the hipster staff exhibits to those of us not rolling in off of our skateboards, this place ROCKS.  

The coffee is delicioso, and the free wi-fi and abundant outlet space has made this place my newest home away from home.  The overflowing magazine rack is also the perfect diversion from actually getting work done.  But, my productivity is saved by the tasteful selection of music and the mild din that suffuses this place, providing just the right atmosphere for my intellectual juices to percolate.  

As a member of the work-from-home crew that haunts Bay Area coffeehouses, I am proud to have hung my temporary shingle at Farley's.    Even if I don't "dress to make like I don't want to impress," when I show up at this hipster haven, one of the staff members is always there to serve me up my one-size fits all coffee with a vegan cookie on the side.  

A smile may go a mile, but it doesn't always beat a terrific cup o' joe.

P.S. Did I mention their annual Halloween doggie costume contest?
author: Luna K.

description:
This is why I love Romy and Cafe Venice.

We've seen a lot of cafe's...coffee shops so its shouldnt be hard to get accustomed to one after all people we come here to just to get a picker-upper.

After been to several, I noticed that being a barista at this small mom and pops (not at Starbucks or Peets or any of those fancy franchise) are way cooler...For one you get to wear what you want, doesnt matter whether your showing off your tits or butt crack or whether you look like and smell like the last time you took a shower was 2 weeks ago, you can wear them dreads, mohawk, you can look like a goth or just regular asian girl. You get to play the music that you want and  not what the company is sellling. The downside to this all is yes it is customer service...dont get me wrong the folks at the register who helped me today are all pleasant but they are more pleasant-er to the "regulars"....this is what this people dont get...or i guess the owners of the business...yes its great to keep the regulars but dont you want to attract new ones that will eventually become your regulars?

Oh and they dont have the "coffee collars", (mind you I save mine so no prob for me) but how can we help save the planet if we just give them another cup (double cup it)...now isnt that wasteful...i just dont know if they ran out the collars.

Over all the experience is A-OK, coffee taste good, if I am in the area I dont mind coming back. 

Oh yes and the baristas could "smile a little" too.
author: Malou C.

description: I am so happy that Farley's started using almond milk instead of soy in their lattes! That made my day as it is the ONLY place around here that does! Thank you Farley's.
author: Trina S.

description: I have been looking for the right cup of hot chocolate for 14 years.  Good tasting coco is the easy part, and I've found my share of cafes sporting yummy ingredients.  Yesterday at Farley's I found, for the first time in my life, a barrista who prepared hot chocolate with the consistency that I have been looking for all these years.  It was thick, hot chocolate FOAM all the way down.  Most people give you hot milk with a little  bit of flaccid coco-foam on top.  This foam had body and sensuality and went all the way to the bottom of the cup.  This was 6-star preparation.  Unfortunately, the ingredients were only 3 stars.
author: Ben G.

description: Forget coffee + treats, I come here to browse the magazines: I look at Vogue UK + the various lit mags that show up (the kind that look like chunky paperbacks and cost $15).
author: Zoe L.

description:
I go there very often as i live nearby. Coffee is ok, premises are great (lots of tables, magazines, etc.). The people behind the counter however, are more often than not grumpy and at times rude.  There is only one size of cup so don t ask for a tall/large coffee or you will get a condescending remark. :-)
There are a few good guys though.
The music in the morning is often quite bad: punkish, loud, shouting music is not the best suited at 7am in my opinion but maybe it reflects the mindset of the grumpy barristats. :-)
author: FOO D.

description: I was thinking about hitting the Starbucks but decided to go local instead.  I'm very glad I did.  The coffee was great.  Sitting in the window seat made studying much more appealing!
author: Kara H.

description:
Great magazine rack, local hangout. Pics of the Halloween pet contest were on the wall- beautifully done.

Baristas were engaged in a fight/argument when I walked it- would be great if they could take it to the back or pay attention to the customer.

Tables a bit close together- found it a little chilly with the door open.
author: KD D.

description:
Awesome coffee (their mocha is my favorite), ambience, people and music.

Sometimes there's a funny smell inside, but I get used to it after a while :)
author: viv k.

description:
Cramped, I'm often stumbling over people to get a table or a latte. Plenty of outlets, wireless connection that makes you re-log in every hour.

Best part of this place really is Hazel's kitchen next door. I usually head over to Hazel's to get a sandwich whenever I go to to Farley's.
author: Latte Queen W.

description: I suppose I could post a rant about how uncomfortably unfriendly the service was (it was), but frankly, it was a one minute transaction, and I won't let that color the rest of my day. My genmaicha was very good; my friend's chai latte was (in her words) "chai-scented steamed milk." The atmosphere seemed cool (I did like the huge magazine racks in the back) though we didn't stay long enough to enjoy it because it was insanely crowded. So overall: meh.
author: Sara Y.

description:
OK, the coffee is not the best in town, but if you want a real "neighborhood cafe" experience, this is the place to go. Everytime that I go there, I feel like a truly "potrerohillan" (which I am). 
The art by local artists is just way cool and the live- music, poetry readings, and "support your local _____" events make this place one of the best independent coffee houses in town. No wifi and "get real" with their choices of drinks (i.e. no one thousand options on milk) just add to the experience.
(I reserve the fifth star for when they get the best coffee in town).
author: S. A.

description:
Walk in get some lovely coffee, have a gander at the magazine wall, hang out, eat fabulous little treats. 
what's not to love?
it isn't even have a pretentious feel
author: Charlie D.

description:
i always pay farley's a visit when eating in the hood.

this last time was a hearty lunch at chez maman which warranted a cup of joe at farley's.  i love anything that is anti-peet's or starbucks though i am partial to the brainwashing tall caramel macchiato that starbucks doles out.

i don't know why people knock the mags rack.  i need my printed media fix and they do carry a good variety from outdoor mags to more art and design publications.

feeding my brain and feeding my soul with a caffeine fix and well ok, a celeb gossip mag time to time keeps me sane.

farley's, you are a rock.  not always pretty but solid.
author: Anh V.

description: Best coffee shop ever. Said to provide WIFI very soon.
author: Yann K.

description:
Coffee is good, other drinks are good as well.  Nothing here is "great".  

Too loud for studying/reading, etc.  The people are nice, though.
author: Timothy S.

description: Despite only having one size, no slip covers (probably to save the planet), and the too cool to smile hipster employees... this place has such good coffee!!! I became an instant addict. Really, smooth, rich, creamy, and fresh. Its the best I have had in the neighborhood and at $1.75 its pretty affordable.
