Just dont ask for a large cuz then they will know your a virgin and scoff at you!
author: M K.

description:
ok, ok, I'm a peetnik, but when I'm on the hill - I don't hesitate to stop here.  the coffee's good - haven't tried the other "grinds" that you can take home in bulk.  great foam on the caps!

i usually go off hours, late pm or evening - the staff is always great -friendly and get to know you by name, even if you're not a hill person - always good for a nice conversation.  great place to hang out and talk with friends. 

love those oat  things for breakfast - try to stay away from those great cookies!  and you have to love the logo....

how about a scrabble contest???
author: Jersey G.

description:
Even though I'm in the Mission and much closer to a ton of other cafes, I make it a point to catch the 22 (hurr) out to Farley's, and you should too. Here's why:

-Good coffee, free refills
-I mentioned free refills right?
-Badass music always
-Lots of free papers and a magazine rack in case you didn't bring anything to read
-Board games to waste time. When's the last time you played fuckin Battleship? That's right, go do it now.
-Cool local crowd, not the too-cool-for-school hipster bitches you find all over Mission (I'm lookin at you, Ritual)
-Some cool baristas will shoot the shit with you

Some negative points that aren't quite significant enough to subtract a star:
-Sometimes cold/crowded/full of flies (bizarre... are the gods angry at you Farley?)
-Some of the baristas are dick-ish. I guess it's what I deserve when I forget my tight jeans and flannel and facial hair in my other fanny pack.
author: Jim K.

description: Simple and calm. My drink got cold because once it was ready I did not hear them call my name and even though I was one of only four people there, it was 15 minutes before they notified me. Not a big deal though. I liked the area and it was a nice simple spot to catch up with a friend.
author: Scott D.

description: Service is not great, but mainly, I should not be able to smell the person serving me from across the counter.  You work in food service - take a shower and wear deodorant.
author: D D.

description:
1) I heart my neighborhood (Potrero Hill).  

2) I heart Farleys.

3) My Review:  So I moved to this hood seven months ago and stepped into Farleys that first weekend.  Loved it instantly. Why?  Friendly, hip staff that were playing equally hip music and the coffee was great.  The biscotti was mouth watering.  The magazines were just the icing on the cake as was the simplicity of it all.  

What you see is what you get.  Really, this is just your local, community coffee shop that does it's thing by just being itself.  I love the bikers, the families, the students, the techy-commuters, etc...  I've become a regular so much so that it feels really odd if I'm not at Farleys in the morning a couple times before work during the week or at noon on the weekends.  

It's like Cheers - everyone knows your name.  And you know ahead of time, that as you're about to arrive, one of your friends or acquaintances will be there.  Besides the coffee, it offers a great social platform.  I like that feeling.  That I can hide out in a corner and work or read or catch up on the neighborhood chatter and maybe make some plans for later in the week. 

Anyway.. when you find a place that keeps bringing you back, it's a great feeling.  I really like Farleys.  It's one of the reasons that I'll stay in Potrero for a long time.  Try it, you might like it too.
author: Emily D.

description:
This place is the first coffee shop I discovered when I moved here two years ago, due mostly to its proximity to the laundromat where I go to overload the washing machines and play Raiden DX. Because it was the first place I felt I could call a hang-out, I have a heightened affinity for its cathedral-high ceilings and unpolished ambience. 

The coffee is pretty good, as are the pastries; not unbelievable, but consistent and tasty. The art on the walls is usually pretty decent, but, hey, they're giving local artists some good exposure, so even when it's not great you can still appreciate it. Anywhere on the floor you sit, you kind of feel like you're in the way of the foot traffic, but seating along the walls is great.

It's easy to feel connected to the community here, since it's usually bustling with people and it feels like everyone is a regular. It's location in Potrero I guess means that everyone IS a regular, since people who don't live here generally don't make the trek all the way up the hill. But if you do, and you don't know about this place, you really have to check it out.
author: Mark B.

description: I read in some reviews that the service here was unfriendly, but I experienced the opposite. The girl at the counter who served me was very nice and friendly. I came in here for a snack before I went to see a play at thick theatre down the street. There weren't any other snacky places open. I was hoping for a sandwich or something like that, but they only have some bakery goods, and all the other places in the neighborhood that might have something like that were closed (except the pizza place). The zucchini bread I had was tasty, as was the soy chai latte. It came in a real cup, which doesn't happen often to me, and it wasn't overly sweet like tons and tons of chai lattes are. Either, they put very little sweetener in, or they put no sweetener in and since I'm used to unsweetened soy milk at home, the sweetness of regular soymilk was enough for me. Very good. The inside isn't fancy, it's all mismatched. You can buy magazines there too. I would come back if I lived anywhere nearby!  Ps cash only, but it was cheap..the chai and bread came to $5.50 I think.
author: Merredith L.

description: Great spot with a superb magazine stand - rarely see those anymore. Old wood floors, high ceilings and lots of space between tables to facilitate daydreaming, like a proper coffee shop should. Velvet Underground on the sound system, and, oh yeah, the coffee's good too. The nice old yippie hanging at the back table was the Farley in question I think. Makes me want to move to Potrero so I can hang out there every day.
author: C M.

description:
one of the finest independent coffee houses before independent coffee houses became all hip and trendy...

farley's is a coffee house for those who love coffee and enjoy the casual cafe ambiance sans the cool factor. the space reminds me somewhat of cafe abir with its eclectic magazine selection, but the coffee is much, much better here and the hipster vibe is checked at the door. i like that. unfortunately, farley's is not perfect. from my experience, if you're not a regular here, the staff can get quite snobbish about their coffee. this makes me mad. i tell you. mad!!! listen, take your 'i'm holier than thou' attitude and shove it. i don't need to be judged.......and no, i don't drink starbucks, you coffee elitists.

you know, i was going to give farley's 4 stars, but more i think about how they treat the non-regulars, the more i get upset about it. hence 3 stars. farley's, you blew it.
author: frisco j.

description:
theyre not grumpy, you're just a yuppy

best cappuccinos on the hill, [lucky thing piccino is in dogpatch too] and an excellent magazine selection for a bookstore, nevermind that they're a coffee shop.

oh and they do community building stuff like displaying local artwork (from all walks too, prisoners, skateboard manufacturers, retards) and a halloween pet parade that is the cutest thing in the world

and i know cute.


plus word on the street is they're adding your O SO PRECIOUS SKIM MALK and WHY FIEZ.   because we all need our lives to be a little more complicated, don't we?
author: Gabrielle K.

description: Before Farley's I never drank coffee! I tried drinking coffee before starting with the Northwestern type-o-brew and that didn't go over very well at all. But now I'm a fan-o-Farley's. I love that the place has beat up floors and keeps the feel of an old historic building and that the crew behind the counter seems like they're coming down off the caffeine and are into their own strange little world, other than, "what can I get'cha?" But man, they pour these really cool designs with frothed milk that I know I haven't been able to do and the latte's are really good. Oh, but don't ask for smiles, that's extra...
author: Gina A.

description: Ok place. Drove here from San Mateo to try a new coffee place. I tend to agree with other reviews that the staff is very cold. Not rude to me adleast. But not welcoming. The coffee is not good. But that is up to debate. Expresso was good. Not comfortable seating. Hard narrow seats. They don't clean tables or wipe them offten. I have to give this place a C-
author: S G.

description: Now they  have wi-fi and nonfat milk.  Same sulky service, but the rest is hard to beat.  They do loosen up, as I said, when you throw the nice vibe at them, but the cool kids attitude really ought to take a vacation.
author: Laurel B.

description: the coffee is always excellent and the local artwork, neighbors, and selection of magazines to freely peruse is perfect. Yay favorite place!
author: Brian T.

description: I didn't feel welcome here because I felt the service was unfriendly and cold, and I don't like feeling uncomfortable in any place I go to drink coffee.  The coffee was ok but not great and the pastries were stale and expensive, for what you get.  There are many other coffee shops in San Francisco I'd rather go.
author: Jin W.

description:
In San Francisco, we often have a problem with wait staff. Despite their lack of education or real skills, there exists a pervasive attitude of, "I am way too cool to be your barista." Yesterday at Farley, the male barista there at 5 PM really took the cake for world-class rudeness and cruelty.

I am not going back in there any time soon. And here's why: 

An old man comes in there listening to his cell phone. He asked for an espresso. I heard him use the word, "please".  The next  event to transpire is that the barista CHUCKs the old man's money back in his face and says, "I don't serve rude people."

Maybe Mr. Barista was having his period, I don't know what-but I was so sitting there going, "WHAT???!!" That was totally over the top and uncalled for.

The old man objects and says that he's  been going in there for twenty years and tried to reason with the barista. 

Hint to old man: Don't waste your time trying to reason with crazy baristas. It's like trying to reason with the Soup Nazi from "Seinfeld."

And you know what the barista does? He starts parodying the old man in front of the other customers while laughing hysterically with the shrillness of shattered glass.

Everyone just sort of gawked at this situation like we were caught in a bad B movie of sorts.

The old dude shuffled out because that's what old people do when crazy baristas act that way. I thought that he was going to cry. 

I was really bothered by the encounter. So, I thought that I should make mention of this here.

By the way, I am an attorney. And that barista is fishing for a lawsuit for age discrimination and intentional infliction of emotional distress, which is such a pity since the dude who owns this place is actually a really nice person.

Lawsuits are expensive. I would have slipped the old dude my card, but I will let the next ambulance chaser have this one...
author: Olivia B.

description: A sunny little setting to hang around, do the crossword, meet up before going elswhere. Farley's has big windows and plenty of light and reading material for your wait. It's simply a genuine neighborhood cafe. The coffee?.... you don't go there for the coffee (3/5). But as for all the scrawny-bearded-tatooed cliches' of a coffee pump engineer... I'd be more than happy to offer you a chill pill outside the next time I get that overly-secure attitude with my service.
author: Royo Y.

description: The coffee IS good.  Tons of cool board games only missing some key chips/pieces, mags.  There is not that comfort vibe, however, just some hard seating, charis and tables.  Without the comfort factor it makes it hard for me to linger.  But, this place is in my hood and I can see that lots of other folks have no problem lingering all day.  I can see how for some people the vibe here is just heaven.  Not quite my cup of tea-vibe, but my husband loves it.  To each their own.  I am not into nazi-/militant- anything.  This is coffee-police central.  And yes, the Coffee Is Good and Rich.  I don't think they do non-fat or even low-fat milk and I think only reg sugar or honey (no pink or blue stuff, which I like).  But, my gut feeling is you'll actually get tarred and feathered for asking for a frappucino, as opposed to just being kicked out.
author: Isa L.

description: I may be picky, but this is was not good coffee.  I didn't like the flavor.  The girl at the counter seemed indifferent, and nearly aloof.  I did not enjoy the feeling of being the odd man out.  I guess there are too many regulars, and not enough odd men out, like me.  Ok magazines.  The crowd can seem a bit snubbish.
author: Honey L.

description: Malcolm Gladwell once said that if you ask people what kind of coffee they want, they'll all say they want a "dark rich hearty roast," --- even though only 25-27% actually like a dark rich hearty roast.  "Most of you like milky, weak coffee," he says. "But you will never ever say, to someone who asks what you want, that you want a milky weak coffee."  Farley's has perfected this said cup of coffee.  Every single drink is watered down.  Hot chocolate is served Swiss Miss packet style, a little powder and a lot of water.
author: Poker B.

description: Good coffee, outdoor seating, free wifi, friendly staff. 4/4 with my list of coffee place requirements.  They even have board games which are great when killing time waiting for my clothes at the laundromat across the street.  Plus, this place is walking distance from my place.  This place is a no-brainer.
author: Chris M.

description: Their espresso is good, and you will always regret bringing in your own reading material! They're pretty inexpensive too!
author: Maddy S.

description: Awesome spot to hang out and have a great cup of coffee.  The atmosphere is fantastic and the sidewalk seating gives a great view down from Portreo Hill.  Highly recommend this spot for a quaint cup of coffee!
author: J H.

description: Beautiful art on the walls, friendly staff, only tried the tea- but it was great, comfortable environment, diversity of age (always refreshing). When I came in they were playing Merriweather Post Pavilion. Clearly an excellent coffee shop, that I will continue to go to.
author: Dani S.

description: Good lattes and chai.  Reasonable prices for decent coffee.  Good atmosphere/music.  They have lots of board games so that's kinda fun.  I usually walk out of there thinking that the servers are sort of jerks but they're just doing their hipster thing so I try not to judge.
author: Kristin P.

description: This is thee place to go on the hill if you are looking to find good place to sit and read magazines or a good book -  as for the coffee??....well, from what i've been told from fellow locals, no one goes here for the coffee. (it's average at best)  But it's a great place to sit, chill out and people watch.  If you want really good coffee, try up the hill at Thinker's Cafe or even Chatz (less attitude) But Farley's does have this funky vibe to it, and it's extremely popular with the locals especially on weekends.
author: Jody M.

description: I'm the kind of person who sees a Starbucks and looks for a rocket launcher. So when visiting a friend I discovered Farley's. The staff was great and the various coffee drinks reminded me of being on a street corner in Paris. If your ever on Portreo Hill and need a cup of liquid heaven, then Farley's is your place.
author: Jordan D.

description: Great little coffee shop nessled in the emerging village of Potrero Hill.  Roomy, lots of places to sit, tables in the windowed nook at the front, and there's a large magazine rack in the corner of the cafe.  What was bigger for me was the neighborhood.  Very pleasantly surprised.   How cute is this area? Well I for one had no idea.  And perfectly situated on a knoll overlooking downtown, the Bay Bridge and Bay.  There are a number of interesting looking restaurants and shops for the enthusiastic local to explore on a sunny weekend day.  I will be back soon to try some of the restaurants.
author: Rick H.

description: Good morning my love. So dark and dreamy, with the perfect foam to make my morning complete. Fabulous selection of magazines and a great place to meet the neighbors. Like me.
author: dava g.

description: Good neighborhood coffee shop.  Plenty of space to do work or study.  Nice magazine selection as well.  I also like the local art they rotate monthly.
author: Clayton K.

description: God bless a coffee shop that sells a great selection of magazines, lets you read them even if you arent going to buy them and believes that the only two logical choices for a good latte are soy or whole milk,  and therefore dont offer any non-fat or 2%. Enough said.
author: Drue C.

description: Funny that I know the guy who reviewed below me and I was just going to say that I love this place.  I love it so much that i take the bus there and back just to read for an hour.  They have an amazing magazine section, people are friendly.  This cafe makes me want to move to Portrero Hill.
author: A K.

description: I want to like this place, I really do. I like the coffee, the magazines, the artsy people from the hood that frequent here...but unfortunately I can only give it 3 stars because the staff is so damn unfriendly. I don't know if it's "SF hipster cool" to act rude or what but nearly every time I go in there I'm met with some surly dude/chic with a chip on their shoulder. One time I went in and stood at the counter waiting while 3 staff members just stood around chatting with each other (I know they saw me) and ignored me for a few minutes. Finally a girl came up and helped me (even though she made me wait she was friendly). I guess I spent too much time living in Japan where the service is so impeccable. Anyway, I still like Farley's and will be back because the coffee is great and I like to support local businesses.
author: lani P.

description:
If you like old hipsters that are trying really hard to not seem as old as they are, if you like attitudes and flips-of-the-hair or sudden turns-of-the head or you like your cafe au lait served abruptly and by someone with disapproving, pursed lips, then Farley's is the place for you! Oh- and if you really miss that feeling of watching the cliques of the supposedly wealthy, cool, popular kids at your high school, then you'll also find Farley's an absolute JOY!  Only this time, the kids are suddenly...thirty-somethings without a cause (truly).
But do tell the barista  that you like your coffee hot, and that does not mean nuked in their microwave, because this is a regular REGULAR occurrence. Oh yeah, and, one more thing, steal a dog from someone, and put any book by Noam Chomsky or Neitzchze under your arm before you enter Farley's so that you don't stick out, otherwise you'll be subject to the decaying hipsters giving you the once-over.
author: Sunny A.

description: I like supporting the neighborhood coffee shop over Starbucks.  But, I always feel ashamed somehow when I stop in on the way to work, and I am wearing something suitably office-appropriate.  Also, the time I was holding my cell phone and was informed that cell phones aren't allowed at the counter (I know that, there is a sign, I was just holding it, not talking on it!), I was too embarassed to stop in for coffee for the next week.  (I hate it when hipsters embarass me!)
author: Riya K.

description: I lived in Potrero Hill for my first month in SF, and I only went to Farley's a couple of times.  There's nothing special about the coffee, and the pastries are your standard coffee shop fare.  I really like the staff, the random music selection (today it was the Flaming Lips and A Tribe Called Quest), and the friendly neighborhood vibe, though.  It seems like this is where neighbors on the hill go just to see who's there and say hello.  Now I go back about once a week for a couple of games of Scrabble, and I really enjoy it.  They also have some board games there, for those who are interested.
author: Andy G.

description: Ok, I'll give it to them. I'll add one more star, grudgingly, but I'll add it. They've finally realized that it is 2008 and that maybe, just maybe people care a little bit about their hearts.  At long last you can enjoy non-fat milk, yes it's true they've finally stepped away from the darkside, well almost. You'll still find snarky baristas and crappy seating, and if only they could figure out that you don't put an iced mocha in a paper cup, they might, just might get my business. Who puts an iced coffee in a paper cup, and what the hell is up with only one cup size? This place still gets a veto from me. At least I gave them a second chance, right?
author: melissa t.

description: In a city of fine coffeehouses, Farley's is exceptional. If you're a writer, a reader, or a people-wathcher, this is the place to consume your caffeine. For verbal exhibitionists, Farley's offers a shared coffeehouse journal, in which any patron can write, draw, or doodle. For voyeurs, the journals spanning many years make interesting reading.
author: scott b.

description: I just don't know... maybe the barista was in a bad mood, or maybe I shouldn't have asked for an iced drink.  Maybe it's just because I'm not a local Farley's patron. Whatever the case, I was greeted with raised eyebrows and a surly demeanor.  My iced drink was served in a paper cup which felt like it was about to break any second.  However, the apple juice I also bought, as well as the fruit and nut bar were very tasty.  The space is very inviting for the most part, never mind the babies crawling all over the floor.  That must have just been a fluke or a halucination on my part.
author: Sarah S.

description:
when the late afternoon sun strafes the sloping sidewalk in front of farley's café, as twilight slowly descends upon potrero hill, there are few places that can match the exquisite satisfaction of watching the day capitulate to night than from a chair in front of this neighborhood cafe... but the funny thing about farley's is that while it remains one of my favourite places to hang out in san francisco, and is certainly my first choice for cafés on potrero hill, the customer service here is really not that friendly and i've started to reconsider whether or not i should continue to patronize this place.

while i generally embrace the staff's laid-back disposition, there's a fine line between a knowing smirk and smug disregard.

i don't demand instant bonhomie between the server and the served, but there's one particular barista that i have in mind who exemplifies what is troubling about farley's customer interactions: a gaunt, surly fellow with dark hair who often mutters to himself and rarely graces customers with a thank you or even eye contact. i don't think i've ever heard him speak and, rather than handing over my change, it is not unusual for him to toss the bills and coins onto the counter.

i don't mind putting up with him, but i have to be honest: farley's loses its charm, bit by bit, when it continues to treat some of its customers as unwelcome interlopers. i have been a semi-regular customer since 1996 and i don't think it's too much to ask for a little less frostiness from the staff. i am well aware that café employees often deal with customers who are severely lacking in social graces but this provides no excuse for assuming a guarded or antagonistic stance in return.

looking askance of the customer service, the coffee is still far above average, the rotating display of local art is generally worth a gander, and the uncommonly amusing music selections often provide more than the occasional nuggets of inspiration.

i just wish that the folks behind the counter would smile more often.
author: christian svanes k.

description: Everything you'd want in a coffee house, from the excellent java to the revolving artwork.  Huge bonuses:  very cool selection of magazines, sumptuous pastries, entertaining board games, softwood floors, place to park your dog, ongoing inter-active dairies, and my favorite of all:  they sell a full selection of stove-top espressos, especially the rubber rings that you need to replace every 6 months!
author: James O.

description: Love this funky little place.  Very good coffee drinks and tea.  Love the atmosphere.  One of my favorite places in SF.  Check out this great neighborhood in SF.  Cute little shops.
author: Cynthia L.

description: Cozy "town square" of Potrero Hill. Nice and airy. A well-represented tea menu with a couple dozen choices, everything from Earl Grey to pu erh. Prices are really fair here, pots of tea are less than $3. Better magazine rack than most book stores.
author: Brandon R.

description: Love little cute coffee shops, especially with outdoor seating, but here's the bonus.  They have a magazine stand inside, with European magazines too.  That's different.  Its got a really homey feel to it, like a shack but not a shack.  With antiques, worn down wood look, but who ever designed this spot.  Good job.  Its nice.  And when given a hot beverage, the barista does that fancy foaming art.  So pretty. Now here is why I'm giving it ok.  I ordered a cold coffee, and they served it to me in the regular hot coffee cups.  Lets just say, the cup started to deteriorate, and the cup was stamped the Farley name, and the ink started running.  Um, that's why cold drinks are service in plastic my dear.  Not acceptable.  Oh and I saw 1, 2, 3. . . .oh wait, a lot.  A lot of flies buzzing around.  Not sure how they can fix that since its nice to keep the door open, but yay, I'm sorry.  It doesn't turn me on to see that.  And finally, it had wi-fi and everyone there hanging out were hipsters.  Yes, yet again, I wonder when will this scene go away.  Its unique, but starting to get tiresome on me.  La sigh.
author: Janice F.

description: One of my favorite neighborhood coffee spots, you are bound to run into someone you know here. Good coffee too, and a nice selection of magazines if you forget to bring your own reading material!
author: Nish N.
sarah l.

description: Jeez, with so many reviews, need I say more? I've bought my octagon beans here since moving to SF- the Wage to my Case. I keep trying to interest my wife in a backgammon game, but I just end up playing both sides by myself while she harps on me for not listening. You can typically find us here on weekend mornings eating chili or something from the cafe next door, while sipping our warm dark wunderdrug. I rarely make it out of here without bumping into a neighbor. The desserts are great.
author: Stephen H.

description:
a coffee shop that plays black sabbath.  now that is really cool!  hell will freeze over if i wait to hear that on the starbucks playlist.

great tea selections.

those oat/granola brick cakes that they call "hockey pucks" really grow on you.  i could get addicted to those things!

staff is really cool.  this place is just great.
author: Norman S.

description: this place is most awesome because for the single hour that i sat outside drinking tea, there was opportunity to play with approximately 20 dogs. forget getting a puppy, from now on if i feel the need to play with pups, i'll just head to Farley's.
author: Regina C.

description: This is a great place to hang out and drink coffee or tea. Not only can you sit and read, you can also get a magazine, borrow a board game, or observe the regulars, which can be quite entertaining. There is a good selection of tea, though I usually get a mocha, which is average. The staff can be rather aloof, but are always kind, i.e. extra water for your tea. One night I got to pick out a mystery grab bag, which turned out to be pastries. I was informed I was luckier than the woman before me, who got a bag with crumpled newspaper. If you find that as amusing as I did, Farley's is the place for you.
author: Alexi S.

description:
this place is the pits. bad coffee and worse service. 

i think farley's gets by on a reputation of being really "neighborhoody," which is fine as long as the product is good ... in reality, if a blue bottle or peet's (or even a starbucks) opened on the same block, Farley's would quickly go out of business.
author: Scott H.

description:
So I just moved to the neighborhood and was excited to try out Farley's.  I love neighborhood coffee shops and had high hopes for this one.  I was disappointed all around.  First the drink. My litmus test for any coffee shop is the cappuccino.  Before Starbucks this was almost always made right, now most place make the Starbucks version which is basically a latte.   Their one size cup guarantees this will always be bad.  I don't want coffee flavored milk.  Perhaps regular coffee is better here.  

Service, I didn't feel any attitude from the barista but maybe that was because he was to buisy ignoring me.  After standing at the counter for 3 minutes I expect a little bit of acknowledgment from the barista who is having a conversation with another patron from behind the counter just 5 feet away.  I don't need him to jump right over but an "I'll be right with you" would have been nice.  Not the most welcoming staff.  

From the street the atmosphere looks great, one of the reasons I was looking forward to trying this place out.  Once inside finding a seat was near impossible at 3 in the afternoon on Saturday.  If half of the floor space wasn't wasted behind the counter I would be more forgiving on this point but they only serve coffee, tea and very basic pastries,  no real food to speak of.  Yet, half the cafe's space is wasted behind the counter while maybe a dozen tables are crowded together in the same amount of space. My living room is smaller than the space behind the counter here.  But I'm glad the barista is nice and comfy and no one is intruding into his personal space.  So sitting here is not incredibly relaxing.  On top of that the chairs are not comfortable at all.  The music is generally good but blaring way to loud. Yes, I'm old but not that old, background music is good, college dorm loud not so much when at a coffee shop.    
What Farley's does have going for it is that it is a neighborhood cafe.  So I'll go here before Starbucks.  But the coffee down the street at Chats is better and you can get food.
author: Michael D.

description: How have I not yet written a review for Farleys? These guys are wonderful. A small business, always pleasant baristas, awesome prices ($2/cup, and one free refill), and now they even have De La Paz! How can you go wrong? My only complaint is that sometimes the music (on radio/speakers) is a bit whacky sometimes, which is a bit off-putting for working, but if you have headphones and you need to concentrate it's fine--- this is not always the case, but sometimes it can be a bit intense. Their live music rocks though, and the outside patio/ street lot is freakin awesome. There's a great community here, an electronic stamp card (buy 10 cups get 1 free), De La Paz beans for sale ($13-$15 per 12oz, normal prices, but freshly roasted (only 2-3 days old which is what you want anyway, better than you will get at Whole Foods)). The one recommendation I would make is to have a savory food option, like bagels/bread/fruits, although they allow you to bring in food from Hazel's next door, but it would be nice to have savory food options after Hazel's closes at 4pm.
author: Amanda S.

description: This is the best neighborhood coffee house in the city.  I like my brew strong enough to rearrange DNA--which is why I'm a Peet's fanatic as well--but Farley's brews a solid cup of joe and serves it in a really comfortable, chill atmosphere.  They also have a fabulous magazine stand to boot.  Just don't ask for a nonfat latte or anything else:  You'll get whole milk and like it.
author: Drew W.

description: Recently my husband went in to grab a magazine and a coffe and you know what?Their staff is still obnoxious as ever.WOW!!Seriously what is the problem with these rude staff?My husband just want a nice cup of coffe and not an attitude to go with it.Third strike and it's official,this place is dead to us and our friends.
author: S F.

description:
I was here for a quick stop before hitting Umi across the street, and was impressed by the variety in the tea section. Myself not much of a coffee drinker, I was simply walking up and down the streets while waiting for my table and was drawn to Farley's for its brightness and inviting feel. It looked like it had established itself as a neighborhood haunt, with its very SF quirks and statements about the politics and economics of the coffee and tea industry. I wasn't really affected by the rebel cry, I just really liked... the space and the likability of the menu. At $1.75 for a cup of genma cha, this is probably a little expensive but in comparison to other SF coffee costs, pretty reasonable; additionally, its not everywhere that you can get a to-go cup of genma cha or pu-er tea, or even pekoe orange. 
Service was great, though I can agree on the mellowness, which was agreeable to me... I can't really stand the Starbucks perky mentality.
I'd come again for sure.
author: Jessica L.

description: Best house coffee I've had in a cafe. Great vegan chocolate chip cookie. Service was horrendous. The barista had a major attitude problem. It's a shame, because I won't spend my money again in a place with such a bad vibe...
author: Chris S.

description: This place is a gem.  I thought the two guys serving the drinks were a little greasy (like they hadn't washed their hair in a week) but I really enjoyed the coffee shop itself.  They have this whole wall of notebooks that people have written in over the years.  I could spend hours in there amusing myself by looking through them.
author: Joanna S.

description: When I moved to Potrero Hill from North Beach, I thought I had lost the ability to sit in a good coffee house and spend the day working, drinking good coffee and people watching in between e-mails and phone calls. Enter Farley's to the rescue. Good coffee at reasonable prices (I've learned that soy latte's can actually taste good), occassional live music, free wifi, a very strong sense of community, and their magazine collection is rivaled only by Fog City on Market. Wherever you might live in the city, swing by and give this place a try ... parking's pretty easy and I'm sure it will become one of your favorite coffee spots.
author: Fred M.

description:
One Cup, One Milk, No Bullshit...
If you're looking for relentlessly cheerful service, or nonfat vanilla- flavored pseudo-coffee, or gallon-sized cups: Go Elsewhere. 
If you're looking for a neighborhood joint (meaning, deal with the kids and the dogs and the counter staff that is chatting it up with the regulars instead of rushing to get you your drink) that has more magazines than you've even heard of, funky tunes on the stereo, board games, art shows, music and poetry events, plenty of seating, and a crowd of locals, Farley's is brilliant.
author: rachel h.

description: Great neighborhood coffee shop. It has a few tables and chairs outside, and you can usually get a seat. It has a good selection of pastry, including my favorite, scones.
author: Amy E.

description: Best coffee shop in the city, if not the universe. The thing about Farley's is that I was going there for about a year before I realized they had a bathroom. That used to drive me crazy because I was relaxing, chugging good coffee, reading the journals and then the full bladder would require me to leave. So, friends, don't pull a me---just go up those stairs in the back and enter the room that looks like you're not supposed to enter it. The bathroom is on the right and it's quite charming too.
author: Stumbalina b.

description: Considering this place is very "liberal" and open minded (yeah right) the emloyees are rather snobby (It's their way or the highway).  The "coffee" is unique and lemon cake is scrumptious.  Kind of small and cold inside (they leave the door open).
author: Heidi M. S.

description: If you come in sweaty and stinky and beg for free water they let you lap it up, even out of real glasses.  They have samples out and don't seem to mind you grabbing two or three, and the coffee was just fine (so was the water).  Plus they have a big fun magazine selection and it just feels comfy airy and sunny.
author: Today Y.

description:
The coffee is good, the service is always snarky and/or aloof and the wait is boring. 

I live nearby and prefer to drive five extra minutes to either Blue Bottle or Dynamo for slightly better coffee and a warm and welcoming vibe. 

'Cause I can get snarky at home...
author: Gym W.

description: Great neighborhood coffee shop, nothing really fancy just coffee people running a coffee business. Farley's is what independent coffee houses do, serve good coffee and make space for everyone. If you want to just read, chat, or just get a cup-o-joe you will love this independent establishment that reflects Potrero culture. Come on in grab an old chair pull up to a old table and enjoy the day.
author: Nick L.

description: Yet another reason why living on Potrero Hill can be like living in a small New England town.  Rustic, charming, no-nonsense coffee house.
author: Jeff P.

description: Whatever man.  Farley's rocks.  For 4 years it was part of my morning routine when I worked in the hood.  So freakin-what if the staff doesn't tuck you in and read you a bedtime story with your cup of coffee...It's a classy no-nonsense operation there...just get your shit, read a magazine, drink your mug, say hi to the dogs and go!  No need to bring "protocol" into this.  It's only coffee.
author: Ranch S.

description:
ok, so i gave farley's a second chance because they just added wi-fi. maybe it's because i've grown accustomed to sugarlump, but i'm not really that impressed. i tried farley's during the pre wi-fi days and decided to quit because of it. but now that i've added it, i've noticed a few good/bad things (+/-, respectively)

 - the floor is uneven. maybe depends on where you sit, but it's definitely noticeable.
 - the coffee is cold and the portions are small. i mean, it can't cost them THAT much more to actually double the volume of my americano when i order a double

 + the bathroom is clean and far away from people
 + they have newspapers
 + it's not full of laptops and people actually talk to each other here

oh yeah.. wi-fi here is free, but it's one of those hotspot redirect things where you have to "login" and it expires after two hours.

verdict: adequate.
author: Bryan E.

description: What do I like about Farley's? No nonsense and within walking distance of where I work! Oh yes, and one of the best collections of magazines for sale that I have seen in a long time anywhere by far! There is something for everyone here and the selection of goodies at the counter can't be resisted, no matter how hard I try!
author: Kim L.

description: When one walks into the big F, one feels like one has entered into the grand-daddy of all neighborhood cafe's . . . in both good and bad.  Great coffee, great people watching, fun staff . . . does feel a little pretentious and exclusive (Like you are a HUGE sell-out of you even think about that "S" place), but then again if it also makes you feel included in that, isn't that good business ;-)
author: Bruce R.

description: One of the best places in the city to sit for hours and read. Be careful with the coffee, as it is rather potent. I gave my only Farley's mug to some guy in Africa, so I'll have to stop in and get a new one sometime soon.
author: Raoul D.

description: Coffee really ain't that great, but the seating is fantastic. Awesome magazines that I am not cool enough to recognize, but enjoy browsing anyway. And is there any reason that Wallpaper still exists? Pretentious! Boring!
author: Liboo K.

description: The coffee is decent.  The decor is chill and homey.  The employees totally rock and are usually rocking out to some good tunes.  Hey, where else in Potrero Hill are you gonna get caffeinated and eat your food from Hazel's?  The funky takeaway cups are a San Francisco original.  Kudos.  The in-house journal is also worth checking out, and it's got a fucking cool bathroom, too.
author: Ben V.

description: Very cozy and popular to the locals.  This seems to be the center of the neighborhood where everyone goes to.  Coffee is good although they only have one size in cups.  They also have a great selection of tea, pastries, magazines, and local artwork.
author: Brandon L.

description: Damn, I love farley's.  One cup one milk one love.  grab a magazine, a red-eye and cookie.  enjoy.
author: Dmitri A. N.

description: Tops the list for "The Best of Po Hill." Great coffee, great magazines, but even better, it's a great place to meet an old friend and hang out catching up. Recipe for a great day: furniture shopping, followed by rejuvenating at Farley's, more furniture, topped off w/ dinner at Bar Tartine.
author: Johnny C.

description: I'm not the coffee shop type.  I prefer to get in, get out, and get on my way.  However...spending lazy Saturday's and Sunday's hanging alone or with friends over several cups of deep, rich coffee whilst perusing an endless selection of magazines or watching the interesting Po'Hill folk  meander on by doesn't sound like such a bad thing.  If I ever get off my high-horse (or the Ritalin kicks in) and become the coffee shop enjoying type, Farley's will be my place because their coffee is delish!  So good, in fact, that I don't even add cream or sweetener (which is quite the feat considering my coffee has often been compared to a liquid candy bar) .
author: Dawn J.

description: I would give Farley's 5 stars if it stayed open past 10 o clock! C'mon guys. At least 11!  I love coming here. The drinks are made really well (though it would be nice if fat free milk were an option) and there's lots of yummy pastries to choose from. Also it's really fun to look through all the journals or play a game of scrabble with a friend. Great place to hang out before catching a show at Bottom of the Hill.
author: Lily F.

description: No coffee house snobs here!  Outside seating where people are bound to acknowledge that you exist- a rare find at a cafe these days.  A great magazine rack.  A neighborhood...of neighbors.
author: frankee U.

description: Great atmosphere. I went here on a Sunday morning  and really enjoyed my experience. The cashier helping me seemed a lil rushed but the rest of the staff was great. You can sit inside  or outside and they had board games and an large array of unique magazines. Best of All:  the patrons bring their dogs along so there was more than enough dogs to admire at this dog-friendly coffee shop.
author: Nicole C.

description:
I really don't know why people think this place is so special. Farley's does not have a cozy feel, and I am really not a big fan of their espresso. This is all I have there so I can't really review the other drinks...
The only reason I go there sometimes is because of the proximity to where I live and also for the free magazines. Yes, the staff is not all smiles but there were never rude to me either.
author: Urban D.

description:
Love love love Farley's!  One of the best local coffeehouses in SF for atmosphere - comfortable, casual and neighborly.

Just one thing - they've hired new baristas.  Sadly, the Farley's techinque for gravity-defying milk foam has not been passed on.  Today I got my first "average" cappuccino from Farley's, very sad indeed.  Hope they get up to speed soon...
author: Girlie G.

description: Great coffee, good cookies, good selection of magazines. Great mix of music. I always can find parking. A nice, friendly, relaxed place to chill and have a great cup of coffe.
author: Jay M.

description: Best cafe on Potrerro Hill.  (That's right Thinker's, you suck.)
author: Michael F.

description: bad coffee and wouldn't provide 2% milk. very disappointing
author: Jessica B.

description: Besides the fact that OJ grew up around here, Potrero might not be the most popular place in SF. Trekkin up De Haro for your morning cup of joe is worth it when you see the breathtaking view of the city and I definitely feel like I'm part of the community when I enter Farley's. The cushioned seats by the window is where I flip through the Onion or study for three hours listening to their cd collection (yesterday was Postal Service and Indigo Girls) and the walls are always changing.  I just discovered the Orange Spice tea, which is among their numerous blacks, greens and herbals. The Apple Cider is good too, and comes with a cinnamon stick. Kids love this place, it's a fun environment and a nice place for chess on the weekends (though some pieces mismatch, it's all about character). They also sell clothing, which is proof of a classic landmark.
author: Kim G.

description: After a quick lunch at Eliza's, my friend and I dropped by Farley's to get our coffee fix. Sorry, I hardly hang out around Potrero Hill, but I find Farley's pretty cool for my first impression. Simple menu, lots of room, plenty of mags, and an array of locals. Unfortunately, it's whole or soy milk- no in-betweens. It's a good place to hang with a couple of good folks with some good mochas. And what's with the ol' sneakers on display at the front windows?
author: Leroid D.

description: Update 9/7/06 What was I thinking? I must have been grumpy or oversensitive when I initially wrote this review. I was having a super busy day and had skipped breakfast. Farley's was the first place that came to mind. It was busy when I arrived, but there was an awesome selection of baked goods and the coffee was piping hot. Hungarian coffee cake is the best! ...Good coffee shop, but the barristas caused me some discomfort by the creepy way they greeted me. I vaguely felt as if I were getting profiled. Despite that, it's a nice place to which I am sure I will return.
author: Evelyn B.

description: This is the ultimate local, cozy, non-starbucks kinda place.  The coffee is good and there's a good selection of teas too.  Whether you wanna be alone with a book, chat with friends, or grab a board game...Farley's is a coffee shop for all types.  I like to walk around the block, up the crazy hill for some exercise and for the breathtaking view up top, and then return to my tea at Farley's.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Perfect morning ritual--great coffee, good selection of magazines and newspapers, you can even play a cool game of checkers..awesome neighborhood hangout--you'll run into the locals from Chez Papa/Mama, Aperto, Scoop, etc.   So San Francisco!
author: Jaena G.

description: I love Farley's. They have great drip coffee and a great neighborhood vibe. What better place to browse an interesting selection of magazines in an old victorian building with black wood floors and white walls. They also display a fun rotating exhibit of local art. Hate me because I'm beautiful, but I wish they had wi-fi, so I'm only rating it 3-stars.
author: Thanya S.

description: This is almost like a time-warp.  One night I stumbled into an accordion contest -- no kidding!  The coffees, however, are ALWAYS excellent.  The guys always look like they just did a big toke, but they are very, very attentive to their espresso drinks.  I have to love that.
author: Robert M.

description: Good coffee, good atmosphere without all the North Beach pretense. A favorite amongst Portrero locals and police make this a very comfortable (and safe) place to grab a cup of coffee and read away your cares with a good book or magazine. A great place to play Scrabble on a rainy day.
author: Be N.

description: Farley's is great. Good coffee, good music, friendly staff. I spend a lot of time in here and enjoy the laid-back atmosphere and the neighborhood-y feeling.
author: Rachel M.

description: I do love this place. Excellent coffee, nice bean selection. No crazy loud music.
author: Alexandra S.

description: Coffee for real.  No BS in this place, great mags, great coffee.  I am fairly sure they will kick you out if you ask for a frappacino.
author: Dan G.

description: Now that Farley's has somewhat reneged on it's One Cup One Milk mantra and now carries soymilk, I think they can move up the rung from a 3 to 4 star joint. The ambience is cool, you can hang out with a pastry and coffee and wait for someone you know to show up or bury your head in a book. They also carry some great mags that you won't see around other places - Giant Robot and Juxtapoz come to mind, but there are many more esoteric choices than just that. Get yourself some some dinner pizza at Goat Hill and follow it up by a cup o' coffee at Farleys - a night on the Hill.
author: Troy E.

description: Four stars for now, since I've only been a few times.  They've all been good experiences, but I can't quite go to that last star without having tried the coffee.  You see, I've only ever had their tea, either in the form of a pot of looseleaf Puerh (a great way to blow a half hour) or a handful of chai lattes.  I highly recommend the chai if you like yours well-spiced and not too sweet.
author: Jay M.

description: I heart Farley's for their ability to amuse me every single time I'm there.  I've played a great game of scrabble there.  Been in awe over how they get that leaf design in their coffee.  Read a variety of the magazines they have for sale.  Listened to some great live music.  I hope the memories continue with you.  You're the light at the end of the tunnel when I end up waking up at 8 am on a Saturday morning and am unable to go back to sleep after going to sleep only 4 hours ago.
author: Jean A.

description: They stand by their motto of "community in a cup" - children's books in a basket available for families with young kids, board games including Scrabble, Balderdash and Clue for the kid in all of us, a wall full of magazines in the back that cater to every person's interest. I don't think I can ever get bored here. It's one of those places where you can take a seat...and the time can just pass away. It's a cool place, but I can't give it 5 stars just yet. I'll give them credit for listening to their customers: they have non-fat milk and wi-fi now. Happy? :)
author: Monica N.

description: I am quite fond of Farley's.  The atmosphere is laid back and comfortable;  the coffee is delicious (and they make a beautiful swirl on my yummy mocha).  They also have interesting entertainment.  I've heard some great tunes with live bands and had a great laugh at their stand-up comedy night.  One star dropped off because the service isn't very warm.
author: Melaina E.

description: These coffee server's just need to put a simple smile on their faces, or anything but the typical negative facade.   Sheesh....  Turn those frown's upside down.   Every morning, same drab, depressed "i do not want to be here, and i do not want to be serving you" look on their faces.    I'll keep going because its convenient and in my hood, but will tip accordingly, or motivate to Thinkers on 20th when I can.  Two stars cause the venu is comfortable.
author: Jeff N.

description: One of my favorite places in the city.  Really, really good coffee, cool location, kick back atmosphere.  I always try to stop by this place when I'm back in town.
author: Eric L.

description:
Can you say double cafe creme? I don't know any other place that knows just how to make this delicious combination of espresso and just the right amount of milk: less than a cappuccino but wetter than a macchiato. Yum!
Farley's is no-nonsense. You will not find a long line of people here asking for half-decaf nonfat soy milk frappa-somethings! These people know coffee and also serve a mean peanut butter cookie.
If you don't come for the board games, cool atmosphere, sidewalk tables where you can sit with your dog, or the art, come for the magazines. Farley's has the best selection of art and design magazines  that I've found in one place in the entire city.
author: Jackie C.

description: I really like this place, great vibe, quirky staff and great coffee.  What more can you ask for from your basic coffee house...  If there is any downside, it's the flies buzzing around when it's warm.
author: Darren Z.

description: I love this place.  The people who work here are friendly and know how to make good coffee.  The place is unpretentious and it's a great place to relax, bring a computer to surf using their free wifi, browse some magazines, or come with friends.  Forget Starbucks!
author: Naomi N.

description: a very nice coffee house way out in the cuts of Portrero Hill. Amazing magazine selection. Plenty of places to sit and loiter.Cute and hip staff. Our friend is showing his art here for the month of July and it's a great spot to show work (note to self!).
author: Lauren V.

description: Hard to go wrong here. Genius spot, great coffee/espresso, and iced latte. I drink iced lattes in the middle of winter...a vice I suppose. Plus, it has one of the best mag/newspaper selections in the city (another vice). There is also a bunch of good outdoor seating up and down the block on both sides of the street! Get over there now!
author: Jason M.

description:
a good soy latte to be had here.   atmosphere is chill, pretty basic.  people who work there are soooome what friendly.  


ya, thats pretty much it.
author: C S.

description: The people working here are consistently rude, and unhappy. I've heard them cussing and talking about patrons while waiting for my coffee.  They seem angry to be working morning, noon and night.  The coffee is fine, but not worth having to interface with terrible acting people.
author: Julie H.

description: My all time Favorite Cafe' in San Francisco. Woohoo! As good as it gets! :)
author: jamie c.

description: Cool, neighborhood coffee joint.  Added plus is they will actually give you a ceramic mug for your coffee.  Something very homey about not having to drink out of a paper cup.  Music is nice, great magazine selection.
author: Todd S.

description:
This is sort of coffeehouse I wish I had in my neighborhood...but instead I have haul my ass to Potrero Hill for the sort of ambiance that is no longer given in so many of our grand city's other "cafe's" (not to mention the zilch-o ambiance of a Starbucks or Tulley's)...

Okay, so they don't offer non-fat...who cares...then drink tea...
author: Hannah H.

description: I am limited in my ability to review Farley's, in that I will normally only drink Hot Chocolate.  That disclaimer aside, I am generally quite happy with their ability to make said beverage.  The mug size, if drinking there, is also very generious.  I generally don't have a big problem with the wait, although it might not be the place for you if you need to be in and out in a minute.  The selection of local papers and games help contrbiute to a nice atmosphere.  A very good choice if you want somewhere to read for an hour or so.
author: Alured P.

description:
It is a good venue. There is nothing spectacular about it, just a nice, quiet place to go have coffee or surf the web. 

I do like that they have board games there, though.
author: Rahul T.

description: There are coffee shops and than there is Farley's.  I was so impressed with this place-coffee, a great selection of teas, artsy setting, board games, magazines, a mix-match of unique people scattered about, etc. etc.  It's local, has that small-town feel and is homey.  One cannot go here and not enjoy themselves-it was relaxing just as much as it was fun!  Farley's is an inspiration of what coffee shops should be and makes Starbucks look like a cheap $2 hooker!!!  ;)
author: Steven K.

description: Cozy neighborhood coffee shop. A place to relax and enjoy your drink or just hang out. They also offer live entertainment. Great place and great coffee/tea.
author: Jamie E.

description: This coffee shop rocks for several reasons besides good coffee. First, the newsstand is well stocked and delectable, and the owner doesn't have a "pay to read" policy. Second, it's a community spot, they sponsor all sorts of events like pumpkin carving contests and live bands. Third, you can bring in outside food to enjoy there. Fourth, it's a coffee shop where people actually talk to each other, instead of the kind that look like mausoleums/Apple product conventions with people glued to laptops. Lastly, baristas have excellent taste in music. Sadly, they do not offer a NF or 2% milk option or any kind of syrups and flavorings. But the pastries rock.
author: Francisca J.

description: Best coffee on the Hill, maybe in town (not to offense our Italian friends on Northbeach, of course... Caf Roma and neighbors are still top rank). People are charming, and it's the best way to take a break and enjoy a well-deserved pause. It would be so nice if Farley's could install a free WiFi access point though, just to make this afternoon break even better.
author: Philippe B.

description: The staff is pretty grumpy as mentioned before.  The coffee is good, but I have issues with the fact that they only sell one size.  Whassup wit dat?  I do love the collection of magazines, especially the English celeb rags.  Those totally rock.
author: Lesley G.

description: Farley's is the quintessential local coffee house that reflects the cultural diversity of the hill and sf. great open seating, periodic art shows on the walls, super high ceiling, and an attitude for the ages. Read, talk, people watch, or just grab and run if you love independent establishments that reflect local cultural. Farley's stands tall against the onslaught of big coffee house chains that reflect the evolution of brands built somewhere else. Uniquely Potrero!
author: ed h.

description: Have work meetings here and drink coffee. Perfect combo.
author: Kathleen M.

description: Funny how you can come in the morning and be greeted by someone grumpier than you, but come in the afternoon be greeted by name and a smile. As it is my neighborhood coffeehouse, I usually stop in here a few times a day. In the morning I get my double latte and my butter-jam and read the Comical, finishing up with the Soduku. I get to pet some dogs, see some friends and wake up, followed by an amazing view of the Cit-aaay on my way home to start my day. In the afternoon I stop in for a double Cafe Creme and super-rich brownie before heading off to work.
author: Alex H.

description: So their coffee is almost three green ones, and it's always a little cold, but the gorgeous and funky people that come in and out are great subjects for people watching. Good spot for writing papers. If you don't get distracted by the cute barista boys, that is.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Oh you silly people who complain about Farley's rudeness.  You should have gone there in the old days!  I used to only order things from the counter near the register because I was so afraid of making the staff walk back to get something for me.  The attitude is half the charm.  Sincerity over ass kissing any day!  Now I'm biased, I admit, because I worked there for years, but still.  Their espresso drinks kick ass, nobody else comes close.  I may not be a fan of the recent changes...adding soy milk was bad enough (and I'm a vegan) but nonfat...it's just hard to deal with.  It will take a lot more than nonfat milk and wifi, however, to bring Farley's down.  Farley's is way of life and a community and I love every bit of it.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Farley's is ok.  
The coffee is hit or miss.  
The staff is mostly cranky hipsters.  
It's a nice place to sit and read a paper though.
author: Kate M.

description:
This place is aight.  I can deal with the lack of wifi as I can see the positives in not having it there, and the mag selection rocks.  The coffee is good, but not great.  Lots of seating and the ambiance is good overall.  

Giving this place a 3 star rating because of the bad service and rude personnel.  Farley's is a victim of the proletariat hipster cancer that's metastized in San Francisco.  Every time I come to that place I feel like I don't have enough tattoos.  So lame.

I know it's bad form to identify individual employees but I just wanted to point out the barista with the short grey hair and black thick framed glasses is awesome!  He's very friendly to all customers and doesn't let his hipsterness get in the way.  Keep on keepin on, brotha!
author: Too Cool F.

description: Ah, My SUnday morning ritual........Coffee and a strawberry scone from Farley's. Employees are always nice, Coffee always taste the same (Damn good).  Its cash only but very inexpensive. Try the Scones, they seriously rock!
author: Blake C.

description:
I moved to San Francisco from Seattle in 2007. Although the weather in SF is a little gloomy at times, nothing can compare to Seattle's corner on the market for number of days spent in drizzle and depressingly low clouds. The result of such a depressing place to live is amazing coffee is roasted and prepared virtually everywhere; folks up there need a "bump" more than you might imagine. Carefully prepared, Farley's coffee is the best cup of coffee I've been able to find outside the boundaries of the Emerald City.

When you know your craft, there is always going to be an attitude about what you do. Good coffee is hard to find, but great coffee is an art. The snotty baristas turn into heartfelt artisans once you show that you understand this. Like any artist, they appreciate being recognized for their artistic talents. I will happily wait 15 minutes for a great cup of coffee!
author: Rachael E.

description:
ok, high priced, small cup'ed coffee (but you get a free refill if you have time to hang out) the espresso is so-so. wonderful magazine selection, average on the goodies. 

the line to the cash register is confusing because of the table right in the middle of it. but once you get away from the "cash register / magazine rack / path to restroom / condiment shelf / 2 tables for 2 area" the general atmosphere is conducive to relaxed goodness. 

also, the staff seems to have a high turnover rate, so maybe the grumpiness some others have experienced there is just misdirected anger about other behind the scenes stuff...
author: Sucka X.

description: My GF and I go to "Fartley's" all the time.  The coffee is made exactly the way I like it.  A double latte is nice and strong with a cool design on the top.  Fartley's is one of those places where people hang out during the day who don't have 9-5 jobs (or jobs) who are these people? - bastards.   I do not have anything against Starbucks, but if one of those places were to go in close around Fartley's I really enjoy knowing that all hell would break loose in Pot Hill.  Yea, I guess there is some tude about that so I'm always careful not to order a "tall" latte or anything because that isn't an option on the giant menu.
author: Thomas D.

description:
The Baristas are from Hollywood I love it... what an attitude.
Coffee was good but for my neighorhood coffee spot  no thanks the staff has got to go.  I deal with angry people all day long. A smile would be awesome at the end of the day.

Fan of the coffee kill the attitude....err and thinkers is gone where to now
author: Diane f.

description:
If you don't go to Starbucks because their coffee is "too strong" then this is not the place for you. Farley's has some darn good coffee,  some of the best in the city. I am a roaster myself so I should know.  

Some might bitch and moan about their baristas being snooty or rude but they have always been decent to me. Anyways, if you have a problem with the whole hipster vibe, how can you possibly manage to live in San Francisco!! Potrero hill yuppies need to get over themselves. 

All I can say is this: If your in the market for a real coffee shop experience, come to Farley's, its got what you need: Good coffee, nice neighborhood feel, free internet, outdoor seating and some tasty naughty snacks!
author: chiara b.

description: Drinks are ok, plenty of cookies to make you go crazy. The guys behind the counter play whatever music their into so be ready to hear some crazy stuff. HA, some of it's ok. Good location and I think that's all you need to stay in business. I'm not sure where Mo. P got the attitude from, everyone there seems pretty respectable like....
author: Ryan F.

description: the coffee is great, the space is nice and open. they have wifi (although it's through an oustide service) and they let you stay to study/work all day. the scones are delicious. five stars for all of that. minus two stars for the rudeness of most of the baristas, which is odd because with all of their photos of the locals on the walls and shared journals to write in, they seem like they're supposed to care about community and all that. after about 10-15 visits though, i've encountered one friendly barista and that was today. the rest are curt with everyone and seem to be annoyed that they have customers at all.
author: Andrea T.

description: Farley's is simply a terrific place to relax and drink coffee in a friendly neighborhood. I usually stop by alone these days to look at magazines, try a fresh pastry, or sip a latte. When my kids were small, they would accompany me for an orange juice and madeleine before we headed over to Christopher's Books. Owner and employees and customers are the reason San Francisco is still a fantastic place to live. Go Farley's!!
author: Mary G.

description: tons of magazines, decent coffee, and scrabble. what more could you want from a coffee shop?
author: Elle B.

description: This is the closest coffee shop to my house, so that's the main reason I go here all the time.  Best latte I've ever had.  Love the magazine selection, window seats, sort of rugged decor, and all the games available to play while inside.  Love the homeless man asleep at the table next to me; looked sort of dead and was holding a book the whole time.  Pie, pumpkin chocolate bread, and ham croissants are perfect.  A bit pricey.  Some of the staff behind the counter are friendlier than others, but none of them have been rude to me.  I love that I can just sort of hang around in here all day.  A few cute employee dudes.  Overall, pretty good.
author: Tuesday J.

description:
ok I have read many of the reviews and through personal experience 
have decided someone needs to fire that skinny douchey barista, period

take back farley's
author: joe b.

description: You know what I really like being able to do at a coffee shop? Get a cup of coffee. Guess what, Farley's makes good, more importantly, STRONG, coffee, quickly. If you want a triple nonfat soy protein wheat-grass latte reduction served by a brainwashed loser with a shit-eating grin, I recommend you head to one of the 100 or more corporate coffee shops in the city. Sure, the staff can be, let's say, less than amicable, but, having to deal with cranky, under-caffeinated people at 7 o'clock in the morning every day might put a chip in your shoulders too, friends.  All I know is, I get exactly what I'm looking for, plus you just can't fuck with the dirt bombs doughnut muffins, they are incredible. If you're a coffee expert, buy a french press and shut up, if you're a thin-skinned bonehead that can't get over the fact that there's only one size cup, go to the starbuck's that inevitably located within walking, nay, driving distance (you have a hybrid, right?) of the neighborhood you're currently gentrifying.
author: Willy M.

description: decent place after 1 try. had the curry pumpkin soup with salad with chicken on top. pretty pricey but the food is fresh.
author: Mary C.

description: Coffee isn't bad, there is a nice little assortment of breakfast pastries. However the service is quite lacking. i have yet to get a glimpse of a smile from the staff there, I thought maybe for some reason they just didn't like me, but it seems like this is the way they treat everyone...
author: Lisa T.

description: I LOVE Farley's!  Every latte I've ever had there was perfectly made!  Even though I live between North Beach & Russian Hill, with 5 cafes within 2 block radius, I would still drive all the way across town for a Farley's latte. If I'm driving back on 101N when Farley's open, I always get off at the Vermont St. exit just so I can stop at Farleys.  The  staff have always been friendly to me.  I just wish they haven't given in to the non-fat  drinkers!  I respected Farley's for serving the "real" thing for the longest time. Well, it's s tough economy and they have to do what they have to do to broaden their customer base.  Still, I love Farley's!
author: Lori H.

description: I go to Farley's because they have the best chai latte in town.  Also because it is blks from my home in Potrero Hill.  Two downers are the steep price for soy instead of milk....$.60 and some (1 or 2) of the staff have an attitude like they are doing me a favor.  I can deal with the attitude in order to support the local small business.
author: G R.

description: I've had to do a fair bit of studying the fast couple weeks and have been trying out coffee shops around the city.  A friend lives in Potrero Hill so I had walked by Farley's on the way to his house and  thought that I would give it a shot.  Conclusion is: one of the best places in the city.  The coffee and snacks looked like your standard fare, although I can only attest to the current tea which was tasty. The part of Farley's that will be bringing me back is the awesome magazine rack, the journals full of patron doodles, and the table next to me that seemed to know everyone who walked through they door.  A great place to spend the afternoon.
author: Elliot A.

description: Farley's is a TRUE neighborhood coffee shop and neighborhood contributor. Great espresso, tea and pastries (if you pick the right ones). Not always impressed by the regular coffee although, now that they are having their own beans roasted, this might be improving. Amazingly kid & pet friendly. The rotating art displays are always interesting if not top quality and ho can beat the pet parade & photo gallery?? Totally incredible magazine selection for a newsstand let alone a coffee shop. Sometimes I wind up buying less that I would because they do not take credit cards which would also help me out as a business owner for expense tracking purposes. In general, the staff is quite delightful especially if you smile at them and do not treat them like crap like many patrons tend to do. Unfortunatly, like with any business there are a few bad apples to spoil the bunch.
author: CJ S.

description: Hands down, best soy lattes in the city.  I take off one star for the staff being rude at times.
author: Michael M.

description: Is it possible to give something a zero star rating?  I have lived down the street from Farley's for over 10 years.  Cool looking place, perfect hangout, but the service can be unbelievably rude.  I remember being yelled at because the employee made me the wrong drink, and clearly that was my fault.  My 75 year old mother was yelled at by worker because she did not order fast enough.  Farley's is like a little club of regulars.   If you are not one of the "cool regulars" you get treated very poorly.  I really do not need to belong to a fraternity at this point (or really ever) in my life.  I always laugh when Farley's is rated as a great coffee shop.  Sad little place.  Get a life people.
author: Jose M.

description: Farley's, once my lil old neighborhood escape say circa 1995-2000... pre-ball park construction, pre 3rd street construction... this was a place where I could really chill out, check out my favorite rags, just get a plain ol cup of coffee, and do laundry accross the street. Now the place is filled  with some jerk in line ahead of me wanting some soy decaf double shot hazelnut skinny drink, and wanting to know if the coffee beans were picked by slave trade laborists. Though it still has it's vicotrian neighborhood charm, the added patrons seem to clutter the setting, altering the once low-key atmosphere.  Tables are now littered with laptops.  Gone are the local artsy types, but you'll still see a few here and there.  I know it may not have been the owners direction to flow this way, but they are a surving independent business, so I'll support them for that! Screw the Starbucks that opened up on 16th & Kansas. Stick to a place where theres some integrity behind it.  One milk used to be thier mantra, so i'm a lil displaced to see soy milk there, but they try hard to keep it real, the staff here is really cool, and the owner still has his heart it in to keep this place running.
author: B H.

description: A coffee shop with a really great neighborhood vibe. Very decent espresso drinks, tasty edibles, and BOARD GAMES. The one negative thing is that the door is always open and it gets kind of cold. But on a warm-ish day, this place can't be beat.
author: Lester D.

description: good coffee, cool location, lots of magazines, rather pretentious staff.
author: Jill k.

description: I am a regular sporadic visitor of this spot, ie if I'm grabbing a bite to eat at the restaurants on 18th, catching a show, or dropping off students in the developments nearby, I'll usually end up here too. Last week, I had a meeting at a school down the street where the bathrooms were locked, so I made a pit stop here afterwards. The barristo poured me a delicious pg tips iced tea (an english brand i don't run across too often) and as I grabbed a tasty peanut butter cookie, he let me know that I could get a refill when I was done.   It was still toasty as usual on the Hill in the late afternoon & amazing light was streaming through the large front windows.  The gallery of photos on the walls were striking but unpretentious, including some portraits of the cafe workers, who are probably students from CCA, the pricey art school down the hill-- which means they are either trust funders or being crushed by massive student loans. You don't even have to acknowledge the 2.0 types at the sidewalk tables if that's not your scene (hey, they probably are yelp designers), but they do have cute dogs.  The inside of the cafe is airy and bright, and you can pick up some arty zines with your coffee. My pit stop in their tiny W.C. had turned into a much needed  hour of cafe decompression...
author: Miz J.

description: i do love this coffee - after my #1 fav, Ritual.  cute decor, great vibe.  and again excellent coffee.
author: Erika Y.

description: Out of all the coffee houses in Potrero Hill Farley's is by far my favorite. Initially, it is shocking that they only have one size of cup and only whole milk but you get over that once you take a sip of their drinks. They are that good to make you not care that they are laden with fat. Even when they are crowded, the simplicity of the Farley's menu makes the line move quickly. There is none of that indecisive ordering that will often turn a  2 minute wait turn into a 10 minute wait. Bottom line is, Farley's produces a great drink and I'll take their fatty latte over a "not enough foam, burnt espresso bean tasting, let the shot sit too long" latte any day. Extra star goes to the fact that they have a wide selection of pastries and their beans are fair trade and organic.
author: Sierra d.

description: This coffee house has so my charm and character.  It's definitely not a starbucks...the menu has the basics and one size cup.  But I had the best mocha I've ever had the Sunday morning.  Plus, you can get some food next door at Hazel's and take a seat at Farley's to eat and have a cup of coffee.  It's just delightful!
author: Kelly M.

description: I went to Oakland Art Murmur tonight and next to one of the gallerys on Grand was the party for Farley's in Oakland, Community in a Cup.  They threw a great party:  the panini sandwiches kept coming out with different ingredients - basil/tomatoes/cheese; zuccini/cheese; sausage/cheese.  I don't make them sound nearly as good as they were.  There was also a 3-tiered service of sweets:  macaroons, chocolate pecan chews and chocolate chip cookies.  Yum!  Great wines too.  The Farley's staff were friendly and very efficient.  Greatly organized event!
author: JK S.
